Question: Which muscles does the musculocutaneous nerve supply?
OptionC: extensor Carpi ulnaris, extensor digitorum, extensor carpi radialis

Question: Which nerve innervates the lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus?

Mr Davies is unable to engage in physical activity without sudden fatigue. He goes to his GP and is diagnosed with Mcardle's disease. This metabolic condition is the inability to breakdown what molecule?
Explanation:
B - glycogen 

Mcardle's disease is a glycogen storage disease that relates to the inability to break down glycogen stores in muscles through glycogenolysis, thus not being able to release energy through glycolysis, resulting in rapid fatigue and failure to continue.

Question: Which of the following muscles is not a rotator cuff muscle?
Explanation: Serratus anterior is not a rotator cuff muscle. It originates from the top 8-9 ribs. Its main part lies deep under the scapula and the pectoral muscles.

Question: Which forearm muscle belongs to the anterior superficial layer?
Explanation: This is in the superficial layer of the anterior compartment of the forearm

Question: A patient enters a GP surgery having hit her elbow on a banister whilst walking down the stairs. When making a fist, only her pinky and ring finger are able to bend. What nerve has the patient damaged?
Explanation: The condition is known as the "sign of benediction", and is caused when the median nerve is damaged at the wrist or elbow.

Question: What is the term given to contraction where the pressure increases in the ventricles but there is no volume change (happens in early ventricular systole)
Which nerve supplies the teres minor muscle
Explanation: The axillary nerve innervates the teres minor muscle

Question: Mr smith presents with a winged scapula following an emergency procedure (chest tube insertion) this can be explained due to damaged caused to a nerve. What nerve would this be?
Explanation: The answer is long thoracic nerve. this innervates Serratus anterior which ”holds” the scapula close to the thorax. A chest tube can damage this as it can sever the long thoracic nerve when inserted.

Question: Mr K comes into A&E with a winged scapula following a motorcycle accident. Which nerve has been damaged?
Explanation: A winged scapula occurs as a result of damage to the long thoracic nerve (C5-C7), which innervates serratus anterior.

Question: Which muscles insert on to the coracoid process?
OptionA: Deltoid, long head of biceps brachii and coracobrachialis
OptionB: Pectoralis minor, coracobrachialis and the short head of biceps brachii
OptionD: Coracobrachialis, latissimus dorsi and the short head of biceps brachii
OptionE: Pectoralis major, coracobrachialis and the long head of biceps brachii
Explanation: The long head of biceps brachii inserts on to the scapula (goes over the shoulder) and pectoralis major and deltoid insert on to the humerus.

Question: Mr Slade visits hospital with paralysis due to Tetradoxin poisoning. He is unable to move. Which ion channels in the body has become blocked causing the paralysis?
Explanation: Tetradoxin blocks Na+ preventing an action potential from being initiated.

Question: What nerve innervates Biceps Brachii?
Explanation: The musculocutaneous nerve innervates Biceps Brachii.

Question: Mrs Adams complains of pain in her hand and tingling. The doctor diagnoses her with carpal tunnel syndrome. What nerve is being compressed in carpal tunnel syndrome?
Explanation: The median nerve travels to the wrist through the carpal tunnel. Compression of the nerve due to swelling etc can cause tingling and pain in the hand.

Question: What are the 3 deep structures of the anterior forearm?
OptionA: Flexor Carpi Radialis, Flexor Capri Ulnaris, Pronator Teres
OptionB: Flexor Digitorum Profundus, Flexor Pollicis Longus, Pronator Teres
OptionC: Extensor Radialis Longus, Extensor Radialis Brevis, Extensor Digiti Minimi
OptionD: Flexor Digitorum Profundus, Flexor Pollicis Longus, Pronator Quadratus
OptionE: Flexor Digitorum Profundus, Flexor Capri Ulnaris, Pronator Teres
Explanation:
Flexor Digitorum Profundus

Attachments: Originates from the ulna and associated interosseous membrane. At the wrist, it splits into four tendons, that pass through the carpal tunnel and attach to the distal phalanges of the four fingers.
Actions: It is the only muscle that can flex the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers. It also flexes at metacarpophalangeal joints and at the wrist.
Innervation: The medial half (acts on the little and ring fingers) is innervated by the ulnar nerve. The lateral half (acts on the middle and index fingers) is innervated by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve.

Flexor Pollicis Longus

This muscle lies laterally to the FDP.

Attachments: Originates from the anterior surface of the radius, and surrounding interosseous membrane. Attaches to the base of the distal phalanx of the thumb.
Actions: Flexes the interphalangeal joint and metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb.
Innervation: Median nerve (anterior interosseous branch).

Pronator Quadratus

A square shaped muscle, found deep to the tendons of the FDP and FPL.

Attachments: Originates from the anterior surface of the ulna, and attaches to the anterior surface of the radius.
Actions: Pronates the forearm.
Innervation: Median nerve (anterior interosseous branch).

 

https://teachmeanatomy.info/upper-limb/muscles/anterior-forearm/

Question: Mr Jones attended his GP and was experiencing muscle cramps and burning. This may be due to a build up in lactic acid from anaerobic respiration. Which enzyme is responsible for the conversion of lactate to pyruvate?
Explanation: Lactate dehydrogenase converts lactate to pyruvate in a redox reaction. Lactate is oxidised to pyruvate.

Question:
A 15 year old boy comes into the A and E after he has fallen on his hand while it was outstretched.

 

Which carpal bone might be at risk of being fractured without the fracture being clear on an X-ray?
Explanation: scaphoid

Question: A boy comes into A&E having fallen on an outstretched arm. He feels pain when you press on the border of the anatomical snuff box. Which bone could be fractured?
Explanation: The scaphoid bone is the floor of the anatomical snuff box.

Question: Mr. Beane visited his GP to get his blood preesure checked, and to check his blood group with a blood test early on a Tuesday Morning. His blood pressure was unusually high compared to the last vist. On his last visit he got his blood pressure checked and had to give a urine sample. Why do you think his blood pressure was unusually high?
OptionB: He has previously fainted at the sight of blood and is worried he may faint in front of his GP.
OptionC: He is under a lot of stress at work.
OptionD: He is in a rush to collect his children from school.
OptionE: He is worried about the result of his blood test.
Explanation: He has a phobia of needles but has not disclosed this to his GP as he sees this as a sign of weakness.

Question: How many heads does the tricep have ?
Explanation: It has a lateral head, medial head and a long head

Question:
Mrs. Smith presents to her GP unable  to spread or pull together her fingers. Her GP suspects she may have ‘Claw Hand’.

 

Which nerve must be affected for this to be the case?
Explanation: https://teachmeanatomy.info/upper-limb/nerves/ulnar-nerve/

Question: Why is the shoulder joint easily dislocated?
OptionA: The rotator cuff muscles are not strong enough to hold the humerus in place.
OptionB: The position which people fall from heights usually involves them landing on their shoulder first, dislocating it.
OptionC: The humerus is such a strong bone, instead of snapping it dislocates.
OptionD: The surface area of the glenoid fossa is considerably smaller than the epiphyses of the humerus, meaning it moves out of place easily.
OptionE: Over training of subscapularis pulls the humerus out of place.

Question:
A patient comes into A & E with an injury to their arm. An examination of the patient is taken and shows that they are only able to abduct their arm the first 15 degrees. X-ray scan shows that they have a fracture their surgical neck of the humerus

 

 

What nerve is most likely to be damaged?
Explanation: The axillary nerve is affected as the supraspinatus ables abduction the first 15 degrees. Whilst the deltoid which is supplied by the axillary nerve abducts from 15-90 degrees. A fracture to the surgical neck often damages the axillary nerve

Question: Which aspect of an ECG describes ventricular depolarisation?
Explanation:
P wave is atrial depolarisation

T wave is ventricular repolarisation 

QRS complex is ventricular depolarisation

Question: Miss Darcey attends a GP appointment after noticing her shoulder blade is sticking way out her back. Dr Nathan explains that she has a condition known as winged scapula caused by damage to one of her nerves. Which nerve has been damaged?
Explanation: Damage to the Long Thoracic Nerve causes paralysis of serratus anterior, leading to winging of the scapula.

Question: Mr Jones presents to A+E with a winged scapula. It is suspected that he may have damage to the nerve that innervates serratus anterior. Whitch nerve innervates serratus anterior?
Explanation: Serratus anterior is innervated by the long thoracic nerve

Question: Ground substance is a highly hydrated semi-solid gel mostly made up of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). Which of the following is an example of a GAG often used in skin-care products?
Explanation: Hyaluronic acid has the ability to massively increase in volume and give the skin a fuller-look. Therefore it is used in anti-wrinkle creams.

Question: Bob is not feeling well. He does not reply when you call for him, but he moves his leg back when something bumps across it. What level of consciousness would you give to him?
Explanation:
Pain is the correct answer because it just is. Just search it up baby gorl xx

 

(In all seriousness, he is not completely unresponsive to stimuli nor is he able to answer or respond to your verbal command)
Tags: Nerve damage, AVPU, consciousness, mental status

Question:
Miss Teddy attended A&E after falling from a tree whilst playing with her friends.

She complained about having a lot of pain in her arm. The patient is unable to extend at the wrist and fingers.

Following an X-Ray, a fracture was clearly identified in the shaft of the humerus. 

Which nerve may be damaged?
Explanation:
The radial nerve is tightly bound within the spiral groove of the humerus. Thus, it is most susceptible to damage with a fracture of the humeral shaft.

https://teachmeanatomy.info/upper-limb/nerves/radial-nerve/

Question: A patient has come to you complaining of pain in their wrist due to a recent fall. Where would you palpate the skin to determine if they have fractured their scaphoid?
Explanation: The anatomical snuffbox a triangular patch of skin over the lateral carpal bones. Of the eight carpal bones, the scaphoid lies below the anatomical snuffbox and pressing this patch of skin will indicate whether the patient has fractured their scaphoid.

Question: Mr Ketone, 49, reported feeling faint on Monday morning. After having his blood glucose monitored, Mr Ketone was identified as being hypoglycemic. What is the average blood glucose range among non-diabetics?
Explanation: 4-8mmol/L is the average blood glucose range for non diabetics. Do not be confused by the units. The standard units are mmol/L.

Question: What nerve innervates pectoralis minor?
Explanation:
The dorsal scapular nerve supplies the rhomboids and levator scapulae 

The medial and pectoral nerve supplies pectoralis major 

The axillary nerve supplies the deltoid and teres minor 

 The lateral pectoral nerve sends a branch out to form the medial pectoral nerve which then innervates pectoralis minor

 

Therefore , the answer is B

Question: Mrs. Jones has a fracture in the surgical neck of her humerus. What nerve might she have also damaged?
Explanation: The axillary nerve passes medially to the surgical neck of the humerus and may be damaged in a surgical neck fracture. Symptoms of this would include weakness and loss of sensation in the shoulder region.

Question: John took part in a 100m sprint. This event took a total of 11 seconds. He mainly used anaerobic respiration. In the Absence of oxygen, levels of Pyruvate and NADH increase. What enzyme is used to catalyse the removal of these 2 molecules?
Explanation:
pyruvate kinase catalyses the conversion of PEP to Pyruvate

Phosphoprotein phosphatase dephosphorylates the PFK-2/FBPase-2 complex

Phosphofructokinase catalyses the conversion of Fru-6-phosphate to Fru-1,6-BP

Gluconeogenesis is the process of generating new glucose 

Lactate dehydrogenase is the answer as it catalyses this reaction as it reduces pyruvate to lactate with the use of NADH

Question: Dr Edwards is currently holding a tutorial for year 1 medical students when he forgets the answer to a question asked by a question. What is the name of the enzyme that catalyzes the reversible transfer of a phosphate group from 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate to ADP producing 3-phosphoglycerate and ATP
Explanation: Check Lecture powerpoint-  Releasing energy from food without oxygen

Question: Mr Jones has presented to his GP and has suspected damage to his Teres Minor muscle. Where does the teres minor insert?
Explanation: The Teres minor muscle originates from the middle third lateral border of the scapula above the teres major, and inserts on the interior facet of greater tuberosity of the humerus.
Tags: Anatomy of upper limb, Anatomy of Upper Limb

Question: Mr. Jones is complaining of blisters in his mouth and skin, this is a result of a condition called Pemphigus Vulgaris; this effects the desmosomes between cells. How does this cause blistering?
OptionA: Fluids enter the membranes of the cell and causes them to burst.
OptionB: Desmoglein proteins increase in size and block pathways between cells.
OptionC: Fluid enters the gaps between cells and causes them to separate.
OptionD: Keratin filaments wrap around the cells and this stops the cell getting any nutrients.
OptionE: Fluid surrounds the cell and stops the cells from moving.
Explanation: This is because antibodies are made to break down the desmosomes this causes the cells to no longer be linked, fluid then floods into the gaps between these cells and causes them to be separated; this causes blisters to appear.

Question: Which part of the Scapula articulates with the clavicle
Explanation: The acromion articulates with the anatomical end of the clavicle.

Question: What is the function of NEWS?
OptionA: It is a tracking system used in hospitals, that monitors basic physical signs.
OptionB: It is used by clinicians when handing over the patient to another ward.
OptionC: It stands for: National Early Warning Score.
OptionD: Identifies patient at risk of deterioration and can be used to priorities urgent treatment.
Explanation: It does stand for National Early Warning Score. However, that does not explain the function of it. It is a tracking system, however, it is also a trigger system. If it was only a tracking system, it wouldn't be acted upon. It is used with the SBAR handover tool, but only when the score aggregated requires you to seek assistance from a senior colleague. You would use it to help to inform the senior colleague of the situation and assessment of the patient.

Question:
Mr Patel books an appointment at the GP  because he has lost sensation around the proximal area of his humerus: He googles his symptoms up and find out this area is also known as the Sergeant's Patch.

Which nerve could possbibly be damaged?

A medical student is revising the brachial plexus.He notices in his textbook that a page has been ripped out. The page that is missing relates to the innervation of latissimus dorsi. What nerve innervates latissimus dorsi??
Explanation: Thoracodorsal nerve innervates latissimus dorsi and comes off the brachial plexus at the posterior cord.

Question: Which of the following is not part of the origin of brachial plexus?
Explanation: C5-C8,T1 are the origins

Tags: Upper Limb Anatomy, Brachial Plexus, Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Nerve damage

Question: Hexokinase is regulated by which of the following molecules?
Explanation: glucose 6 phosphate

Question: Where does the long head of biceps brachii originate ?
Explanation:
The long head of biceps brachii originates from the supragelnoid tubercle 

 

The short head originates from the coccoid process, where chorocbrachialis also emerges from

Question: Mr. John is a patient that has just entered the GP and complains of an inability to flex the arm at the elbow joint. Which muscles are involved in the flexion of the arm at the elbow joint?
Explanation: The muscles involved in the flexion of the arm at the elbow joint are found in the anterior compartment of the arm. These include biceps brachii, brachioradialis and brachialis.
Tags: Upper Limb Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb

Question:
A patient named Mr John has been diagnosed with diabetes and needs to get his blood pressure taken today in the hospital.

 

Alicia, a first year student on her first day of placement, will be taking his blood pressure for the first time.

 

Which artery should she be looking for to find the systolic blood pressure?
Explanation: The pulse of the brachial artery is palpable on the anterior aspect of the elbow, thus it would be easy to use a stethoscope to listen out for the Korotkov sounds and determine the blood pressure of a patient.
Tags: Vital signs, Anatomy of upper limb, Clinical

Question: Mr Allen has an ECG. When interpreting the ECG you notice an abnormality with the P wave. What stage of the cardiac cycle is affected.
Explanation:
The P wave is associated with atrial depolarisation

The QRS complex is associated with ventricular depolarisation but atrial repolarisation also occurs here.

The T wave is associated with ventricular repolarisation

Question: Cell culture studies have been done on Mr Humphrey after referral by his GP. Specialists notice he has an abnormality in complex V of the mitochondrial electron transport chain. Under normal conditions, diffusion of which ion through the protein drives ATP production?
Explanation: H+ diffuses down its electrochemical gradient back into the mitochondrial matrix. This drives rotation of ATP synthase (complex V) forming ATP from ADP and Pi.

Question: A patient presents with symptoms that indicate rupture of the biceps tendon. His upper arm has a 'popeye' appearance but he isn't experiencing much weakness in the upper arm. Which major branch of brachial plexus innervates the biceps brachii muscle?
Explanation: Musculocutaneous nerve innervates biceps brachii, brachialis and coracobrachialis muscles in the upper arm
Tags: Upper Limb Anatomy, Brachial Plexus, Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Clinical

Question: A young boy has fractured the surgical neck of the humerus while playing rugby. What nerve could possibly be damaged and how would damage to this nerve present clinically ?
OptionC: axillary nerve, presented as loss of sensation in anterior arm
Explanation: radial nerve damaged, as it passes through the radial groove on the humerus. Damage to the radial nerve is presented as "wrist drop"
Tags: Brachial Plexus, Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Nerve damage

Question: You are waiting at the finish line of a marathon, and see a runner approach, they appear to have lost control of their limbs and are unable to coordinate and continue running. What is the most likely cause of this.
OptionA: They are so emotionally overwhelmed to have reached the finish line that they can't keep going.
OptionB: They are severely dehydrated from the race causing them to feel faint.
OptionC: They were not fit enough to run the race
OptionD: An excess of lactic acid is starting to breakdown muscle
OptionE: Overexertion in the race has depleted glycogen stores causing the runner to 'hit the wall'
Explanation: Depleted glycogen means there is insufficient available for the metabolism required to keep running.

Question: You're an F1 doctor on call and come across a patient with severe paresthesia and pain in the hand and arm. You reckon its a median nerve injury at the wrist caused by the median nerve entrapped under the flexor retinaculum. What syndrome may the patient have?
Explanation:
The median nerve runs under the flexor retinaculum into the palmar side of the hand to innervate the flexors of the hand. Injury can cause the entrapment of this nerve under the flexor retinaculum resulting in symptoms of pain and paresthesia in a patients hand. This leads to the Carpal Tunnel Syndrome. 

 

Duchenne Syndrome - muscle disease - myoglobin leaks out of muscles 

Turner Syndrome - Chromosomal disease - affects development in females 

Cubital Tunnel Syndrome - Pressure/stretching of ulnar nerve - pain and paresthesia in ring and small finger. 

Down Syndrome - Chromosomal disease - mongloid features

Question:
A medical student prepares for his anatomy exam the night before and realised that he knows nothing about the brachial plexus. He opens up his textbook and comes across the characteristic M shape made by the lateral and medial chords.

Which muscle does the musculocutaneous nerve not innervate?
Explanation: The answer is Deltoid since the musculocutaneous nerve does not innervate the deltoid.

Question: Which nerve innervates both the deltoid and teres minor muscles?
Explanation:
The correct answer is the axillary nerve. 

The axillary nerve forms from the C5 and C6 roots of the brachial plexus.

Question: You are running a marathon and have reached mile 23. What molecule are you mainly breaking down for use in respiration?
Explanation: By mile 23 you will have used up most of the glycogen reserves in your muscle cells so must use another energy source - from adaptations to exercise tutorial.

Question: Mr Jack could not shake Mr Paul's hand. All his fingers were stuck in a curved position. This created an awkward situation between them.Which nerve did Mr Jack damage?
Explanation: Claw hand aka Klumpke's Palsy occurs from excessive abduction and causes loss in sensation along the median side of the arm therefore the ulnar nerve would be damaged.

Question: In Erb's Palsy, which results from excessive increase in the angle between the neck and the shoulder, the roots of C5 and C6 are stretched or even tear. This can occur during childbirth or shoulder trauma. What muscles are likely to be effected?
OptionA: suprapinatus, infraspinatus, subclavius, biceps, brachialis, corachobrachialis, deltoid, and teres minor.
OptionB: suprapinatus, infraspinatus, subclavius, biceps, brachialis, corachobrachialis, deltoid, teres minor and teres major.
OptionC: suprapinatus, infraspinatus, subclavius, biceps, triceps, brachialis, corachobrachialis, and teres minor.
OptionD: biceps, triceps, brachialis, corachobrachialis, deltoid, teres minor, teres major
OptionE: biceps, triceps, brachialis, corachobrachialis, deltoid, teres minor, teres major, pectoralis major.
Explanation: When roots C5 and C6 are damaged, this effects the musculocutaneous nerve, suprascaoular nerve, axillary nerve and nerve to subclavius. The muscles effected are those that are innervated by these nerves.
Tags: Brachial Plexus, Anatomy of upper limb, Nerve damage

Question: Which nerve innervates the coracobrachialis?
Explanation:
Radial nerve --> posterior compartment of the forearm

Ulnar nerve --> anterior compartment of the forearm (flexor carpi ulnaris) and the hand (flexor digitorum profundus)

Median nerve --> anterior compartment of the forearm

Musculocutaneous nerve --> coracobrachialis, biceps brachii, brachialis

Axillary nerve --> deltoid, teres minor
Tags: Upper Limb Anatomy, Brachial Plexus, Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb

Question: What substrate is an activator of the PFK 1 enzyme in glycolysis?
Explanation: Fructose 2 6 bisphosphate is an allosteric activator of PFK 1

Question: Mrs. Williams goes to the GP and presents some pain when she tries to raise her left arm and says she it hurts when she lays on it when she’s sleeping. The doctor suspects shoulder impingement syndrome. What causes shoulder impingement syndrome?
Explanation: Subacromial bursitis is a common cause of shoulder pain that is usually related to shoulder impingement of your bursa between your rotator cuff tendons and bone (acromion). A swollen bursa creates friction in your shoulder spaces, limiting range of movement Or making the movement more painful.

Question: When a muscle contracts, which section of the fiber shortens?
Explanation: The I band is the section of the sarcomere that consists of just actin therefore is the lighter band. The A band is the section consisting of actin and myosin overlapping. As the muscles contract, the sarcomere shortens and the Z-lines move closer to each other. The actin and myosin overlap further which appears as the I Band (section with only actin) shortening.

Question: A patient tears their teres minor muscle , what will the patient struggle with?
Explanation:
the job of the teres minor is to provide stability to the rotator cuff however this job is mainly carried out by the tendons attaching to the humeral head.

As this injury is to the muscle and not the tendon the patient is likely to struggle more with adduction of the humerus rather than to suffer a dislocation.
Tags: Upper Limb Anatomy, Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Clinical

Question: Mr Williams has an x-ray on his injured arm. The x-ray shows he has fractured the surgical neck of his right humerus.  He also complains of weakness and numbness in his shoulder region and is unable to lift his arm over his head. The doctor suspects there is some nervous damage. Which nerve is most likely to have been damaged in his fall?

Mrs Phalange comes into A&E after a car accident and is unable to abduct her left arm. 

The nerve which supplies her deltoid muscle has been damaged. 

What nerve is the deltoid innervated by?
Explanation: The deltoid is innervated by the axillary nerve , which is one of the terminal branches of the brachial plexus

Question: Which enzyme directly regulates glycolysis in liver cells?
Explanation: Because Phosphofructokinase1(unregulated by fructo-2,6-bisphosphate which is regulated by the bifunctional enzyme PFK2/FBPase2) specifically phosphorylates fructose-6-phosphate into fructo-1,6-bisphosphate which is an intermediate in the glycolysis pathway.

Question: The following is the concentration of which ion (at resting potential) in an excitatory cell : inside the cell (150mM: 5mM)?
Explanation: At resting potential, there is a high concentration of K+ ions within the axon 150mM. There is a low concentration of K+ outside the membrane of 5mM. During repolarisation, the K+ ions have a net movement out of the cell through voltage gated potassium channels

Question: Which type of solute carrier allows the movement of two or more ions across the cell membrane in the same direction?
Dr Davies is measuring her patient's blood pressure. Over which artery should she place the stethoscope in order to hear the Korotkov sounds?

Mr. Wilson, aged 35 years old was recently told by his GP that he is at risk of developing type II diabetes. He has been advised to engage in a more active lifestyle by undertaking more physical exercise.

What physiological effect will increased physical exercise have on Mr. Wilson's health?
OptionA: May result in increased muscle mass which will increase Mr. Wilson's metabolic rate.
OptionB: May result in an increased number of GLUT-4 transporters in Mr. Wilson's muscles.
OptionC: May result in increased insulin production by islet cells.
OptionD: May result in an increased number of insulin receptors on Mr. Wilson's liver.
Explanation: GLUT4- is an insulin-dependent glucose transporter. It is mostly found in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. The more Mr.Wilson exercises, the more GLUT-4 he may develop because his muscles will begin to need more glucose.  Therefore, he may be likely to develop type 2 diabetes as glucose is more effectively absorbed.

Question: Taylor is confused about pressure in the heart. He observes a slight increase in pressure in the aorta after the semilunar valves close. What is this dip and increase called?
Explanation:
B. Dicrotic Notch. 

This increase in pressure is caused by the aorta recoiling ( due to its compliance ) and closure of the semilunar value blocking the back flow of blood. However preventing the 'back flowing' of blood causes it to rebound into the aorta colliding with the walls increasing the pressure slightly.

 

https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/circulatory-system/pressure-volume-loops/v/pressure-in-the-left-heart-part-2

minute 9:50

Question: Mrs Williams attends an appointment with her GP and is told she needs an ECG. Her ECG comes back as normal . In what part of the cardiac cycle is the p wave generated?
Explanation:
The answer is d as The p wave is generated as atria depolarise prior to contraction.

Not A as ventricular depolarisation is the QRS complex

Not B as ventricular repolarisation is the t wave 

Not c as Atrial repolarisation  the QRS wave as occurs when ventricles depolarise

Not e the p wave occurs prior to atria contraction.  

PCS unit 2 week 9 the cardiac cycle. Learning outcome: explain electrical and mechanical events of the cardiac cycle.

Question: A patient presents at A&E unable to abduct their arm above the horizontal position. They also have a winged scapula. Which muscle has been paralysed in order to cause these symptoms?
Explanation: "When the serratus anterior is paralyzed because of injury to the long thoracic nerve, the medial border of the scapula moves laterally and posteriorly away from the thoracic wall. This gives the scapula the appearance of a wing. When the arm is raised, the medial border and inferior angle of the scapula pull away from the thoracic wall. This is known as winged scapula. The arm cannot be abducted above the horizontal position because the serratus anterior is unable to rotate the glenoid cavity superiorly to allow complete abduction of the limb." - Clinical Box page 114 Moore's Clinical Anatomy 6th Edition
Tags: Nerve damage, Upper Limb Anatomy, Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Clinical

Question: Gareth has been doing hobbies which include repeated bending of the wrist. As a result he experiences a tingling pain in his fingers, wrist and arm. He decides to see his GP who suspects he has Carpel Tunnel Syndrome. Assuming the GP is correct, what nerve has been compressed?
Explanation:
B. Median nerve innovates the thumb, index and middle fingers along with the superficial flexors of the forearm ( minus the flexor carpi ulnaris ) resulting in the tingling pain of the arm and fingers. 

E. This is the roof of the carpal tunnel and not the answer therefore.

Question:
Michael Jackson is having a dose of Propofol injected into the vein. the usual concentration is 10 mg/ml before the surgery and is injected at a rate of 4ml per 10 seconds for 2 minutes. The doctor gave 22mg/ml of Propofol and injected at a rate of 0.5ml a second for 2 minutes and 30 seconds before the surgery instead.

By how much was Michael Jackson overdosed by as a percentage increase?
Explanation:
1) 10 mg/ml times my 4 ml to find out how many mg of Propofol in 4 ml = 40

2) 2 minutes = 120 seconds. 120/10 as its every 10 seconds = 12

3) 40 x 12 = 480 mg for normal dose.

4) then work out dose given 22 mg/ml times by 0.5 = 11

5) 2 minutes and 30 seconds = 150 seconds. 

6) 11 x 150 = 1650 mg for given dose 

7) percentage change = (given - normal)/normal x 100.  (1650 - 480)/480 x 100 = 243.75 %

Question: A F1 doctor on a ward is trying to figure out which nerve may be damaged from a broken humerus, however, he forgets the rough positioning of the how the nerves run alongside the humerus. Which of the following best describes the positioning of the radial, median and ulnar nerve along the humerus bone?
OptionA:
The radial nerve runs mostly anteriorly, but runs posteriorly down the radial groove of the humerus.

Median runs anteriorly.

Ulnar runs anteriorly until it passes under the ulnar groove on the medial epicondyle.
OptionB:
Ulnar runs anteriorly until it passes under the ulnar groove on the medial epicondyle.
Radial runs completely posteriorly.

Median runs anteriorly.
OptionD:
Radial runs anteriorly

Median and Ulnar run posteriorly.
OptionE:
Radial runs posteriorly along the radial groove, but mostly anteriorly.

Median runs anteriorly.

Ulnar runs anteriorly, but passes under the ulnar groove at the lateral epicondyle.
Explanation:
Radial runs mostly anteriorly, but runs under the radial groove.

Median runs anteriorly.

Ulnar runs anteriorly, but passes under the ulnar groove at the medial epicondyle.

Question: Winged scapula is a condition caused by the damage of the serratus anterior muscle which is innervate by what nerve?
Explanation: The long thoracic nerve innervates the serrates anterior muscle, which has the function of pulling the scapula forward around the thorax. Damage to the axillary nerve means that serrates anterior can no longer hold the scapula against the ribcage hence the 'winged' appearance:
Tags: Upper Limb Anatomy, Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Nerve damage

Question: You are an F1 Doctor and a patient is interested in knowing how her medication works. (Dihydropyridine) Calcium channel blockers such as Amlodipine are often used to control blood pressure. Using your knowledge of Calcium channels what effect is this likely to have:
OptionA: Stabilises Blood Pressure to reduce changes throughout the day
Explanation: Calcium channel blockers are used very commonly to control hypertension (high blood pressure). Therefore they DECREASE BLOOD PRESSURE. They function by blocking Calcium channels hence allowing less Calcium to enter the cells and therefore decrease the force of contraction.
Tags: Membrane transport, Cardiac cycle, Vital signs, Muscle Contraction

Question: What three factors give rise to the electrochemical gradient?
OptionA: the electical gradient; the size of the molecule/ion; the equilibrium potential of the ion
OptionB: the concentration gradient; the charge of the molecule/ion; the membrane potential
OptionC: the size of the molecule/ion; the charge of the molecule/ion; the membrane potential
OptionD: the concentration gradient; the equilibrium potential ; the membrane potential
OptionE: the membrane potential; the concentration gradient; the size of the molecule/ion
Explanation: The size of the molecule/ion does not give rise to the electrochemical gradient; nor does the equilibrium potential of the ion/molecule

Question: Grace is cutting up an avocado ready to mush and eat with her carrot sticks. Unfortunately she cuts her wrist in the process resulting in damage to one of her nerves. She tried to form a fist but instead only forms the position shown... What nerve has been damaged ?
Explanation:
Median nerve.The image shows 'sign of benediction' which despite looking like claw hand ( ulnar nerve damage ) is actually not. It occurs and the index and middle fingers cannot flex due to damage of the median nerve which innovates them which means only the Ulnar nerve can be used which flexes the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus to bend the 4th and 5th finger. Once the hand is relaxed Ape hand will occur. 

 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0AAligXLJ1A

Question: Will has been downing to many VKs at quidz in and ends up losing a tooth. He wanders what joint the tooth has left from. What joint is it ?
Explanation: Fibrous joints are found in gomphoses of teeth, are strong, hard to move and mostly contain collagen.

Question: The pleura is important as it covers the inner surface of the thoracic cavity and contains many different vital organs. During a viva in the anatomy centre, a medical student is asked by one of there teachers to define the anterior borders of the pleura. However, he has forgot due to not revising the pleura due to a heavy night out. You decide to help, What are the anterior borders of the pleura?
OptionA: Apex 3cm above the clavicle, both sides come in together into the 2nd costal cartilage. Left side out at 4th costal cartilage. Right side out at 6th costal cartilage. most bottom part of pleura at most lateral point of the 8th rib.
OptionB: Apex 2 cm above clavicle, both sides come together into 3rd costal cartilage, left and right out at 4th costal cartilage and most bottom part of pleura at the most lateral part of 8th rib.
OptionD: Apex at 3cm above clavicle, both sides in to the body of sternum and the most lateral part of the pleura is at the 9th rib.
OptionE: apex 3cm above clavicle, both sides down to 2nd costal cartilage. Right side out at 4th costal cartilage, left side out at 6th costal cartilage. Bottom part at the most lateral part of 8th rib.
Explanation:
a good way to remember this is by using the acronym A 2 4 6 8 (10 12)

anterior borders 

a- apex 3 cm above clavicle 

2- both sides come in at 2nd costal cartilage towards midline

4- left side goes out

6-right side goes out 

8- both lie on my lateral part of 8th rib (down mid clavicular line)

 

Lateral border 

10-goes down to 10th rib (down mid axillary Line)

 

posterior border

12-goes to 12th rib (down mid scapular line)

Question: You see someone you like and want to impress them. You think you can impress them by telling them the carpel bones in their hand. You decide to check you know their names and positions in relation to each other before you approach. Consider your hand in the anatomical position. Starting from the proximal carpels, and the lateral side of your palm, what are your 8 carpel bones in order? (After you have done the proximal 4, go lateral again and label the distal ones)
OptionA: Scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, pisiform, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate
OptionB: Hamate, capitate, scaphoid, trapezium, trapezoid, lunate, pisiform, triquetrum
OptionD: Hamate, triquetrum, lunate, scaphoid, pisiform, capitate, trapezium, trapezoid
OptionE: Trapezium, trapezoid, triquetrum, pisiform, hamate, scaphoid, lunate, capitate

Question: Pyruvate dehydrogenase is used as an enzyme in the link reaction, it has a lot of coenzymes and inhibition of these stop the enzyme working. Which of these inhbitions are correct?
OptionA: CoA is inhibited by amytal and malonate prevents Lipoic acid binding to pyruvate dehydrogenase.
OptionB: TPP is inhibited by cyanide poisoning and arsenate prevents FAD binding to pyruvate dehydrogenase.
OptionC: TPP is inhibited by mercury poisoning and arsenate prevents Lipoic acid binding to pyruvate dehydrogenase.
OptionD: FAD is inhibited by mercury poisoning and arsenate prevents TPP binding to pyruvate dehydrogenase.
OptionE: TPP is inhibited by cyanide poisoning and malonate prevents Lipoic acid binding to pyruvate dehydrogenase.

Question: Pyruvate dehydrogenase is an enzyme in the link reaction, it is part of a key regulatory step, what products inhibit it and how?
OptionA: NADH allosterically inhibits PDH and CO2 competitively inhibits PDH, when levels of these are high then the enzyme switches off
OptionB: Acetyl CoA allosterically inhibits PDH and ATP competitively inhibits PDH, when levels of these are high then the enzyme switches off
OptionC: NADH and Acetyl CoA allosterically inhibits PDH, when levels of these are high then the enzyme switches off.
OptionD: CO2 allosterically inhibits PDH and NADH competitively inhibits PDH, when levels of these are high then the enzyme switches off
OptionE: NADH allosterically inhibits PDH and FAD competitively inhibits PDH, when levels of these are high then the enzyme switches off

Question: There are two shuttles for allowing NADH produced from glycolysis to enter the mitochondrial matrix. One is the glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle, which allows movement by the use of the enzyme glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase in the cytosol. NADH gets oxidised by G3P dehydrogenase, this reduces dihydroxyacetone to glycerol-3-phosphate, which in turn moves into the matrix. In the matrix, G3P gets oxidised to dihydroxyacetone by mitochondrial G3P dehydrogenase, reducing ubiquinone to ubiquinol. The ubiquinol then gets oxidised, reducing FAD+ to FADH2. Why might this be considered a ’less efficient‘ mode of transport in comparison to the Malate-aspartate transporter?
OptionA: Because the process of movement requires more ATP.
OptionC: Because the this mode produces FADH which produces more ATP.
OptionD: Because in the malate-aspartate transporter, NADH gets produced which produces more ATP in the electron transport chain.

Question: What nerve innervates Brachioradialis
Explanation:
The radial nerve supplies the brachioradialis muscle which is in the posterior compartment of the forearm.

 

Useful to remember - the similarly-named brachialis muscle (therefore easy to confuse) in the anterior compartment of the upper arm is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve which is a different branch of the brachial plexus.
Tags: Anatomy, Upper Limb Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb

Question: Which rotator cuff muscle does not insert on the greater tuberosity of the humerus?
Explanation:
Subscapularis inserts onto the lesser tubercle of the humerus. However the rest of the rotor cuff muscles insert on the greater tubercle of the humerus.

Here's a brief diagram of subscapularis:

Question: A patient has fractured the surgical neck of their humerus by falling on an outstretched hand (FOOSH). Which nerve faces the most risk of being damaged?
Explanation:
The surgical neck of the humerus is a frequent site of fracture – usually by a direct blow to the area, or falling on an outstretched hand.

The key neurovascular structures at risk here are the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex artery.

Axillary nerve damage will result in paralysis to the deltoid and teres minor muscles. The patient will have difficulty performing abduction of the affected limb. The nerve also innervates the skin over the lower deltoid (regimental badge area), and therefore sensation in this region may be impaired.

(Information via Teach Me Anatomy)
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Nerve damage

Question: A patient has fracture the shaft of their humerus. Which nerve faces the most risk of being damaged?
Explanation:
The radial nerve runs through the radial groove - a shallow depression running diagonally down the posterior surface of the humerus.

The radial nerve runs close to the bone on the shaft of the humerus, therefore is under risk of damage, as seen in the picture below:

Question: Subscapularis is a rotator cuff muscle that originates from the scapula. What part of the scapula is the origin of subscapularis?
Explanation:
Subscapularis originates from the subscapular fossa, which is a large concave depression over most of the scapulars costal surface.

Below is a brief diagram:

Question: Jessica Ennis-Hill has been training her endurance fitness by running at higher altitudes. As a result, what has happened to her MUSCLE cells to help with cardiovascular endurance?
OptionB: Her cells have swollen and she looks Jacked
OptionC: There is more Haemoglobin in the blood.
OptionE: The cell membranes are more permeable to oxygen.
Explanation:
A. Myoglobin increases. Its function is to transport O2 to mitochondria within cells so increasing levels increases cardiovascular efficiency. When myoglobin is present in urine in high concentrations it is a sign of skeletal or cardiac muscle injury and turns the urine a dark red brown colour.

C. is wrong as it is not intracellular (not MUSCLE cells)

E. wrong as cell membranes allow small non polar molecules through.

Question: Sahajpal goes to the cash and carry. She falls and damages her nerves, she cannot move her anterior arm muscles. What nerve is damaged?
Which of the following is NOT an example of a Pyrimidine molecule?
Explanation: Adenine is an example of a Purine molecule.

Question: What is the recommended energy requirement (from the NHS) per day for the average male?
Explanation:
C is the correct answer

 

A is the recommended energy requirement (from the NHS) per day for the average female

B is too small a value for an average male

C is the correct answer

D is the recommended energy requirement (from the NHS) per day for the average female in KJ

E is too small a value for an average male 

 

(2500 kcal converts to 10,500KJ)

Question: which one of these is not a rotator cuff muscle?
Explanation: Teres major is a small muscle that runs along the lateral border of the scapula and is not a rotator cuff muscle?
Tags: Anatomy, Upper Limb Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb

Question: Which one of these muscles is not entirely innervated by the median nerve?
Explanation: Lateral part of flexor digitorum profundus is supplied by the median nerve and the medial part is supplied by the ulnar nerve.

Question: Usain Bolt is preparing to run a marathon. He is used to sprinting and is therefore unaware of the mechanisms underlying long distance running. He asks his coach what type of energy producing process will his body be undergoing from hour 3 of the race onwards.
Explanation:
0-10s - ATP and creatine phosphate system

10-60s - anaerobic glycolysis 

1min - 3 hours - aerobic glycolysis

3hours onward - aerobic lipolysis

Question: Manisha falls down and shatters some bones in her wrist. how many bones are in the wrist?
Explanation: There are 8 bones: the lunate, hamate, scaphoid, pisiform, triquetrum, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate
Tags: Anatomy, Upper Limb Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb

Question: Sophie had an unfortunate accident with a car and squirrel; in A&E, the doctor noticed she was missing some ribs on her x-ray. How many ribs should she have?
Explanation: 12 on each side therefore in total there are 24

Question: Lava, the hard-working student, wants to know the codon for the initiation code.  What is the correct answer?
Explanation: AUG is the correct combination and order of nucleotides for the initiation code

Question: Gareth Bale has injured himself playing golf and now has a "Golfer's Elbow". Which part of his humerus has Bale injured?
Explanation: Golfer's elbow (medial epicondylitis) is a condition that causes pain where the tendons of your forearm muscles attach to the bony bump on the inside of your elbow - the medial epicondyle.
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Humerus anatomy

Question: Which ribs are atypical?
Explanation: Rib 1 is short and more curved and only has 1 facet on its head. Rib 2 has a rough edge for attachment of serratus anterior. Rib 10 only has 1 facet. Ribs 11 and 12 have no neck and only have 1 facet.

Question: Mr. Rai falls onto an outstretched hand whilst at the gym training really hard and suffers a surgical neck fracture of the humerus. This leads to paralysis to the deltoid and teres minor muscles. What nerve is damaged that causes this paralysis?
Explanation:
Axillary nerve damage will result in paralysis to the deltoid and teres minor muscles. The patient will have difficulty performing abduction of the affected limb.

Nerve also innervates the skin over the lower deltoid, and therefore sensation in this region may be impaired
Tags: Nerve damage, Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Upper Limb Anatomy, Muscle Contraction

Question: Which one of these is not part of the superior medistinum ?
Explanation: The diaphragm borders the inferior mediastinum
Tags: Cardiac cycle, Thorax, Anatomy, Heart Rate, Muscle Contraction

Question: Which nerve innervates the diaphragm?
Explanation:
-The vagus nerve innervates the majority of the muscles associated with the pharynx and larynx.

-As part of the “fight-versus-flight” response, the sympathetic nerves innervate the heart, blood vessels, bronchi, and GI tract.

-The femoral nerve and obturator nerve are present in the abdomen, not the thorax

-The phrenic nerve is the correct answer

Question:
Sean Morrison was playing football in the park on a sunny day, he falls over the ball and experiences a particularly bad FOOSH. He has a 'dinner fork' deformity.

 

What bone has been fractured?

✋🏿⚽️🏥
Explanation: dinner fork deformity is when the hand is posteriorly displaced due to a fracture In the distal radius 👌🏿
Tags: Upper Limb Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb

Question: Eileen has came across a patient who has passed her a dressing soiled with blood. How should she appropriately  dispose of this?
Explanation: As it has blood it must be put in a Orange bag as there is a chance it may be infectious .

Question: GLUTs are Glucose Transporters involved in facilitated diffusion of glucose across the cell membrane. Which of the following is most likely to transport fructose?
Explanation:
GLUT 1 is present in all cells and higher levels are detected when glucose levels are low.

GLUT 2 transports glucose in the liver and pancreatic B cells

GLUT 3 is expressed in the brain and is responsible for glucose uptake in neurones.

GLUT 4 is mainly present in muscle and adipose tissue. 

GLUT 5 is a fructose transporter.

Question: Manisha is revising for her exams and learning about the joints in her hand. She is flexing her knuckles and realizes that these are synovial joints. But she wonders what type of synovial joints they are since there are a few types of them.
Explanation: The answer is Condyloid because it is a metacarpophalangeal joint. The condyloid joint permits a variety of movements in different planes but DOES NOT allow rotation.
Tags: Joints, Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb

Question: In pacemaker cells, the increase in permeability to which ion is responsible for the upstroke in action potential?
Explanation: In pacemaker cells the upstroke in action potential is due to an increase in permeability to calcium. In cardiac myocytes in the atria and ventricles, it is due to an increase in permeability to sodium.

Question: A 58 year old female is diagnosed with Carpal Tunnel Syndrome. The patient would like to know which nerve is compressed - which nerve is it?
Which of following muscles abducts the humerus at the shoulder?
Explanation: Deltoid and supraspinatus abduct the humerus at the shoulder

Question: Dave has a paralysed diaphragm. Which nerve has he damaged?
Explanation: Phrenic nerve is the only nerve that supplies motor function to the diaphragm

Question: Seb has a very bad habit of going to fattoush every Wednesday after the rugby social, he has now developed cholesterol problems that have led to a coronary artery disease. As a result Seb needed a heart transplant. In heart transplants the vagus nerve is cut. How is Seb's heart rate affected after surgery?
Explanation: vagus nerve innervates parasympathetic, as vagus nerve is cut sympathetic is stimulated at rest. Parasympathetic cannot maintain the lower resting heart rate of 60bpm. Therefore it will be higher at rest.
Tags: Thorax, Anatomy, Heart Rate, Nerve damage

Question: Lalaz was thrown in the air for cheer and has had a FOOSH (fall on out stretched hand). She has pains and swelling around the wrist. What is the likely fracture?
Explanation: A FOOSH injury commonly affects the scaphoid because it's the main connection between your hand and forearm. When you fall on your hand, all of the energy produced when your hand hits the ground travels to your forearm through the scaphoid.
Tags: Carpel bones, Anatomy of upper limb

Question: Logic has haemophilia A; a disorder associated with poor blood clotting, which can result in a subcutaneous haematoma and joint bleeds. Which clotting factor does he have a problem with?
Explanation: Haemophilia A includes a problem with clotting factor VIII, part of the intrinsic pathway

Question: What is not a content of the cubital fossa?
Explanation: It just isn't. Science.

Question: What is the largest muscle of the rotator cuff?
Explanation: Subscapularis is anteriorly positioned, and the largest of the four. The deltoid is not part of the rotator cuff muscles.
Tags: Humerus anatomy, Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Upper Limb Anatomy

Question: An 89 year old man called Morgan Freeman has come into A&E with chest pains. An ECG is recorded. What does the T wave of an ECG correspond to?
Explanation: The t wave shows ventricular repolarisation

Question: A patient is tested for a problem with clotting formation. It is found that there is an issue with the intrinsic pathway of the clotting cascade. Which of the following factors is involved?
Explanation: Factor XII is converted to activated factor XIIa which acts on plasma protein prekallikrein to release kallikrein. Whilst both XII and XIIa are options, XIIa is the best answer because it is the active form

Question:
Joe has told everyone he has dislocated his shoulder joint. He has in fact dislocated his glenohumeral joint.

Which bones make up the glenohumeral joint?
Explanation:
A - These are involved in the elbow joint. Ulna is a part of the forearm not the arm.

B - These are involved in the acromioclavicular joint

C - These are a part of the forearm not the arm

D - These are a part of the glenohumeral joint.

E - Hamate is a bone in the hand.
Tags: Humerus anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Upper Limb Anatomy

Question: Where do bisoprolol work?
Explanation: Bisoprolol is a non-selective receptor

Question: You have come across a member of the public on your way back to Talybont Halls collapsed on the ground by Tesco Express. They are unresponsive, not breathing and show no signs of life. Which of the following is a cause of Cardiac Arrest?
Explanation:
Whilst stress, intoxication and over-exertion may contribute towards an increased risk of Cardiac arrest, the clinical cause is hypovolaemia (low blood volume). Hypochondria is when someone is excessively worried about their health.

Tip: Remember the 4 Ts and the 4 Hs

Question: Ali, Male and age 21, was at a legs, bums and tums class. He measured his VO2max and found it to be ‘fair’. For his age, what is the range of values that his VO2max would fall into?
Explanation:
VO2max (maximal oxygen consumption) is the maximal amount of oxygen an individual‘s body can transport and utilise during incremental exercise. It is widely accepted the single best measure of cardiovascular fitness and maximal aerobic power.

 

In men of age 20-24:

Very poor: <32

Poor: 32-37

Fair: 38-43

Average: 44-50

Good: 51-56

Very good: 57-62

Excellent: >62

 (all values in ml/kg/min)

 

To find out more about VO2max, refer to Practical handbook from ‘energy during exercise’ practical.

Question:
A 10 year old boy called Justin Bieber has come into A&E after a FOOSH and has localised pain in the radial side of his hand.

You suspect it is a scaphoid fracture, failure to re-vascularise will result immediately in?
OptionC: Loss of blood supply to the hand
Explanation: Scaphoid has a unique blood supply, therefore fracture can disrupt blood supply to proximal portion. Failure to revascularise quickly can result in avascular necrosis and long-term osteoarthritis.
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Upper Limb Anatomy, Clinical relevance of anatomy

Question:
Mr Richardson has taken amytal. 

Amytal is a barbiturate drug used as a sedative and a hypnotic

What complex in the electron transport chain has been inhibited?
Explanation: Amytal inhibits complex 1. However, complexes 2 through to 5 still work

Question:
Jenny likes to go to the gym a lot and is a keen body-builder. After one of her upper arm sessions she was curious to know what is the action of her tricep muscle? 

 

What is the action of triceps brachii? - help Jenny out!
Explanation:
https://teachmeanatomy.info/upper-limb/muscles/upper-arm/ 

 

Refer to this link for more info

Question: David suffers from anxiety which is cause by low GABA levels. GABA is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. To which ion does the membrane become more permeable to when GABA is released from neurons?
Explanation: ipsp causes the cell to become hyperpolarized, making it harder for AP to occur. This is achieved by making the cell more negatively charged as Chloride ion channels open, making the membrane more permeable to chloride.

Question: A first year medical student did PCS unit 1 quiz and didn’t know anything about joints, so what joint has the most movement?
Explanation: Synovial joints are freely movable, the joint contains synovial fluid which reduces friction

Question: Which muscle is located in the anterior forearm?
Explanation: Anconeus, abductor pollicis longus, brachioradialis, and extensor indicis are located on the posterior side

Question: Which of the following muscles serve as the anatomical landmark for the median nerve in the forearm?
Explanation: The median nerve runs along the posterior of palmaris longus muscle. Hence, it can be used as the anatomical landmark to find the median nerve.

Question: A patient presents with a possible first degree heart block. An ECG has been taken. What sign on their ECG would indicate first degree heart block?
Explanation: The prolonged PR interval is due to prolonged conduction from the atria to the ventricles. A prolonged PR interval is longer than 0.2 seconds. The PR interval represents the time from the onset of atrial depolarisation due to sinus node activation to the onset of ventricular repolarisation.

Question: What nerve supplies the flexors in the anterior compartment of the arm?
Explanation: Musculocutaneous nerve innervates the biceps brachii, corcacobrachialis and brachialis.

Question:
The following reaction is catalysed by an enzyme. The enzyme is upregulated by Fructose-2,6-Bisphosphate. It is down regulated by pH.

 

Fructose-6-Ph -> Fru-1,6,BisPh

 

What is the name of the enzyme?
Explanation:
Releasing Food from Energy without Oxygen:

 

e) Outline glycolysis, including the substrates and products, the phosphorylation of glucose and the production of triose phosphate (pyruvate).

 

Phosphoryl group transfer reaction. Uses ATP to add a phosphate group. Important regulatory step in Glycolysis. Enzyme is unregulated by AMP, ADP and Fru-2,6-Bisphosphate. Downregulated by ATP and low pH from lactate.

Question: Fenny was at a heavy quids in with "Twist and Pulse" when he tried to pop and lock and damaged the subscapularis rotator cuff muscle. But where does this muscle insert?
Explanation: The subscapularis muscle is the only rotator cuff muscle that does not insert on the greater tubercle, it inserts on the lesser tubercle.
Tags: Humerus anatomy, Anatomy, Joints, Anatomy of upper limb

Question:
Following a chest x-ray it is found that Charles has pericardial effusion.

What area does the build up of fluid occur in?
Explanation:
As the pericardial cavity is a space that can fill up with fluid.

However the fibrous, parietal, visceral pericardium are actual tissue that surrounds the heart or form the sac surrounding the heart they cannot fill up with fluid.

The pulmonary pleura surrounds the lungs and not the heart surrounds the lungs so is n

Question:
Gareth is a keen Medical Student who likes to ask lots of questions. When abducting his shoulder to put his hand up to ask a question he wonders, 

What muscle fibres are mainly responsible for the abduction of the shoulder joint?
Explanation: middle fibres of the Deltoid are mainly responsible for abduction of the shoulder throughout the movement

Question: Mrs Davies' youngest son has been diagnosed with Cystic Fibrosis. The doctor explains to her that is the result of a mutation in the Cystic Fibrosis Trans-membrane Regulator due to a mutated gene on chromosome 7. This results in the production of a defective transporter to transport chloride ions out of the cell to draw water into the mucus. What type of transporter is the now defective transporter?
Explanation:
The defective transporter is an ABC Transporter which usually does not reach the plasma membrane. Chloride ions cannot be transported out of the cell into the mucus so the water potential of the mucus is not lowered so water is not drawn into the mucus. This results in thick, viscous mucus in the patient. 

 

See: ABC Transporter Slide on Membrane Transport Plenary

Question: After watching his favourite film "From Dusk til Dawn" Jeff gets excited thinking about the myogenic properties of the heart. He thinks about which part of the heart initiates the action potential that causes the heart to contract. Which part is it?
Explanation: The sino - atrial node is what initiates the action potential that will cause the heart to contract.

Question: A doctor wants to listen to a patients heart but first they must identify the position of the sternal angle, which pair of Ribs are closely aligned with the Sternal angle?
Explanation:
The sternal angle is found in close approximation with the 2nd rib pair 

See slide 8 on the thorax session 11 powerpoint

Question:
Mrs Smith has been diagnosed with pericardial effusion. This is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial cavity. 

Between which two layers is the pericardial cavity located?
Explanation: The pericardial cavity is located between the parietal pericardium and visceral pericardium. Pericardial effusion can lead to an increase in pressure within the heart resulting in decreased cardiac output.

Question: A patient presents with Carpal Tunnel Syndrome with clinical features including numbness, tingling and pain that radiates to the forearm. What within the carpal tunnel has been compressed to cause this?
Explanation: Median nerve runs through the carpal tunnel and tapping the median nerve will elicit pain with someone who has carpal tunnel syndrome.

Question: You are in a consultation with a patient and are going to ask them questions. What does the 'I' in ICEE mean?
Explanation: B-Ideas beliefs regarding the cause- Please see the Calgary Cambridge guide to the medical interview- communication process

Question: Bill has paralysed his diaphragm. Which nerve may have been damaged?
Explanation: The phrenic nerve supplies the diaphragm

Question: Bob is doing a dissection of the chest. Which structure is found in the posterior mediastinum?
Explanation: Brachiocephalic veins, the superior vena cava, thymus and trachea are found in the superior mediastinum.

Question:
Kathryn has visited her GP because of a tingling sensation and numbness/pain in her left hand. Her GP suspects carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by the compression of what nerve?
Explanation:
A. Median Nerve.

The median nerve goes down the arm and forearm, passes through the carpal tunnel at the wrist, and goes into the hand. The nerve provides feeling in the thumb and index, middle, and ring fingers. Carpal tunnel syndrome occurs when the median nerve is squeezed or compressed as it travels through the wrist.

Question: Worst Viva Ever: Iestyn has been overly stressed about his involvement in 'the worst viva ever' and this resulted in a high blood pressure. High blood pressure can be a cause of Carpal Tunnel syndrome. What is carpal tunnel syndrome?
OptionC: A leisure in the flexor digitorum superficialis
OptionE: Involuntary contractions of flexors of the wrist

Question: A student is missing a page in their textbook which states the innervation of the serratus anterior muscle. Which nerve innervates serratus anterior?
Explanation: The long thoracic nerve innervates serratus anterior.

Question: Following a clinical examination, it is suspected that a patient is suffering with damage to one of their posterior axio-appendicular muscles. Which of the following muscles is not a posterior axio-appendicular muscle?
Explanation: Deltoid is a scapulohumeral muscle.

Question: A patient is thought to have nerve damage to the nerves that supply the skin over the clavicle and superolateral aspect of pectoralis major. Which nerves are these?

Ms.Godoi is a nice lady who fell when dancing on top of the table at Christmas Ball. The patient has been complaining of swelling in her shoulder area. The doctor examines the patient and concludes that a joint located on her upper limb was compromised. This joint allows gliding and is uniaxial. Which type joint has been compromised and where in the upper limb could it be located?
Explanation:
Option B would be correct because the plane joints permit gliding and sliding movements and the acromioclavicular joint is located in the upper limb near the area of swelling the patient has complained about. 

 

  • Option A would be incorrect because the saddle joint is biaxial and the elbow joint is not a saddle type of joint
  • Option C would be incorrect because the swelling that the patient has complained about is located next to her shoulder
  • Option D would be incorrect because the ball and socket joint is biaxial
  • Option E would be incorrect because the condyloid joint is biaxial and the glenohumeral joint is not a condyloid type of joint

Question: Mr. ABC attends A&E presenting with pain in his left arm, shortness of breath and chest pain. The doctors suspect a myocardial infarction and want to confirm their theory by looking for the presence of a particular protein in the blood which indicates damage to cardiac muscle. What is the main protein indicating this?
Explanation: Recall in the micro-anatomy of muscle practical, creatine kinase would have been a good guess but it is also found in too many other muscles to reason that it is present in the blood due to a cardiac muscle injury specifically.

Question: During placement, the consultant asks the medical student which leads represent the lateral view of the heart. The medical student answers correctly, so what does he/she say?
OptionA: lead I, lead II, V3, V5, aVr
Explanation: Image taken from cardiovascular teaching session hosted by cardiovascular society

Question: A patient who has been diagnosed with pericarditis is also experiencing shoulder pain. One of the nerves supplying the pericardium also have sensory fibres supplying dermatomes in the shoulder region, causing referred pain. What nerve is causing this ?
Explanation:
Although the sympathetic trunk and vagus nerve also supply the pericardium, the phrenic nerve (C3-C5) has branches which supply dermatomes of the shoulder region. 

 

Information gathered from Moore's Anatomy under Pericardium

Question: A male child has difficulty walking, running and standing up. As they get older, their mobility further decreases and so does respiratory function. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Muscular dystrophy is due to the absence of the dystrophin protein which is essential for supporting muscles and their related functions.

 

review microanatomy of muscle practical

Question: This nerve has a solely sensory function in the hand, that is, it does not innervate hand muscles. Providing this sensory innervation to the dorsal aspect of the hand from the first 3 digits to the lateral aspect of the 4th digit, what nerve is this?

Question: Which of the following statements is correct?
OptionA:
Vein compliance> Artery compliance

Vein elastance > Artery elastance
OptionB:
Artery compliance> Vein compliance

Vein elastance > Artery elastance
OptionC:
Vein compliance> Artery compliance

Artery elastance > Vein elastance
OptionD:
Artery compliance> Vein compliance

Artery elastance> Vein elastance
OptionE:
Artery compliance= Vein compliance

Artery elastance= Vein elastance
Explanation: Veins will expand to a greater extent upon increased pressure than arteries therefore have a greater compliance (compliance= volume/pressure). Elastance is the inverse of compliance and therefore arteries have a greater elastance than veins.

Question: Which of the following best describes the function of peroxisomes?
Explanation:
A is correct

B is a very vague answer- although peroxisomes do start the synthesis of the main phospholipid of the myelin sheath.

C is incorrect. Peroxisomes remove free radicals

D is a function of the smooth ER and the mitochondria

E is a function of the Golgi apparatus

Question: Which connective tissue is found in aponeuroses?
Mr Rees has hurt his knee during a rugby game and the doctor believes it involves a cartilage tear. Which type of cartilage is found within the meniscus of the knee joint?
Explanation: fibrocartilage is a blend of hyaline cartilage and dense connective tissue and because it is compressional it can resist tension well and hence is found where strong support and ability to withstand heavy pressure is required as in the knee joint. The thick bundles of collagen will have a parallel arrangement and contain fibrorocytes.

Question: Dracula tears the heart out of Mariam. Her heart continues to beat. What is this due to?
Explanation:
Chordae tendinae stop the valves going inside out and are held to the ventricle walls by papillary muscles.

The pacemaker cells are autorhythmic as they follow a repetitive pattern of Na+ channels opening followed by Ca2+ leading to faster depolarisation followed by K+ voltage gated channels opening repolarising the membrane

Question: Mr Evans has been diagnosed with Marfan syndrome in his twenties and is reviewed by his consultant cardiologist. Mr Evans asks how this condition is inherited. How would you reply?
Explanation: The terms autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive are used to describe gene variants on non-sex chromosomes (autosomes) and their associated traits, while those on sex chromosomes (allosomes) are termed X-linked dominant, X-linked recessive or Y-linked, and these show a very different inheritance and presentation pattern to autosomal traits which depends on the sex of the individual (see Sex linkage). Marfan syndrome is known to be autosomal dominant condition affecting connective tissue. The most serious complications of this condition involve the heart and aorta, with an increased risk of mitral valve prolapse and aortic aneurysm.

Question: Joe decides to attend the Medics' Football social event on a Wednesday night, where the theme is a talent show. He is told before hand that he must perform a rendition of Stavros Flatley's BGT audition. Joe is very nervous before his performance, but once he consumes a few Snakey-Bs he gets very passionate in the dance. His river dance is simply flawless. For this moment and this moment alone, Joe is Stavros Flatley. Every step, reel, slip jig and hornpipe resemble the original audition to a tee. Joe decides to end his routine with a classic dance move, 'the lawnmower' which involves a sharp movement of the shoulder, as shown below. As he's about to end his performance, he wonders: 'Which anatomical term best describes this movement of the right shoulder girdle?"
Explanation:
The action of shrugging the shoulders is an example of elevation of the shoulder girdle. The muscles involved in elevating the shoulder girdle are the upper fibers of trapezius, levator scapulae, rhomboid major and rhomboid minor.

 

The judges scored Joe a 10 for his performance, obviously.
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Joints, Upper Limb Anatomy

Question:
Iestyn has a heavy night out and inevitably ends up in his favourite fast food restaurant, Fattoush. He slips on some of Fattoush's garlic sauce (good stuff) and falls forward on an outstretched hand, somewhat resembling Bambi on ice. He crawls into his local GP practise 2 days later with a painful swelling on the side of his thumb, and a filthy hangover.

 

Which carpal is most likely to be fractured from his Fattoush FOOSH?
Explanation:
A scaphoid fracture is a break in one of the eight small bones that make up the wrist. It’s one of the most common FOOSH injuries. The main symptom is pain, with or without swelling or bruising, on the side of your thumb. You’ll notice this pain within a few days of your fall.

The injury is sometimes believed to be a sprain or strain because it does not usually cause a physical deformity. But putting off treatment for a scaphoid fracture may lead to future complications caused by incorrect healing.

Complications may include poor blood flow into your bones, bone loss, and arthritis. If you feel pain on the thumb-side of your wrist following a fall, see a doctor.

Treatment depends on its severity. Less severe fractures may be treated by putting your hand and wrist in a cast, while severe fractures require surgery to mend the broken scaphoid bone together.
Tags: Carpel bones, Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Upper Limb Anatomy, Fattoush

Question: Tommy after a late night was trekking back to his flat after the heavy night of praying. On route back to his flat ( that is over an hour away) he is followed by 3 men as he passes Fattoush. As Tommy went around the corner the men proceeded to put masks on and chase him down an alley. Tommy briskly fell like a leaf in the sharp winds of Cardiff. Trapped, lost, alone, Tommy felt optionless the men pulled out mallets and said YOU AREN'T GOING ANYWHERE unless you can help me with quiz. It was at this point Tommy realised he was STILL wearing his lanyard. the men asked " what are the functions of the deltoid?"
OptionA:
Anterior: flexion and internal rotation of the arm
Middle: abduction of the arm
Posterior: extension and external rotation of the arm

At the Elbow joint
OptionB:
Anterior: circumduction in sagittal plate
Middle: abduction of the arm
Posterior: circumduction in sagittal plate

At the glenohumeral joint
OptionC:
Anterior: elevation and internal rotation of the arm
Middle: adduction of the arm
Posterior: extension and external rotation of the arm

At the glenohumeral joint
OptionD:
Anterior: flexion and external rotation of the arm
Middle: abduction of the arm
Posterior: internal rotation of the arm

At the glenohumeral joint
OptionE:
Anterior: flexion and internal rotation of the arm
Middle: abduction of the arm
Posterior: extension and external rotation of the arm

At the glenohumeral joint
Explanation:
Anterior (clavicular) part: flexion and internal rotation of the arm,
Middle (acromial part): abduction of the arm beyond the initial 15°
Posterior (spinal part): extension and external rotation of the arm.

At the Glenohumeral joint (shoulder)
Tags: Anatomy of upper limb, Joints, Upper Limb Anatomy, Fattoush

Question:
Joe is walking home after being DESTROYED 1-on-1 by Tommy during medics football. He is hurt physically, as well as emotionally. He picks up his phone to cry to his mother, who will probably disown him now.

 

What does NEWS stand for?
A patient presents to A&E with severe trauma to her right forearm following an RTA. The patient is unable to pronate her forearm to any degree. Which two muscles are most likely to be affected?
Explanation: The pronator teres is a muscle (located mainly in the forearm) that, along with the pronator quadratus, serves to pronate the forearm (turning it so that the palm faces posteriorly when from the anatomical position). It has two attachments, to the medial humeral supracondylar ridge and the ulnar tuberosity, and inserts near the middle of the radius.
Tags: Anatomy of upper limb, Upper limb anatomy

Question: Within a DNA strand, what type of bond links all the nucleotides together?
Explanation: In DNA and RNA, nucleotides are linked by phosphodiester bonds between the 3' and 5' carbon atoms of the sugar.

Question:
Joseph and Thomas are setting up their wild west society when they come across a difficult question on their form. Help them to answer it:

 

Which best describes the superficial muscles present in the anterior compartement of the forearm?

OptionB: Palmaris longus, pronator teres, flexor carpi radialis, flexor carpi ulnaris
