Question: What are some of the direct effects of growth hormone?
OptionA: Insulin-like growth factor produced in the liver which targets growth plates to produce more cartilage, which is replaced by bone making you taller.
OptionB: Inhibits glucose uptake, stimulates protein synthesis, increases lipolysis and has anti-insulin effects.
Explanation: B= is correct, these are the direct anabolic effects whereas A lists the indirect effects of growth hormone, which also includes soft tissue growth, protein synthesis and cell proliferation.

Question:
There are different types of carriers in our bodies. ATP is an example of an energy carrier, coenzymeA is an example of a carbon carrier and NADH is an example of an electron carrier.

 

Which one of statements below is incorrect regarding these different carriers in our bodies?
OptionA: Flavin adenine dinucleotide is synthesised from riboflavin vitamin
OptionB: One molecule of NADH yields approximately 2.5ATP. One molecule of FADH2 yields approximately 1.5ATP
OptionC: Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide is synthesised as vitamin B3 in our diets
OptionD: NADPH is a very good oxidising agent
OptionE: Coenzyme A is a carbon carrier because it has a reactive side chain that can form bonds with two carbons
Explanation:
A - Flavin adenine dinucleotide - FAD is synthesised from riboflavin vitamin (therefore correct)

 

B - 1NADH = 2.5ATP 

      1FADH2 = 1.5ATP (therefore correct)

 

C - Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide - NAD+ is synthesised as vitamin B3 in our diets (therefore correct)

 

D - NADPH is a reducing agent used to build macromolecules] (therefore incorrect)

 

E - CoA's side chain can form bonds with two carbons, making it a carbon carrier (therefore correct)

 

All of the other statements are correct! (See slides 17-21 Lecture 7 Chemistry of Life for all of this written down)

Question: What is the theory of planned behaviour?
OptionA: that health is influenced by personal beliefs or perceptions about a disease or a health threat
OptionB: involves the belief that one is able to exert control over one's behaviour
OptionC: developed from the theory of reasoned action which focused on voluntary behaviour whereas this theory focusses on perceived behavioural control where attempts are made to link behaviour directly to health where behavioural intent is a key component and includes perceived severity and susceptibility and perceived benefits and barriers as the key components
OptionD: assess a persons readiness to act on a new healthier behaviour where we spiral through pre-contemplation, awareness, preparation, intention to change, action, modification and maintenance in order to change towards healthier behaviour
Explanation: A = health belief model B =self efficacy D = trans theoretical behaviour model of change

Question: The 'somatopause' is a phenomenon that occurs later in life when there's a decreased level of growth hormone in the blood. Which one of the following isn't a symptom of the somatopause.
Explanation: See hormonal control lecture

Question: Josh HATES looking over the key types of reactions in metabolic pathways in PCS1 because he can never remember them. He looks over one question about this topic and realises that he really should do some more revision on it because he can not even say which of the following statements below is incorrect. Can you help Josh?
OptionA: Oxidation, Ligation, Isomerisation, Reduction, Group transfer and Hydrolysis are the six key reactions in metabolic pathways
OptionB:
Pyruvate + CO2 + ATP + H2O --> Oxaloacetate +ADP +Pi + H+

This an example of a ligation reaction
OptionC: Kinases and phosphatases are the key enzymes that carry out group transfer reactions (of phosphate group)
OptionD:
Citrate --> isocitrate

This an example of an isomerisation reaction
Explanation:
A - REDOX (consisting of both oxidation and reduction reactions), Ligation, Isomerisation, Group transfer, LYASES and Hydrolysis are the six key recurring reaction

Ligation - uses ligase enzymes. Ligation is where 2 sets of carbon molecules join together (ATP usually required)

Isomerisation - rearrangement. Nothing enters/leaves the system. Isomerases are key enzymes

Group transfer - transfers functional groups. Kinases and Phosphatases are the key enzymes involved with transferring phosphate. 

Hydrolysis - splitting a molecule up, using H2O. Hydrolase enzymes involved.

Redox - oxidation and reduction reactions (addidtion/removal of oxygen or removal/addition of H+). Dehydrogenase enzymes are the key enzymes involved. 

Lyases - this reaction has many sub categories, and is when a molecule is broken apart without using water to do so but also without using oxidation. 

 

Therefore A is the incorrect answer

 

(Slides 23-27 of Chemistry of Life Lecture)

Question: What is the term used when describing excess free iron in the body?
Explanation: Haemochromatosis is used to describe having excess free iron in the body. This can be toxic as is can cause free radial reactions causing oxidative damage to cells.

Which form is present in animals and which form is present in plants?
This question recaps the basics of skeletal muscle. Which one of the statements below is correct regarding skeletal muscle?
OptionA: Skeletal muscle microstructure is made up of thick filaments (actin) and thin filaments (myosin)
OptionB: Skeletal muscle has non-myelinated axons, therefore conduction is not very rapid
OptionC: Skeletal muscle has a striated appearance, and does not contain nuclei
Explanation:
A - Skeletal muscle microstructure is made up of thick filaments (MYOSIN) and thin filaments (ACTIN)


B - Skeletal muscle has myelinated axons, therefore conduction is very rapid

 

C - Skeletal muscle has a striated appearance, and does contain nuclei

 

D - Skeletal muscle is under voluntary control of the somatic nervous system - therefore this is correct!

 

(Muscle Contraction Lecture)

Question: What is the difference between a molecule of ribose and a molecule of deoxyribose?
OptionA: Ribose is a five carbon sugar whereas deoxyribose is a six carbon sugar
OptionB: Ribose sugars may contain a uracil base as opposed to a thymine base
OptionC: Ribose sugars contain oxygen whereas deoxyribose does not contain any oxygen
OptionD: Ribose sugars have an oxygen bonded to their 1' and 4' carbons whereas deoxyribose have a hydroxyl group bonded to their 1' and 4' carbons
OptionE: Ribose has a hydroxyl group bonded to its 2' carbon whereas deoxyribose has a hydrogen bonded to its 2' carbon

Question: This question is about the sliding filament theory of muscle contraction and the detailed sequence of events that occurs in a cross bridge cycle. Which one of the following statements is not true regarding muscle contraction
OptionA: Myosin is an ATPase that hydrolyses ATP into ADP and Pi
OptionB: When the myosin head is 'cocked', it is in its low energy form
OptionC: When myosin head form cross bridges with actin active sites, ADP is attached to the myosin head
OptionD: When the phosphate is released, the myosin head moves, pulling (sliding) the actin filament past the myosin causing the power stroke
OptionE: When ATP is attached, the myosin head is no longer attached to the actin filament active sites as ATP binding causes myosin to release from actin
Explanation:
B - When the myosin head is 'cocked' it is in its highest energy form as it is ready to cause the power stroke and pull the actin filament along. When myosin is in its lowest energy form, it is called rigor mortis (when there is a lack of ATP, causing the muscles to stiffen) 

 

Muscle contraction lecture - slides 10 and 11

Question: Normally, only the heart sounds S1 and S2 can be heard in auscultation of the heart. However, in some cases, additional heart sounds S3 and S4 can b heard. When can both of these extra heart sounds be heard and why?
OptionA:
S3 = can be heard in early diastole. It is caused by deceleration of blood moving from the left atrium to the left ventricle and can indicate  congestive heart failiure. 
S4 = can be heard in atrial contraction. It is associated with stiff ventricles or left ventricular hypertrophy.
OptionB:
S3 = can be heard in atrial contraction. It is associated with stiff ventricles or left ventricular hypertrophy.
S4 = can be heard in early diastole. It is caused by deceleration of blood moving from the left atrium to the left ventricle and can indicate congestive heart failiure.
OptionC:
S3 = can be heard in early diastole. It is associated with stiff ventricles or left ventricular hypertrophy.

S4 = can be heard in atrial contraction. It is caused by deceleration of blood moving from the left atrium to the left ventricle and can indicate congestive heart failiure.
OptionD:
S3 = can be heard in atrial contraction. It is caused by deceleration of blood moving from the left atrium to the left ventricle and can indicate congestive heart failiure.

S4 = can be heard in early diastole. It is associated with stiff ventricles or left ventricular hypertrophy.
Explanation:
B is incorrect because it has both the location of the sounds and the cause of the sounds the other way around

C is incorrect because although the location of the sounds is correct, the cause of the sounds is the other way around

D is incorrect because although the cause of the sounds is correct, the location of the sounds is incorrect

Question:
This question is about length-tension curves, how this was determined and associated key words relating to this experiment.

 

Which one of the following statements is incorrect?
OptionA: Isotonic contractions are where muscles can get shorter
OptionB: The length-tension curve for a single muscle fibre was determined by clamping both ends of a muscle fibre into a fixed position, so that they could not get shorter. The tension of the muscle fibre at each length/fixed position could then be determined. This allowed us to see the optimal sarcomere length which generated the most tension.
OptionC: By squashing muscle fibres, you get more tension
OptionD: Isometric contractions are where muscles do not get shorter
OptionE: By elongating muscle fibres, you get less tension
Explanation:
A - Isotonic contractions are where muscles can get shorter. 

 

B - This is the correct experiment carried out to determine the optimal sarcomere length, which generated the most tension

 

C - By squashing muscle fibres, therefore making them shorter, you get less tension (as you disrupt the actin and myosin structure, as they go over each other so will not be able to bind and form cross bridges).

 

D - Isometric contractions are where muscles do not/can not get shorter

 

E - Similarly to C, if you make muscle fibres longer, the actin and myosin will be too far apart to bind, so cannot form cross bridges, so you will get less tension
Tags: Muscle Contraction, PCS 1, muscles, Isometric, Isotonic

Question: Skeletal muscle, smooth muscle and cardiac muscle have many similarities and differences. Which one of the following statements is incorrect regarding these two types of muscle?
OptionA: Skeletal muscle is under voluntary control whereas cardiac and smooth muscles are under involuntary control
OptionB: Both cardiac and skeletal muscle have striated appearance, unlike smooth muscle cells
OptionC: Smooth muscle contraction involves calmodulin, unlike cardiac and skeletal muscle contraction
OptionD: All three muscle types (smooth, skeletal and cardiac) contractions are thin filament regulated because they all involve actin and myosin
Explanation:
All three muscle types (smooth, skeletal and cardiac) contractions are not thin filament regulated because they do not all involve actin and myosin

 

Smooth muscle contractions are thick filament regulated:

- Ca2+ entering the cell binds to calmodulin, activating it. Calmodulin then activates myosin light chain kinase, which phosphorylates myosin light chain heads, causing the myosin ATPase activity to increase (which therefore increases the hydrolysis of ATP into ADP and Pi, so that the myosin head can attach to actin filament active site and form cross bridges, and carry out contraction). 

 

Skeletal and cardiac muscle contractions are thin filament regulated (therefore involve troponin)
Tags: Skeletal Muscle, Smooth Muscle, Muscle Contraction, PCS 1

Question: Heart failure is a condition in which the heart can't pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. One extra cardiac factor that can contribute to heart failure is increased preload. Which of the following conditions is the least likely to cause increased pre-load on the heart?
Explanation:
The answer is A because Mitral stenosis involves narrowing of the mitral valve which prevents normal filling of the ventricles and since pre-load is a measure of the tensions that exists in the heart walls as a result of increased diastolic filling (filling of the ventricles), it is unlikely that mitral stenosis will cause this. 

C is incorrect because Renal failure results in an increase in blood volume due to retention of sodium and water and this increase in blood volume results in increased pre-load.

Question:
There are different glucose transporters in the body. GLUT1, GLUT2, GLUT3, GLUT4 and GLUT 5. They are found in different tissues, have different properties and have different functions.

 

GLUT 1 and GLUT 3 are found everywhere in the body and have functions in basal uptake.

 

Where are GLUT2 and GLUT4 found, and what are the functions of these two transporters?
OptionA:
GLUT2 transporters are found in muscle and adipose tissue

GLUT4 transporters are found on the plasma membrane of the liver and pancreatic B cells

 

GLUT2 becomes more sensitive after a meal, and the liver activates GLUT2 before insulin is released

GLUT4 is insulin responsive
GLUT4 is not effected by exercise

GLUT2 transporters are found on the plasma membrane of the liver and pancreatic B cells

GLUT4 transporters are found in muscle and adipose tissue

 

GLUT2 becomes more sensitive after a meal, and the liver activates GLUT2 after insulin is released

GLUT4 is insulin responsive

GLUT4 is not effected by exercise
OptionC:
GLUT2 transporters are found on the plasma membrane of the liver and pancreatic B cells
GLUT4 transporters are found in muscle and adipose tissue

 

GLUT2 becomes more sensitive after a meal, and the liver activates GLUT2 before insulin is released

GLUT4 is insulin responsive

The more exercise you do, the better your body becomes at responding to glucose
OptionD:
GLUT2 transporters are found in muscle and adipose tissue
GLUT4 transporters are found on the plasma membrane of the liver and pancreatic B cells

 

GLUT2 becomes more sensitive after a meal, and the liver activates GLUT2 after insulin is released
GLUT4 is insulin responsive
The more exercise you do, the better your body becomes at responding to glucose
Explanation:
GLUT2 transporters are found on the plasma membrane of the liver and pancreatic B cells
GLUT4 transporters are found in muscle and adipose tissue

Question: Glycolysis occurs in the cytoplasm and produces two molecules of pyruvate per glucose. Which statement best describes the rate limiting step of glycolysis, the key regulatory enzyme (not found in the liver) which catalyses this step and best describes how the enzyme is regulated?
OptionA:
The phosphorylation of glucose into glucose-6-phosphate

Hexokinase enzyme catalyses this reaction

Hekokinase enzyme is self regulated (by its product glucose-6-phosphate)
OptionB:
The phosphorylation of glucose into glucose-6-phosphate
Glucokinase enzyme catalyses this reaction

Glucokinase enzyme is not self regulated, but regulated by fructose-6-phosphate
OptionC:
The phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate into fructose-1,6-bisphosphate 

Phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK1) enzyme catalyses this reaction

PFK1 enzyme responds to ATP and AMP. High levels of ATP (and therefore low levels of AMP/ADP) mean that PFK1 is switched on
OptionD:
The phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate into fructose-1,6-bisphosphate
Phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK1) enzyme catalyses this reaction
PFK1 enzyme responds to ATP and AMP. Low levels of ATP (and therefore high levels of AMP/ADP) mean that PFK1 is switched on
Explanation:
A - This statement is all correct, however this first step of glycolysis is NOT the rate limiting step. (But it is still a key regulatory step within glycolysis)

The phosphorylation of glucose into glucose-6-phosphate
Hexokinase enzyme catalyses this reaction
Hekokinase enzyme is self regulated (by its product glucose-6-phosphate)

 

B - This statement is incorrect because glucokinase is the isoform of hexokinase enzyme found in the liver (which this question is not asking for). 

 

C - This statement is correct about this stage being the rate limiting step, however it states incorrectly that at high levels of ATP, PFK1 is switched on. At high levels of ATP (and therefore low levels of AMP/ADP) PFK1 enzyme is switched off.

 

D - This is correct! This is the rate limiting step, PFK1 is the key enzyme that catalyses this reaction and it responds to ATP/AMP. At low levels of ATP, PFK1 is switched on. 

 

(Releasing Energy from Food Without using Oxygen Lecture)

Question: Julia is across the street from a bakery, whose freshly baked breads and pastries waft their aroma throughout the neighbourhood. As she tries to cross the road, a van almost crashes into her. Julia is in temporary shock and is feeling distressed. She also realises that she is no longer feeling hungry. What is a possible explanation for this?
OptionA: PYY hormone, that suppresses appetite, is released upon experiencing emotional stress.
OptionB: via the HPA-axis, adrenaline is released from the adrenal glands that acts on G-cells to inhibit gastrin secretion
OptionC: sympathetic activity during this event inhibits gastric secretion
OptionD: parasympathetic activity during this event inhibits gastric secretion
Explanation: emotional distress, fear, anxiety or any other state that triggers a sympathetic response will inhibit gastric secretion because the parasympathetic controls over the GI tract are temporarily overridden.
Tags: Digestion, Autonomic control, GI tract, PCS 2, sympathetic innervation

Question: You are on placement in the GP surgery when one of the patients in the waiting room starts to feel unwell and you are asked to take their blood pressure. Which of the following options best describes where you should place the stethoscope to hear the Korotkoff sounds:?
OptionA: Lateral to the biceps tendon in the cubital fossa
OptionB: Medial to the biceps tendon in the cubital fossa
OptionC: Lateral to the median cubital vein in the cubital fossa
OptionD: Medial to the median cubital vein in the cubital fossa
Explanation:
Brachial pulse can be felt by palpating medial to biceps tendon in cubital fossa & when measuring bp, it is where stethoscope must be placed to hear Korotkoff sounds

The medial cubital vein carries relevance to venepuncture, rather than blood pressure.
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Upper Limb Anatomy, Clinical

Question: You are shadowing a radiologist on one of your placements when he asks you to interpret an X-ray. He reminds you that an X-ray is a negative examination but what does he mean by this?
OptionA: An x-ray should only be carried out if definitely necessary as it carries some negative implications such as radiation
OptionB: Darkest part of the x-ray is where the most light shone through
OptionC: Lightest part of the x-ray is where the most light shone through
OptionD: Poor contrast is observed for soft-tissues on x-rays
OptionE: X-rays use high energy electrons that strike a rotating tungsten target
Explanation:
D is correct because this is the meaning of a negative examination e.g. on an X-ray, bone absorbs a lot of light, not much shines through and hence bones appear as white while e.g. air is seen as dark because a lot of light shines through. Covered in medical imaging lecture.

While D & E are correct statements, they do not define negative examination

Question: In a 12 lead ECG which of these leads does not produce an inferior view of the heart?
Explanation: V3 along with V4 will produce an anterior view of the heart where V3 is the chest lead placed midway between V2 at the 4th intercostal space and V4 at the 5th intercostal space on the mid axillary line.

Question: A medical student is describing a drug to their friend as they have forgotten the name but they know its mechanism and that it acts on the heart which drug are they describing: ' it is a beta blocker which is a selective B1 antagonist which depresses phase 4 of the pacemaker action potential as it blocks the calcium channels meaning heart rate is slowed and so it is used to treat angina and Gs is blocked so less ATP is converted to cAMP by adenylate cyclase'
Explanation:
D and E act on the eye primarily and not the heart where pilocarpine constricts the pupil by being a muscarnic acetylcholine receptor agonist and exciting the parasympathetic nervous system while tropic amide is a mAChR antagonist which prevents pupil constricting and hence causes it to dilate. 

Adrenaline is a beta 1 G protein coupled agonist which causes this receptor to become activated and hence cAMP levels will increase, the calcium channels become phosphorylated and more calcium enters the pace-maker cells and hence a steeper phase 4 results in more spontaneous action potentials 

Verapamil is an L-type calcium channel blocker which is used as an anti-arrhymia drug as it causes a longer phase 2 as this is where there would be an influx of calcium

Question: A medical student is reviewing the autonomic control of the heart and wants to know what effect caffeine has on the heart how would this be explained?
OptionA:
When not phosphorylated it binds to SERCA and inhibits it; the overall effect of this micro peptide hormone is to decrease contractility and the rate of muscle relaxation to increase stroke volume and heart rate. Calcium ion channel repressor and is inactivated by the phosphorylation by PKA
It acts as an ATPase inhibitor
OptionB:
inhibits phosphodiesterase which usually converts cAMP to AMP this causes increased levels of cAMP in the cardiac myocytes
This leads to a greater level of PKA
Therefore a phosphorylation cascade occurs, resulting in Ca2+ entering the myocytes
This Ca2+ then bonds to troponin, resulting in a stronger contraction force (ionotropic effect)
OptionC: binds to action which holds the actin - myosin complex in place and it must be removed for contraction to take place
OptionD: competitive inhibitor for sodium pump in the myocyte which would be exchanged for calcium ions and hence there is an increase in calcium ion concentration and hence an increase in heart rate
Explanation: A is the role of phospholamban and C is the role of troponin I and D is the mechanism for digitalis

Question: Mrs. Jones visits her GP complaining of chest pain, dizziness and feeling fatigued. Her GP decides to take an ECG and upon examining it, he notices something off with it. The image below shows a part of Mrs. Jones ECG. What can explain this pattern?
Explanation: During 2nd degree heart block, there is intermittent failure of excitation to pass to the ventricles. P-R intervals on the ECG become progressively longer until one P-wave fails to elicit a QRS complex and thus ventricular depolarisation.  So you may likely notice P-waves with no corresponding QRS complexes.

Question: Which one of the following statements describes one of the roles of thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) in aerobic respiration, within the mitochondria?
OptionA: Removes a phosphate from one of the intermediates during glycolysis.
OptionB: Adds a phosphate to one of the intermediates during glycolysis.
OptionD: Decarboxylates citrate in the citric acid cycle.
Explanation:
A - This is incorrect. TPP does not removes a phosphate from one of the intermediates during glycolysis. This could have been eliminated by process of elimination because it is talking about glycolysis which occurs in the cytoplasm. The question specifically asks for the role of TPP in aerobic respiration in the mitochondria

 

B - This is incorrect. TPP does not add a phosphate to one of the intermediates during glycolysis. Again, this could have been eliminated by process of elimination because it is talking about glycolysis which occurs in the cytoplasm.

 

C - This is correct. 

 

D - Citrate is not decarboxylated in TCA cycle, so this is incorrect.

Question: The link reaction takes place in the mitochondria and is irreversible. One of the statements below regarding the link reaction is incorrect, can you identify which one?
OptionA: The link reaction is the stage of aerobic respiration where pyruvate is converted to acetyl CoA, following the oxdidative decarboxylation and the addition of CoA to pyruvate.
OptionC: The link reaction is inhibited by its products
OptionD: One CO2 molecule, one NADH (+H+) and one Acetyl CoA molecule is produced from the link reaction
Explanation:
A - This is correct. The link reaction is the stage of aerobic respiration where pyruvate is converted to acetyl CoA, following the oxidative decarboxylation (the oxidation of pyruvate, and then the removal of a CO2 molecule) and the addition of CoA to pyruvate.

 

B - This is correct. The link reaction is adenylate controlled. High levels of ATP deactivates pyruvate dehydrogenase (which carries out the oxidation of pyruvate). high levels of pyruvate increase the activation of pyruvate dehydrogenase 

 

C - This is correct. The link reaction is inhibited by its products (NADH and Acetyl CoA)

 

D - This is incorrect. 2x CO2, 2x NADH (+H+) and 2x Acetyl CoA produced from the link reaction (due to it occurring twice, for each one glucose molecule)

Question: Which statement does not best describe the cofactors involved in the link reaction?
OptionA: TPP cofactor is used in the link reaction to decarboxylate pyruvate and is not used up during the reaction
OptionB: Lipoic acid is a cofactor involved in the link reaction and it is not used up during the reaction
OptionC: CoA is a cofactor involved in the link recaction
OptionD: NADH is a cofator involved in the link reaction
Explanation:
A, B, C - all correct. CoA, TPP and lipoid acid are all cofactors involved in the link reaction. Lipoic acid and TPP are not used up in the process.

 

D - This is incorrect. NAD+ is a cofactor involved in the link reaction. NADH is a product of the link reaction

Question: Opsonisation is part of the innate immune response and occurs due to the production of a membrane attack pathway due to the production of what molecule on the pathogen surface?
Explanation:
B is the correct answer, C3b is produced via three different pathways. C3 is cleaved into C3a and C3b. C3b leads to opsonisation and C3a co-ordinates the inflammatory response and membrane attack complex, producing anaphyltoxin. 

C and D are actually types of T cell (cytotoxic and helper respectively)

D is the memory B cell, which is activated when MHC II receptor has specific protein from antigen in

Question: The cori cycle, also called the lactic acid cycle, is the metabolic process whereby the lactate produced from anaerobic respiration in the muscles is transported back to the liver. Which one of the statements below best describes the cori cycle
OptionA:
Lactate (which is more stable than lactic acid) is transported back to the liver via the blood where it is converted back to glucose. The lactate is converted to pyruvate, and then converted to glucose by gluconeogenesis. This is an ATP intensive process (net use of 4 ATP) therefore aerobic respiration must be occurring as ATP must be in constant supply.

 

The cori cycle occurs to prevent lactate acidosis under anaerobic conditions.
OptionB:
Lactate (which is more stable than lactic acid) is transported back to the liver via the blood where it is converted back to glucose. The lactate is converted to pyruvate, and then converted to glucose by gluconeogenesis. This is an ATP intensive process (net use of 6 ATP) therefore aerobic respiration must be occurring as ATP must be in constant supply.

 

The cori cycle occurs to prevent lactate acidosis under anaerobic conditions.
OptionC:
Lactate (which is more stable than lactic acid) is transported back to the liver via the blood where it is converted back to glucose. The lactate is converted to pyruvate, and then converted to glucose by gluconeogenesis. This is an ATP intensive process (net use of 4 ATP) therefore aerobic respiration must be occurring as ATP must be in constant supply.

 

The cori cycle occurs to prevent lactate acidosis under aerobic conditions.
OptionD:
Lactate (which is more stable than lactic acid) is transported back to the liver via the blood where it is converted back to glucose. The lactate is converted to pyruvate, and then converted to glucose by gluconeogenesis. This is an ATP intensive process (net use of 6 ATP) therefore aerobic respiration must be occurring as ATP must be in constant supply.

 


The cori cycle occurs to prevent lactate acidosis under aerobic conditions.
Explanation:
A - this is correct. 

Lactate (which is more stable than lactic acid) is transported back to the liver via the blood where it is converted back to glucose.

The lactate is converted to pyruvate, and then converted to glucose by gluconeogenesis. (2x lactate --> 2x pyruvate --> 1x glucose)

This is an ATP intensive process (net use of 4 ATP. 6 are used to convert pyruvate back to glucose, but 2 are produced during glycolysis, to form pyruvate from glucose)

Therefore aerobic respiration must be occurring as ATP must be in constant supply.

The cori cycle occurs to prevent lactate acidosis under anaerobic conditions - if is was aerobic conditions, there would not be a lactate build up because pyruvate would enter the mitochondria to undergo the link reaction, not get converted to lactic acid.

 

 

(Adaptations to Exercise Tutorial)
Tags: Aerobic respiration, Anaerobic respiration, PCS 1, Cori Cycle

Question: Marathon runners can 'hit the wall'. Which one of these statements does not best describe a marathon runner hitting the wall and how they should avoid it?
OptionA: To avoid hitting the wall, you should undergo altitude training
OptionB: Hitting the wall is the depletion of glycogen (the main energy source during exercise). As a result, you run out of this energy source and begin to undergo lipolysis, which is a much faster process. You become extremely fatigued
OptionC: To avoid hitting the wall, you should little carbohydrates so that your body is less dependent on them during exercise
OptionD: To avoid hitting the wall, you should stick to pace whilst running
Explanation:
Hitting the wall is the depletion of glycogen (the main energy source during exercise). As a result, you run out of this energy source and begin to undergo lipolysis, which is a much faster process. You become extremely fatigued.

 

To avoid hitting the wall you should:

Undergo altitude training, to increase the number of RBCs so you can carry more oxygen (and reduce oxygen debt)

Stick to pace whilst running

Eat plenty of carbohydrates so that your body can build up a larger carbohydrate stored - making C incorrect

 

(adaptation to exercise tutorial)

Question: Which one of the following statements is incorrect regarding the intertubercular sulcus of the humerus?
OptionA: The intertubercular sulcus of the humerus separates the greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus
OptionB: The tendon of the short head of the biceps brachii runs through this intertubercular deep groove of the humerus from the shoulder joint
OptionC: Pectoralis major, teres major and latissimus dorsi insert onto the intertubercular sulcus of the humerus
OptionD: The intertubercular sulcus of the humerus is also known as the bicipital groove
Explanation:
A - This is correct. see diagram (the groove separates the greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus


B - This is incorrect. The tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii runs through this deep groove

 

C, D - These are correct 

 

Refer to bones of the upper - teach me anatomy for clarification/more diagrams
