Question: The lateral compartment of the lower leg has two muscles in it, what are they called?
Explanation: C: incorrect, these muscles are in the posterior compartment of the lower leg and form the Achille's tendon together.
Tags: Lower Limb, Anatomy of the lower limb, Case 1

Question: Bruno has recently burnt his hand. The process of him burning his hand to him experiencing the pain is called nociception. What are the 4 stages of nociception in the correct order?
Explanation:
Nociception occurs in four main phases:
• Transduction: Exposure to noxious stimulus produces action potential (periphery)
• Transmission: Travels along fibres from point of transduction to dorsal horn and to the brain (spinal cord)
• Perception: Experience of discomfort, pain. Conscious, emotional & subjective (brain)
• Modulation: Response to pain, facilitation or inhibition of nociceptive input

Question: Josephine cut herself trying to open a tin can. She experiences a lot of pain but, being a neuroscience student, is aware that this is her brain's interpretation of the nociceptive signal. Which part of the brain is responsible for pain perception?
OptionA: The thalamus receives the nociceptive inputs from the afferent nerve fibres and pain perception then occurs in the cerebral cortex
OptionB: The amygdala receives the nociceptive inputs from the afferent nerve fibres and pain perception then occurs in the basal ganglia
OptionC: The amygdala receives the nociceptive inputs from the afferent nerve fibres and pain perception then occurs in the cerebral cortex
OptionD: The thalamus receives the nociceptive inputs from the afferent nerve fibres and pain perception then occurs in the pons
OptionE: The amygdala receives the nociceptive inputs from the afferent nerve fibres and pain perception then occurs in the cerebellum
Explanation:
In the brain;

• Thalamus is the second relay station
• Connections to many parts of the brain; Cortex, Limbic system & Brainstem
• Pain perceptions occurs in the cortex

Question: Venezuela presents at A&E insisting she has fractured her hip after googling her symptoms. after carrying out a physical examination and x-ray, the doctor explains she has dislocated rather than fractured her hip, but what is the difference?
OptionA:
Dislocation = hip externally rotated

Fracture = hip internally rotated
OptionB:
Dislocation = hip internally rotated
Fracture = hip externally rotated
OptionC: Dislocations are more likely to heal improperly than fractures
OptionD: Fracture can cause injury to blood vessels and nerves whereas a dislocation cannot.
OptionE: Loss of power at the joint is a sign of a fracture but not a dislocation
Explanation:
A is wrong because it is the other way around (B)- think of a posterior dislocation of the hip, the presentation is that the leg is internally rotated 

C- this is untrue, both are similarly likely to heal improperly

D- dislocations can cause injury to blood vessels and nerves

E- loss of power at the joint is also a sign of dislocation
Tags: Anatomy, Lower Limb, Anatomy of the lower limb, Case 1, Clinical

Question: A 50-year-old man is undergoing a right nephrectomy. The surgeons divide the renal artery. At what level does this usually branch off the abdominal aorta?
Explanation: The renal arteries usually branch off the aorta on a level with L2

Question: A 20-year-old male with sickle cell presents to the hospital with signs of infection and sever dehydration, as well as acute kidney injury. Which of the following acts to directly activate the renin-angiotensin system?
Explanation:
The renin-angiotensin system (RAS) is a hormone system that is involved in the regulation of the plasma sodium concentration and arterial blood pressure. 

 

-When the plasma sodium concentration is lower than normal or the renal blood flow is reduced through low blood pressure, the juxtaglomerular cells in the kidneys convert prorenin into renin, which is then secreted directly into the circulation

-Plasma renin then acts on angiotensinogen to form angiotensin I. Angiotensin I is then converted, to angiotensin II, by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) found within the lungs and the epithelial cells of the kidneys. 

-Angiotensin II is a potent vaso-active peptide that causes arterioles to constrict, resulting in increased arterial blood pressure. Angiotensin II also stimulates the secretion of the hormone aldosterone from the adrenal cortex. 

-Aldosterone causes the kidneys to increase the reabsorption of sodium ions from the tubular fluid into the blood, while at the same time causing them to excrete potassium ions which are lost in urine.

Question: Atherosclerosis is caused by the deposition of lipid layered foam cells, but what are these cells made up of?
OptionA: Foam cells formed from a higher ratio of HDL:LDL, with increased HDL deposition
OptionB: Foam cells are derived from macrophages which ingest and degrade LDL
OptionC: Foam cells are secreted by cytokines like TNF-alpha and CXCL8
OptionD: Foam cells formed from a higher ratio of LDL:HDL with increased LDL deposition
Explanation:
A: incorrect, this is the wrong way around, higher ratio of LDL can cause athersclerosis due to the pathway highlighted in B 

B: correct :)

C: incorrect, made this up

D: this is correct, however the better, more specific answer is A
Tags: Case 2, atherosclerosis, ischemia, coronary artery disease

Question: Kay is running a half-marathon, she is running at a fast pace, faster than she has run before. She thinks back to her lectures on the heart and remembers that exercise increases preload but she can't remember what effect this will have on the ejection fraction of the heart. Can you help her?
OptionA: There is an increased venous return, increasing preload and therefore increasing stroke volume by the Frank-Starling mechanism. This means ejection fraction will increase.
OptionB: Increased aortic pressure and systemic vascular resistance means that the aortic valve closes at a higher pressure, therefore there is a lower ejection fraction as a lower volume of blood can be pumped from the heart.
OptionC: There is a decreased venous return, decreasing preload and therefore decreasing stroke volume by the Frank-Starling mechanism. This means ejection fraction will decrease.
Explanation:
A: this is correct, ejection fraction increases because the increased volume increases pressure therefore causing more stretch so a greater volume of blood can be ejected at any one time. 

B: incorrect, this describes an increased AFTERLOAD

C: incorrect, this is the wrong way around
Tags: Cardiac anatomy, Cardiac cycle, Heart, Heart Rate, Heart anatomy

Question: Felacio is really struggling to cope with his chronic pain and has decided to carry out his own research. He looks into different inhibitory  neurotransmitters involved in the modulation of pain but which of the following is not an inhibitory neurotransmitter involved in pain?
Explanation:
A & B are both endogenous opioids involved in the inhibitory modulation of pain

D is an EXCITATORY neurotransmitter

Question: Describe the intracellular signalling cascade that initiates an increased inotropy
OptionA: Norepinephrine is the neurotransmitter that activates the B1 adrenoceptor causing activation of the Gs subunit catalysing the formation of cAMP from ATP by adenyl cyclase activating protein kinase A meaning that there is more Ca2+ which hyperpolarises HCN channels so less time is required to meet threshold and they depolarise sooner, increasing inotropy
OptionB: Decreased levels of the neurotransmitter adrenaline, which binds to receptor ligands coupled to Gs proteins. This causes less conversion of ATP to cAMP by adenyl cyclase. cAMP activates protein kinase A which phosphorylates L-type calcium channels, therefore decreased Ca2+ concentration in the SR so more of the ion binds to troponin, therefore creating weaker contractions, increasing inotropy.
OptionC: Increased levels of the neurotransmitter adrenaline, which binds to receptor ligands coupled to Gs proteins. This causes the conversion of ATP to cAMP by adenyl cyclase. cAMP activates protein kinase A which phosphorylates L-type calcium channels, therefore increasing Ca2+ concentration in the SR so more of the ion binds to troponin, therefore creating stronger contractions, increasing inotropy.
Explanation:
A: incorrect, this is actually the correct pathway for increased chronotropy! Heart rate

B: incorrect, INCREASED adrenaline

C: correct pathway! :)

Question: How does the SERCA pump work and when stimulated, how does it affect heart rate?
OptionA: Beta-adrenergic stimulation causes cAMP dependent pKA to phosphorylate phospholamban, this increases Ca2+ uptake by the sarcoplasmic reticulum therefore increasing the rate of relaxation and increasing heart rate and cardiac output.
OptionB: Beta-adrenergic stimulation causes cAMP dependent pKA to phosphorylate phospholamban, this increases Ca2+ uptake by the sarcoplasmic reticulum therefore decreasing the rate of relaxation and decreasing heart rate and cardiac output.
OptionC: Beta-adrenergic stimulation causes cAMP dependent phosphatase to dephosphorylate phospholamban, this increases Ca2+ uptake by the sarcoplasmic reticulum therefore increasing the rate of relaxation and increasing heart rate and cardiac output.
OptionD: Beta-adrenergic stimulation causes cAMP dependent phosphatase to dephosphorylate phospholamban, this increases Ca2+ uptake by the sarcoplasmic reticulum therefore decreasing the rate of relaxation and decreasing heart rate and cardiac output.
Explanation:
A: correct

B: incorrect as it increases cardiac output etc 

C + D : incorrect as we use a kinase not a phosphatase
Tags: Cardiac Action Potential, Cardiac anatomy, Case 2

Question: Rishi has recently had a viral infection and both his innate and adaptive immune systems have kicked in to try and clear it. Which of the following best describes the innate immune system?
OptionA: The innate immune system is relatively quickly induced (days) but is relatively non-specific. It is designed to eliminate early infectious threats or hold them at bay until the adaptive immune system is activated.
OptionB: The innate immune system is rapidly induced (minutes) and is specific. It is designed to eliminate early infectious threats or hold them at bay until the adaptive immune system is activated.
OptionC: The innate immune system is relatively quickly induced (days) and is specific. It is required to completely eradicate infection and prevent reinfection.
OptionD: The innate immune system is rapidly induced (minutes) but is relatively non-specific. It is designed to eliminate early infectious threats or hold them at bay until the adaptive immune system is activated.
OptionE: The innate immune system is rapidly induced (minutes) and non-specific. It halters the progress of early infections.
Explanation:
A- wrong because it takes minutes not days for the innate immune system to be engaged

B- wrong because the innate immune system is non-specific

C- wrong because it takes minutes not days for the innate immune system to be engaged and it is non-specific and it does not completely eradicate infection always

E- not enough detail, D is a better option, but it is correct in what it says

Question: When looking at blood vessel tone, what is the difference between autoregulation and functional hyperaemia?
OptionA:
Autoregulation is the intrinsic response to stretch and looks at the stability of blood flow, the myogenic response to increased resistance e.g. if there is an increased pressure, there is vasoconstriction to restore blood flow. 

Functional hyperaemia is when there is increased efficiency in removing waste products e.g. in exercise like increased relaxation of VSMC causing vasodilation.
OptionB:
Functional hyperaemia is the intrinsic response to stretch and looks at the stability of blood flow, the myogenic response to increased resistance e.g. if there is an increased pressure, there is vasoconstriction to restore blood flow.

Autoregulation is when there is increased efficiency in removing waste products e.g. in exercise like increased relaxation of VSMC causing vasodilation.
Explanation: B: incorrect, wrong way around

Question: What is the mechanism through which nitric oxide (NO) causes vasodilation?
OptionA: NO activates guanylate cyclase, this causes the conversion of GTP to cGMP. cGMP then activates pKG which phosphorylates myosin light chain kinase, therefore causing vasodilation.
OptionB: NO activates guanylate cyclase, this causes the conversion of GTP to cGMP. cGMP then activates pKG which leads to the activation of myosin phosphatase which dephosphorylates myosin light chain kinase, therefore causing vasodilation.
OptionC: NO activates adenyl cyclase, this causes the conversion of ATP to cAMP. cAMP then activates pKA which leads to the activation of myosin phosphatase which dephosphorylates myosin light chain kinase, therefore causing vasodilation.
OptionD: NO activates adenyl cyclase, this causes the conversion of ATP to cAMP. cAMP then activates pKA  which phosphorylates myosin light chain kinase, therefore causing vasodilation.
Explanation:
A: incorrect as it misses out the activation of myosin phosphatase, therefore has phosphorylation the wrong way around. 

B: correct :)

C: incorrect as looks at adenyl cyclase, cAMP and pKA instead

D: wrong activators, and wrong phosphoryation way around
Tags: Cardiac Action Potential, Cardiac anatomy, Cardiac cycle, Case 2

Question: Oliver has been to the GP after experiencing what he believed to be a tummy bug and was told he has Giardiasis, a parasitic infection caused by a parasite called Giardia intestinali. Which of the following best describes how the body deals with parasitic infections?
OptionA: Most parasites are too big to be phagocytosed so macrophages, dendritic cells, eosinophils and basophils are used to encourage actions such as vomiting, diarrhoea and coughing to eject the parasitic organism from the body.
OptionB: Most parasites are too big to be phagocytosed so mast cells, eosinophils and basophils are used to encourage actions such as vomiting, diarrhoea and coughing to eject the parasitic organism from the body.
OptionC: Most parasites can be phagocytosed but for those that cannot; mast cells, eosinophils and basophils are used to encourage actions such as vomiting, diarrhoea and coughing to eject the parasitic organism from the body.
OptionD: Most parasites are phagocytosed by the action of macrophages and CD8+ cyctotoxic T cels.
OptionE: Most parasites are too big to be phagocytosed so mast cells are used to eject the parasitic organism from the body.
Explanation:
A - not the best answer as there is no mention of mast cells which are important in dealing with parasitic infections

C- not the best answer as most parasites are not phagocytosed

D- not the best answer as most parasites are not phagocytosed and it is mast cells, eosinophils and basophils that are involved mainly in dealing with parasites

E- not enough detail

Question: Ehlers dans syndrome is a connective tissue disorder that affects collagen. Which connective tissue connects muscle to bones?
Explanation: Tendons are composed of tough fibrous connective tissue which are able to withstand tension and are composed of collagen and elastin fibres embedded in a proteoglycan matrix

Question: Pericardial effusion can be caused by an infection, fluid accumulates in the pericardial cavity and can cause symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath (dyspnea), discomfort when lying down (orthopnea) and swelling in the legs or abdomen. When this fluid compresses the heart, increasing pressure and reducing ejection fraction, the condition is called something else. What is this condition called?

Question: Mitral valve replacement can be performed when there is stenosis, in order to improve blood flow to the ventricle or when there is regurgitation. One symptom of mitral valve stenosis is shortness of breath. This can be caused by pulmonary oedema. What is the mechanism of this?
OptionA: Narrowed valve means that blood pools in the left ventricle, this pooling of blood compromises cardiac output, therefore increasing the thickness of the myocardium in the ventricular wall.
OptionB: The narrowed valve (stenosis) results in a reduced blood flow to the ventricles, therefore more blood stays in the left atrium. This increases the resistance of the blood in the pulmonary vein, therefore creating pooling of blood in the lungs. This increased fluid compared to air in the lungs therefore causes breathlessness.
OptionC: The narrowed valve (stenosis) results in a reduced blood flow to the ventricles, therefore more blood stays in the left atrium. This decrease the resistance of the blood in the pulmonary vein, therefore creating pooling of blood in the lungs. This increased fluid compared to air in the lungs therefore causes breathlessness.
Explanation:
A; this is incorrect as does not describe oedema, instead describing left ventricular hypertrophy

C: incorrect, increases NOT decreases resistance
Tags: Cardiac anatomy, Heart, Heart anatomy, Case 2

Question: You are about to give a child their MMR vaccine, however, you can tell they are really worried about it hurting so you try to distract them by focusing their attention towards a funny picture. Which of the following best explains why you try to distract their attention away from the pain?

Question: Metabolising lipids can occur in different pathways: one such involves excess cholesterol from peripheral tissues being delivered to the liver by HDL. What is this pathway called?

A: exogenous is the movement of dietary fats, they are absorbed in the form of chylomicrons to capillaries, acted on by lipoprotein lipase, the remnant free fatty acids form adipose tissue and the chylomicron remnants are transported to the liver. 

B: correct

C: endogenous pathway is when free fatty acids and cholesterol from the liver form very low density lipoproteins entering the capillary and then form adipose tissue and intermediate density lipoproteins, hepatic lipase breaks down LDL which travels to tissues and is also deposited in the liver.

What is this condition called?

Question: Diabetes can mean that there is impaired granulocyte function and chemotaxis meaning the individual is more prone to infection, decreased collagen synthesis and increased levels of proteinases and defective macrophages due to the high levels of glucose in the blood. Also diabetes may experience impaired wound healing due to diabetic ulcers or inflammation meaning they are unable to dense cutaneous pressure. Which factor below is not a local factor affecting wound healing?
Explanation: hormones along with stress and disease, age, sex and medication are all systemic factors affecting wound healing

Question: Mr Z visits his GP complaining of breathlessness and a persistent cough which brings up purulent, yellow green sputum.  His history reveals that he has been admitted to hospital with pneumonia. His CT results are shown below. Based on the available information, what would be a reasonable diagnosis for Mr Z?
OptionB: pulmonary edmea due to congestive heart failure
Explanation:
Bronchiectasis is a long term condition where the airways of the lung become abnormally widened, leading to a build up of mucous that can make the lungs more vulnerable to infection. The most common symptoms of bronchiectasis are a persistent cough that usually brings up sputum and breathlessness. Both symptoms were presented by Mr Z. In a large number of cases, the cause for bronchiectasis is idiopathic (no known cause). However, it can be caused by damage or destruction to the muscle and tissue surrounding the bronchi. This would occur in pneumonia , something that Mr Z has a past medicla history of. CT shows tramlines which are due to the thickening of the bronchial walls 

lung abscesses could cause a cough. However, the sputum is foul smelling and dark due to the presence of anaerobic bacteria. It may also be streaked with blood 

Pulmonary edema could also present with breathlessness. However, sputum production is not a typical presentation (the pink frofy secretions from the trachea should not be confused with sputum)

Question: Miss Shoe was very much looking forward to her favourite dinner (cheesy chips and gravy) a few hours ago. Once eating her food she feels very full and satisfied, so she does not have much of an appetite left. Which of the following are an example of an anorexigenic hormone
Explanation:
anorexigenic = decreases appetite

orexigenic = increases appetite

 

leptin = decreases appetite (therefore anorexigenic)

ghrelin = increases appetite (therefore orexigenic)

orexin = increases cravings of food just prior to eating (therefore orexigenic, clue is in the name)

CCK = gives a feeling of short term satiety (thus decreases appetite and is anorexigenic)

PYY = decreases appetite (therefore anorexigenic)

Question: What is the function of J receptors in respiration?
OptionA: Respond to degree of stretch. located in the tissue of the lung and act to prevent overinflation. Stimulation terminates the inspiritory phase
OptionB: Respond to changes in blood flow and chemistry. Stimulation limits inflation and shortens inspiritory phase
OptionC: Responds to irritants. Stimulation brings about a foreful ejection of air (cough)
OptionD: Located in the golgi tendons. Respond to changes in position and length. When exercising, regular rythmic movement of joints upregulates breathing to match metabolic demand
Explanation:
A- refering to stretch receptors 

B- correct answer 

C-irritant receptor 

D- proprioceptor

Question: What is the substrate of renin?
Explanation: Renin hydrolyses angiotensinogen to form angiotensin I

Question: An 80-year-old man with a history of chronic kidney disease presents to the general practice with a painful left foot. You prescribe NSAIDs, however, they are contraindicated in severe renal disease. Which of the following statements most accurately describes the action of NSAIDs on the glomerular filtration pressure?
Explanation:
NSAIDs are commonly used anti-inflammatory drugs, their main mechanism of action is via the inhibition of the enzymes COX-1 and COX-2. These enzymes are pivotal for the synthesis of prostanoids (prostaglandins and thromboxanes)

In the kidney the prostaglandins cause a vasodilation of the afferent arterioles of the glomeruli. This allows for a higher rate of blood flow into the glomerulus and thus an increase in glomerular filtration rate. 

 

The NSAIDs inhibit the role of COX enzymes and subsequently reduce the levels of prostaglandins. The resulting loss of afferent arteriole vasodilation causes a reduced renal perfusion and thus GFR.

Question: At which level is the hilum of the left kidney located
Explanation: Remember L1 (left one) is the level of the hilum of the left kidney

Question: Juniper, 12, has recently broken her arm. It has been placed in a cast for the next 6 weeks while the fracture repairs itself. What processes, in the correct order, will take place as the bone heals?
OptionA: Haematoma, Inflammation, Granulation, Callus formation, Consolidation, Remodelling
Explanation:
Stages of natural bone healing;
• Haematoma- blood vessel tearing, local bleeding & defect between fracture ends filled with blood clot,
• Inflammation- acute inflammation, macrophages invade the clot & start destruction, then vascular ingrowth
• Granulation- vascular ingrowth (of granulation capillaries), by 5th day after injury, granulation tissue has replaced clot entirely
• Callus- islands of cartilage appear, near the periosteum, fracture ends are now united by a sleeve of vascularized granulation tissue & cartilage = provisional callus. By the end of week 1, calcium is deposited in the cartilage, osteoblast start to produce osteoid across the fracture. The callus calcifies and ends unite
• Consolidation
• Remodeling – woven bone (immature) replaced by lamellar bone (osteoblasts & osteoclasts), excess bone is slowly resorbed, takes years, often incomplete

Question:
A patient attends the renal clinic having been diagnosed with chronic kidney disease stage 4, secondary to long-standing hypertension and diabetes. She asks about the diet she should be keeping to. 

 

What is the most appropriate piece of advice about her diet she should be given?
Explanation:
Protein - a source of ammonia, which is normally excreted by the kidney (but less so in chronic kidney disease)

 

Phosphate - can complex with calcium to cause renal stones

 

Sodium - increases blood pressure, which damages the kidney further 

 

Potassium - not well excreted by failing kidneys and can cause cardiac arrhythmias

Question:
A 5-year-old boy is referred to the child assessent unit for recurrent urinary tract infections. The paediatrics trainee asks the medical student to list the risk factors for UTI's in children. 

 

Which one of the following is a known risk factor for UTIs in children
Explanation:
Posterior urethral valves increases the risk of urinary tract infection

 

Double voiding is a protective factor and reduces the risk of urinary tract infections (UTI) in children by ensuring the bladder is completely empty. 

 

Male gender is a protective factor against UTIs, because in males the urethra is 8 inches long, while in females, the urethra is only 2 inches long; this reduces the risk of UTIs in males

 

Male circumcision is known to reduce the risk of UTIs

Question: Margarita, a post menopausal, caucasian woman, 57, has recently been diagnosed with osteoporosis. She decides to read up on it and reads that being caucasian/asian is a risk factor for osteoporosis. Which of the following best explain why this is the case?
OptionA: Asian/Caucasian women tend to be more likely to undergo early-menopause.
OptionB: Asian/Caucasian women tend to have lower levels of oestrogen.
OptionC: Asian/Caucasian women tend to have higher levels of progesterone.
OptionD: Asian/Caucasian women tend to be more likely to have thyroid issues.
OptionE: This information she has read is not accurate. Asian/caucasian women are not at higher risk of osteoporosis.
Explanation: Low level of oestrogen causes an increase in the osteoclast: osteoblast ratio which causes apoptosis of osteoclasts and lower levels of oestrogen are present in Caucasian & Asians.

Question: Nadja is a 38 year old woman who has recently started experiencing swelling and stiffness in her joints. She finds this is particularly worse in the morning, in her hands and elbows, and has attended the GP because this pain has been getting progressively worse over the past few weeks. Based solely on this information, what may the GP suspect Nadja has?
Explanation:
E- Scoliosis is usually diagnosed much younger

C- osteoarthritis present usually older, stifness develops slower over years not weeks, swelling is rare

B- form of pre osteoarthritis so same as C applies

A- back pain is usually the main symptom

Question: Where does breathing pattern arise?
Explanation:
The medulla is considered to be a pattern generator. This is determined as if damaged is obtained between the level of the spinal cord and the medulla, then breathing caeses

The pons is responsible for fine tuning breathing; modifying the rate and the rhythm, this is determined because if damage is obtained in this area, breathing pattern is irregular


breathing is able to continue if there is damage to the cerebral cortex (for example when the patient is in a vegetive state)

Question: Francis, 22, recently suffered a bad fall while out roller skating. He sustained lacerations of similar degrees both his face and knee. 3 weeks later and his facial wound had healed, with almost no scarring, yet his knee wound, had only partially healed and he could see a scar beginning to form on the edges. Which of the following could best explain the reasons for this?
OptionA: He was not consuming sufficient Copper and Vitamin C in his diet, which are both needed for effective wound healing.
OptionB: There is better vascularity to facial wounds.
OptionC: His knee laceration still has a foreign body stuck in it.
OptionD: His fluctuating levels of hormones will have affected the rates of healing.
OptionE: He was taking anti-inflammatory drugs which slowed the wound healing process in his knee.
Explanation:
A- this is a systemic factor. The answer should be looking for a local factor as one wound has healed and the other has not. If he was not consuming the right amount of nutrients, both wounds would be healing slower.

B- this is correct. Facial wounds heal faster and scar less because they receive a better blood supply.

C- if his knee laceration still had a foreign body stuck in it, there would be no healing as the wound needs to be sterile to heal but the question states it was healing just slower

D- again this is a systemic factor. The answer should be looking for a local factor as one wound has healed and the other has not.

E- again this is a systemic factor. The answer should be looking for a local factor as one wound has healed and the other has not.

Question: Chemoreceptors are sensitive to changes in pH. Increased stimulation of chemoreceptors increases rate and depth of ventilation. What is the significance of a build up in hydrogen ions in the CSF compared to capillary blood?
OptionA: H+ ions are buffered by plasma proteins in capillary blood. There are no plasma proteins in the CSF and therefore it is more sensitive to a change in pH
OptionB: There is no build up of hydrogen ions in the CSF as they are not able to diffuse across the blood brain barrier. Therefore, if there is a build up of hydrogen ions in the CSF it is indicative of pathology
OptionC: Carbon dioxide is not able to diffuse across the blood brain barrier. Its reaction with water to form H2C03 and then HC03 + H+ does not occur in the CSF as it does in the capillary blood. Therefore if there is an increase in H+ ions in the CSF it is indicative of pathology.
Explanation:
A- correct answer 

charged ions and carbon dioxide are both able to move across the blood brain barrier. Both B and C are therefore incorrect.

Question: Sofia, 24, has recently had a biopsy taken from a scar that is still present 4 months post surgery as the doctors could not decide on observation alone what type of scar it was. The biopsy found her scar to be a keloid scar. Which of the following would the biopsy have shown for the doctors to be able to conclude this?
OptionB: Collagen fibres parallel to the skin's surafce
OptionE: You cannot distinguish between a keloid and hypertrophic scar from a biopsy
Explanation:
A- it is alpha smooth actin myofirboblasts and these would be present in a hypertrophic scar

B- present in a hypertrophic scar

C- correct :)

D- present in a hypertrophic scar

E- untrue you can distinguish

Question: Winston has recently been diagnosed with Rickets. What is he deficient in?
Explanation: Rickets is a vit D deficiency that leads to poor bone health & increased incidents of fractures

Question: Alec has been involved in some experimental drug trials. He was informed that the opioid analgesic he was being given, Remifentanil, was only experimental and likely to not show a promising effect. As a result, his analgesic benefit was significantly lower than others who partook in the trial but had the drug hyped up. Which of the following best explains the reasons for Alec's experience?
OptionA: His negative expectation stimulated activity in the hippocampus and amygdala, which are the negative pain systems and produced a negative emotion associated with the analgesic.
OptionB: He suffers from chronic stress which meant he already had a reduced pain threshold and so the analgesic effect was not as potent on him.
OptionC: His negative expectation stimulated activity in the PAG, the negative pain system, and produced a negative emotion associated with the analgesic.
OptionD: Alec had recently lost a close family member and his period of low mood was lowering his pain threshold so the analgesic effect was not as potent on him.
OptionE: His negative expectation made him experience the pain to be less controllable than the other participants who had the drug hyped up so the analgesic effect was not as potent on him.
Explanation:
While B, D and E are all valid reasons for why a pain threshold may be lower and hence less analgesic effect experienced, they are not the best options as A specifically looks at the negative expectation's effect on the brain.

C is not valid as the PAG is not a negative pain system.

Question: Dynasty has recently been on holiday and come back with significant sun burn. Which layer of the skin is responsible for providing UV protection?
Explanation: The stratum basal layer is responsible for providing UV irradiation protection

Question: You are reviewing a patient's skin biopsy when you discover a melanoma. From which layer of the skin is this melanoma likely to derive?
Explanation: A is the correct answer because melanomas develop from melanocytes which are found in the stratum basal layer. Melanocytes are most at risk of cancers because they trap UV energy that Is harmful to DNA.

Question: One of your patients has been using a steroid cream to treat some eczema on her neck. One of the side effects of topical steroid creams is thinning of the skin. Which of the following layers is responsible for giving the skin its strength and extensibility?
Explanation: The deeper reticular dermis is a layer of dense irregular connective tissue that gives the skin its strength & extensibility. From skin micro anatomy workbook answers, case 1.

Question: What antibody is allergen specific?
Explanation: IgE is allergen specific. IgE will bind to surface of mast cells, making them capable of recognising antigen in tissues instantaneously

Question: Which of these extrapyramidal (stereotyped movements) pathways is incorrectly described?
Explanation:
B - this describes rubrospinal pathways 

vestibulospinal is axial muscles and extensors

Question: CF mainly affects which body system/systems
Explanation:
Somebody with CF makes too much thick, sticky mucus. This blocks airway passages and makes them more prone to developing infection as the mucus is a good environment for bacteria to grow. The narrowed, inflammed airways make it more difficult to breath. 

The thick secretions also clog the ducts of the pancreas which blocks digestive enzymes and other secretions from the pancreas. This means that bowl movements are often foul smelling and bulky. 

information and question taken from https://www.urmc.rochester.edu/encyclopedia/content.aspx?ContentTypeID=40&ContentID=CysticFibrosisQuiz&CustomAnswers_CysticFibrosisQuiz=q1a5_c,q2a4_c,q3a5_c,q4a5_c,q5a5_c,q6a5_c,q7a5_c,q8a4_c,q9a3_c

Question: If there was a lumbar lesion with the spinothalamic tract where would the sensory deprivation be?
OptionA: sensory deprivation would be contralateral to the site of the lesion as the tract crosses immediately once entering the spinal cord and it would mean a loss of pain, temperature, simple touch
OptionB: sensory deprivation would be contralateral to the site of the lesion as the tract crosses immediately once entering the spinal cord and it would mean a discriminative touch, vibration and conscious proprioception
OptionC: the sensory deprivation would be ipsilateral to the lesion as it decussates in the medulla and it would mean a loss of pain, temperature and simple touch
OptionD: the sensory deprivation would be ipsilateral to the lesion as it decussates in the medulla and it would mean a loss of discriminative touch, vibration and conscious proprioception
OptionE: no effect as it does not decussate at all - this tract converts proprioceptive information from proprioceptive skeletal muscles and joints to the cerebellum
Explanation:
B - correctly describes spinothalamic decussation but the function here describes the dorsal column tract 

C - describes dorsal column decussation but spinothalamic function 

D - describes dorsal column tract 

E - this s the dorsal spinocerebellar tract which does not decussate at all
Tags: Nervous System, Neuroanatomy, Neuroscience, Noceiception, Nociception

Question: What form of compensation does the line A-B represent?
OptionA: Respiritory compensation through hyperventilation, decreasing the concentration of carbon dioxide
OptionB: Metabolic compensation, reducing the plasma concentratrion of HC03
OptionC: Respiritory compensation through hypoventilation, increasing the concentration of carbon dioxide
OptionD: Metabolic compensation, increasing the plasma concentration of HC03
Explanation:
In this context, metabolic means a primary change in HC03. This is chiefly controlled by the kidneys and the Pc02 is determined chiefly by the lungs.

Movement of the line from A- B is increasing the HC03 concentration, bringing the pH back towards normal value as PC02 is high (60mmHg) which lowers the pH.

Question: Arlo is being prescribed some pain relief for his shoulder injury. The doctor takes a full medical history to check for any contraindications. It appears Arlo has had a history of real impairment. Which of the following pain relief should he not be prescribed?
Explanation: Ibuprofen is contraindicated if you have gastric ulceration or a history of renal impairment

Question: Nia is looking into different pain relief options as she is currently taking Ibuprofen and it is not providing strong enough pain relief for her chronic back pain. Which of the following pain relief medication has been linked with the development Cushing's syndrome if taken chronically?
Explanation: Prednisolone has an ADR of Cushing's syndrome and immune suppression if taken chronically

Question: Gregory is currently in A&E with acute alcohol intoxication. He is complaining of a really significant headache and asking for pain relief to help. Which of the following pain relief medication is he contraindicated for?
Explanation: Paracetamol is contraindicated if you are in liver failure or acute alcohol intoxication (alcohol poisoning)

Question: Matilda has recently broken her right ulna bone in the diaphysis. What type of bone mostly makes up this region of the bone?
Explanation:
B-E are all just terms that mean the same thing- spongy bone, which is found in the ends of long bones

 

A is correct as cortical/compact bone is found in the shafts/diaphysis of long bones & makes up 80% of all bones

Question: A patient has presented at your GP surgery with numbness and tingling in their lower leg following an injury off their skateboard a couple of weeks ago. After a physical examination, you suspect there may be damage to the tibial nerve. What are the nerve roots of the tibial nerve?
Explanation: Tibial nerve roots are L4-S3
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of the lower limb, Nerve damage, Case 1

Question: A patient presenting with a heat arrhythmia has been admitted for an angiogram. Which coronary artery would most likely need to be investigated?
OptionA: Circumflex branch of the left coronary artery
OptionB: Marginal branch of the right coronary artery
OptionC: Left anterior descending branch of the left coronary artery
OptionD: Sinoatrial branch of the right coronary artery
OptionE: Posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery
Explanation: If someone is suffering with an arrhythmia, would need to investigate the sinoatrial branch to see if it is blocked as this branch supplies the SAN and AVN.

Question: Heart disease is one of the leading cause of death in women. Which of the following, concerning women and their experiences with cardiovascular disease, is most appropriate?
OptionA: Heart disease is typically less advanced and severe in women when they present for treatment.
OptionB: Women experience a less significant decline in quality of life after a heart disease diagnosis than men.
OptionC: Women are more likely to have higher social support than men following a heart disease diagnosis.
OptionD: Women are more likely to underutilise and drop out of cardiac rehabilitation programmes than men.
OptionE: Women are less likely to experience poor sleep after a heart disease diagnosis.
Explanation:
Why the following were incorrect;

 

A- Heart disease is typically MORE advanced and severe in women when they present for treatment.

B- Women experience a MORE significant decline in quality of life after a heart disease diagnosis than men.

C- Women are LESS likely to have higher social support than men following a heart disease diagnosis.

E- Women are MORE likely to experience poor sleep after a heart disease diagnosis.

Question:
NSAIDs are a collection of drugs that act to inhibit the COX enzymes of PGHS. They have 3 major effects:

ANTI INFLAMMATORY 

ANTI PYRETIC 

ANALGESIC 

What explanation briefly summarises NSAIDs ANTI PYRETIC effects?
OptionA: decrease prostaglandin production to A-delta and C fibres are no longer sensitised to noxious stimuli
OptionB: decreases PGE2 and PGI2 production so there is no vasodilation of vessels
OptionC: competes with arachidonic acid for the COX domain of PGHS
OptionD: acetylates a serine residue of the COX enzymes, chemically modifying the enzyme.
OptionE: inhibits the production of PGE2 so IL1 is not produced and prostaglandins are not released into the CNS, therefore having no effect on the hypothalamus
Explanation:
A = NSAIDs analgesic effects

B = NSAIDs anti-inflammatory effects 

C = MOA of ibuprofen

D = MOA of aspirin

 

E = NSAIDs antipyretic effects

PGE2 production is inhibited as NSAIDs bind to the COX enzymes of PGHS, preventing the formation of PGG2 and PGH2

IL1 releases prostaglandins into the CNS where they elevate the hypothalamic set point for temperature control, thus causing fever

 

explanation adapted from Rang and Dales Pharmacology

Question: Atherosclerosis is a disease in which fat is deposited under the epithelium in smooth muscle cells and this affects smooth muscle cells causing them to proliferate giving rise to atherosclerotic plaque. What happens to the phenotype of blood vessels whether is dysregulation of the order of smooth muscle cells?
OptionA: It changes from a contractile phenotype to a synthetic phenotype.
OptionB: It changes from a vascular phenotype to a contractile phenotype.
OptionC: It changes from a synthetic phenotype to a contractile phenotype.
OptionD: It changes from a synthetic phenotype to a vascular phenotype.
OptionE: The phenotype of blood vessels does not change.
Explanation:
contractile phenotype = blood vessels not growing but contract/relax

synthetic phenotype = blood vessels growing and we do not want BVs to be proliferating (unless cut) so when there is atherosclerosis, the fat deposition is taken up by macrophages and transformed into foam cells which release cytokine and growth factor that affect the smooth muscles cells, causing them to proliferate and creating an atherosclerotic plaque
Tags: Smooth Muscle, Blood Vessels, atherosclerosis, Case 2

Question: Regulation of vascular tone can be carried out by local and systemically. Which of the following means fo regulating vascular tone can be both a local and systemic factor?
OptionE: There is no overlap between local and systemic means of regulating vascular tone
Explanation:
Humoral control of regulating vascular tone includes chemical substances e.g. hormone and ions dissolved in the blood and this can be both systemic and local control

B- this is only local control

C- this is only systemic control

D- this is what neural control is and this is only systemic 

E- not true

Question: Thecal cells have receptors for LH. What do Thecal cells produce when LH binds to the receptor?
Explanation:
Thecal cells have receptors for LH which causes them to produce androstenedione, which is then converted to estrogen by granulosa cells

Granulosa cells produce progesterone and inhibin as well as estrogen 

FSH is produced by gonadatrophs in the anterior pituitary

Question: A medical student is reviewing their immunology notes and comes across an antibody which provides localised protection on mucous membranes but they cannot remember which antibody this is referring to. Which antibody is it?
Explanation:
IgM is the first immunoglobulin to be secreted in response to an infection. This antibody fixes complement but does not pass into fatal circulation 

The role of IgD in the immune system is largely unknown. 

IgE is the least abundant isotope and its main role is protection against helminths and certain protozoan parasites. 

IgG is the most abundant isotope in the blood serum and enhances phagocytosis of bacteria and viruses and fixes complement and passes to the metal circulation. 

 

IgA is the most commonly produced immunoglobulin in the body and provides localised protection on mucuous membranes and is transported across the interior of the cell vis transcytosis and found in secretions such as salvia, mucus and tears.

Question: Some people take aspirin as it can have protective effects against cardiovascular disease. Which of the following provides the best explanation as to why this is the case?
OptionA: Aspirin irreversibly blocks the COX domain in prostaglandin production to prevent the production of Thromboxane A2 ( a vasoconstrictor), allowing prostacyclin to take over
OptionB: Aspirin irreversibly blocks the COX domain in prostaglandin production to prevent the production of Prostaglandin D2 ( a vasoconstrictor), allowing prostacyclin to take over
OptionC: Aspirin irreversibly blocks the COX domain in prostaglandin production to prevent the production of Prostaglandin E2 ( a vasoconstrictor), allowing prostacyclin to take over
OptionD: Aspirin irreversibly blocks the COX domain in prostaglandin production to prevent the production of Prostaglandin F2 ( a vasoconstrictor), allowing prostacyclin to take over
OptionE: Aspirin reversibly blocks the COX domain in prostaglandin production to prevent the production of Prostaglandin D2 ( a vasoconstrictor), allowing prostacyclin to take over
Explanation:
A- correct

B- aspirin blocks the production of TXA2 not PGD2

C- aspirin blocks the production of TXA2 not PGE2. Also PGE2 is a vasodilator so you would not want to block its production if you were aiming to protect against CVD

D-aspirin blocks the production of TXA2 not PGF2

E- aspirin irreversibly blocks the COX domain
Tags: NSAIDS, Blood Vessels, Heart, coronary artery disease, Case 2

Question: Jane, 66, has been taking NSAIDs for a the past couple of years as she suffers with chronic back pain. She is becoming increasingly worried to continue taking NSAIDs daily as she has a history of heart disease in the family and has been informed that there is a well documented increased risk of cardiovascular events associated with the use of NSAIDs chronically. Which of the following best explains why this is the case?
OptionA: NSADIS inhibit prostacyclin production from the endothelium and so the balance in arteries favours PGD2, a vasoconstrictor, and thus promotes the likelihood of thrombosis through vasoconstriction of vascular smooth muscle cells and platelet aggregation.
OptionB: NSADIS inhibit PGI2 production from the endothelium and so the balance in arteries favours TXA2, a vasoconstrictor, and thus promotes the likelihood of thrombosis.
OptionC: NSADIS inhibit PGE2 production from the endothelium and so the balance in arteries favours PGD2, a vasoconstrictor, and thus promotes the likelihood of thrombosis through platelet aggregation.
OptionD: NSADIS inhibit prostacyclin production from the endothelium and so the balance in arteries favours TXA2, a vasoconstrictor, and thus promotes the likelihood of fat deposits.
OptionE: NSADIS inhibit PGI2 production from the endothelium and so the balance in arteries favours TXA2, a vasoconstrictor, and thus promotes the likelihood of thrombosis through vasoconstriction of vascular smooth muscle cells and platelet aggregation.
Explanation:
Why the following are incorrect;

 

Note- prostacyclin and PGI2 = same thing.


A- balance in arteries will favour TXA2 not PGD2

B- lacks the detail that E has 

C- NSAIDs inhibit PGI2/prostacyclin production, not PGE2, also balance in arteries will favour TXA2 not PGD2

D- promotes likelihood of thrombosis, not fat deposit 

E- correct :)

Question: Where does the Left ovarian vein drain?
Explanation:
The ovarian veins are asymmetrical. The right ovarian vein drains into the inferior vena cava but the left ovarian vein drains into the renal vein and then the inferior vena cava 

The ovarian arteries are branches of the abdominal aorta 

The vessels course through the suspensory ligament

Question: Patient X has recently undergone Transurethral Resection of the Prostate (TURP) surgery after being diagnosed with Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH), a noncancerous enlargement of the prostate. What zone of the prostate is most likely to be affected by BPH?
OptionE: They are all as likely as each other to be affected
Explanation: The correct answer is C - The Transitional Zone. TURP involves removing part of the prostate through the urethra using a cauterising loop. The procedure may result in retrograde ejaculation as there may be damage to the nerves or muscles (e.g. the internal urethral sphincter) surrounding the neck of the bladder.
Tags: Reproductive systems, Anatomy, genitourinary tract, Case 4, Male Anatomy

Question: Marsupian, 72, has a family history of heart disease and has recently been experiencing what he describes as a burning pain in his chest, which is brought on by physical exertion but relieved by rest. The chest sensation is occasionally accompanied by shortness of breath, nausea and sweating.  From this alone, what would you suspect Marsupian may be showing signs of?
Explanation:
Why the following are incorrect;

 

A- ACS is more serious than stable angina, it is when stable angina transitions to unstable angina and would be characterised by the chest pain at rest as well.

B- the symptoms of this are not described in the question

C- while he may have this, the symptoms in the question is not suggestive of this as much as it is for stable angina

D- while he may have this, the symptoms in the question is not suggestive of this as much as it is for stable angina

E- correct
Tags: Heart, coronary artery disease, Case 2, ischemia

Question: Gabe has recently been prescribed some beta blockers prophylactically to prevent the likelihood of the onset of a heart attack, however, he is finding they make him out of breathe really easily and his fingers and toes are always cold. Beta blockers can be selective for different sub-types of receptors. The beta blocker he has specifically been prescribed is Atenolol. Which subtype of receptor are atenolol beta blockers cardio selctive for?
Explanation: Atenolol beta blockers are cardio selective for Beta 1 receptors so they act to slow the heart rate, hence the rate limiting symptoms Gabe experienced.

Question:
Simple columnar epithelium of the endocervix transitions into non kertitanized stratisfied sqaumous epithelium of the ectocervix 

 

Before puberty, the epithelial transition occurs near the os. However, enlargement of the uterus and cervix during puberty cause the endocervical mucosa to evert, resulting in a transitional zone of columnar epithelium on the outer surface of the cervix. What is this called?
Explanation:
Ectropian is the process described above. The enlargement of the cervix due to puberty or pregnancy causes cells of the endocervix are present on the outside surface of the cervix 

The area where the soft cells meet the squamous epithelial cells (hard cells), which are thosefound on the outer surface of the cervix, is called the transformation zone

The site of epithelial change seems to predisposes this area to malignant transformation 

Nabothian cysts are most often caused when squamous epithelium of the ectocervix grows over the simple collumnar epithelium of the endocervix 

 

http://www.siumed.edu/~dking2/erg/cervix.htm

Question: ACE inhibitors, such as Ramipril, are used as a drug intervention for treating hypertension. What effect do ACE inhibitors have specifically on the cardiac system?
OptionD: They indirectly block Na+ uptake by blocking ACE
OptionE: ACE inhibitors only act on he kidneys and do not affect the cardiac system
Explanation:
ACE inhibitors limit LV remodelling.

 

A- limits LV not RV remodelling

B- valid but this is effect on vascular not cardiac system

C- valid but this is effect on kidneys

E- untrue

Question: Apibaxan is a direct acting oral anticoagulant drug (DOAC) given if a patient is at an increased risk of clotting. Which of the following does Apibaxan inhibit?
Explanation: Apibaxan is a highly selective irreversible inhibitor of factor Xa- prevent conversion of prothrombin to thrombin as thrombin is the terminal step in clot formation. From pharmacology lightbulb case 2 :)

Question: Harmful blood clots can cause heart attacks, strokes, deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Some drugs aimed at preventing this can be anticoagulant or anti platelet drugs which prevent the formation of a clot or fibrinolytic drugs which dissolve an existing clot. Which of the following is a fibrinolytic drug?
Explanation:
Why the following are wrong;

 

A- anti-coagulant DOAC drug

C- anti platelet drug

D- anti-hypertensive or symptom relieving drugs 

E- anti coagulant drug

 

From pharmacology lightbulb case 2 :)

Question: A T wave inversion can at times be seen on an ECG in patients experiencing NSTEMI heart attacks. However, not all signs of T wave inversion are pathological. In which ECG lead may you see T wave inversion that is not pathological?
OptionD: T wave inversion is pathological on any ECG lead, unless in a paediatric patient.
Explanation: Although T wave inversion is not always pathological in paediatric patients, it can also not be pathological in aVR leads. From Dr Coffey's ECG E learning, case 2.

Question: When investigating acute coronary heart syndromes, an ECG may be required, to look for signs such as an ST elevation or depression. Which ECG leads does the left anterior descending artery correspond to?
Explanation:
LAD corresponds to leads V1-V4. Notes from Case 2 lecture of percutaneous investigations and treatment of stable angina. 

 

A- this is only proximal LCA

C- this is RCA

D & E made up

Question: Which of the following arteries would be considered a good conduit for a coronary artery bypass graft as a result of its high production of nitrous oxide and prostacyclin giving it a high patency?
Explanation:
The internal mammary artery is considered the best conduit for CABG due to its extremely high patency as a result of the following characteristics;

  • high production of prostacyclin and NO which induce vasodilation and inhibit platelet aggregation
  • thin medial layer with little smooth muscle

Question: Which antibiotic would be appropriate for the treatment of moderate mycoplasma infection?
Explanation:
A, B C and D are beta lactam antibiotics (penecillins and cephalosporins). Their MOA is inhibiting cell wall synthesis through binding to one or more Penicillin Binding Proteins. They therefore will not be effective against mycoplasma, as this is a genus of bacteria that lack a cell wall 

Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that works through inhibiting protein synthesis.

Question: Some bacteria express beta lactamase, which can cleave the beta lactam ring of cephalosporins and penicillins, inactivating these antibitoics. What can be used in combindation with these antibitoics to overcome this form of resistance?
Explanation:
Clavulanic acid mimics the structure of beta lactams, inhibiting the beta lactamase and thereby allowing the beta lactam to do its job. Though this is not synergism, as clavulanic acid does not have an antibacterial effect, it is a very useful combination which is frequently prescribed 

co-amoxiclav for example, which is amoxicillin and clavulanic acid 

 

Cell wall inhibitors can be prescribed synergistically along with aminoglycoside (protein synthesis inhibitors) and fluroquinolones (inhibit DNA replication). The cell wall inhbitors weaken the wall allowing the aminoglycosides and fluroquinolones to exert greater effect 

Rifampicin is an example of fluroquinolon 

gentamycin is an example of a aminoglycoside

Question: A patient comes in and their condition can be described as follows: hypertrophy of the submucosal glands and increased number of goblet cells and music-ciliary dysfunction leading to mucus hypertension and retention and this inability to clear the mucus blocks the airway and means it is more likely to become infected. The patient has a productive cough and an inflamed airway. Which condition does the describe?
Explanation:
A - emphysema will cause alveolar wall destruction and over inflation where the elastic is degraded and this leads to hyper inflation of the alveoli and destruction of the walls and a loss of lung elasticity. 

D- COPD is a way of categorising the obstructive disorders of chronic bronchitis and emphysema which are usually caused by smoking. 

E - asthma is a reversible obstruction which is triggered by allergens or infection and which causes bronchial hyper responsiveness

Question: Romeo comes into the A and E after coming out in a rash immediately after taking a single dose of penicillin. What type of adverse drug reaction is Romeo suffering from?
Explanation:
Type A adverse drug reactions are predictable and dose dependent. An example of this is gentamicin that is toxic to the Kidneys in high concentrations 

Type B adverse drug reactions are unpredictable, often immune related and include allergic reactions, in Romeos case, to penicllin. 

Type C These are effects that require a prolonged period of exposure to develop. Romeo came out in a rash after a single dose 

Type D These are effects that do not arise until a prolonged period after exposure. Romeo came out in a rash immediately 

Type E- These are effects seen on medicine withdrawal. Again, Romeo has taken a single dose of penicillin (not over a prolonged period and then stopped his mediciation) 

http://www.knowledge.scot.nhs.uk/ecomscormplayer/ADRmodule2/9-other-types.html#panel1

Question:
Miss Y visits her gynecologist with discomfort during urination, discharge with an unusual fishy smell and soreness of the genitals. Her doctor performs a colposcopy and it is found that she has a straberry cervix. She is treated with metronidazole. Based on the information,

what is Miss Y diagnosis?
Explanation: All of the listed STI present with discharge. All the listed options also present with pain and burning wilst urinating. A UTI is less likely as discharge is not a common presentation. The most distringuishing factor is the stawberry cervix; strawberry cervix is almost always a sign of trichomoniasis

Question: Creatinine is a natural substance that is used to estimate GFR. What mechanism means that creatinine clearence overestimates GFR?
OptionA: Creatinine is secreted by the Proximal tubule
OptionC: Creatinine is reabsorbed at the proximal tubule
Explanation:
A small component of the excreted creatinine is secreted by the PCT and therefore creatinine clearence overestimates GFR function at low renal blood flow. The diagram shows that around GFR function can be reduced to around 75% before serum creatinine sufficiently increases. This is because , until this point, the Kidney are able to compensate (partly through PCT secreting creatinine) 

 

If creatinine was reabsorbed (which is not the case) then its function would be an underestimation.

Question: Which one of the listed features would not be apparent in a peak flow of someone with COPD
OptionC: no great improvement in lung volumes with corticosteroids
Explanation:
The gold standard for measuring COPD is spirometry rather than peak flow. However, peak flow diagram for a patient with COPD will not show a great deal of variability and will have consistently low lung volumes. This is more of a feature present in somebody with poorly controlled asthma 

 

There will not be much improvement with corticosteroids. COPD is an irreversible limitation to airflow.  Again, this is a feature of someone with asthma. In Asthma, there is a reversible limitation to airflow caused by inflammation of the airways in response to relatively benign environmental antigens.

Question: The respiratory system has a number of different specialised cells which perform specific functions. One such cell is the Clara Cell, what is the function of this cell?
OptionA: Cells with thin, flattened nuclei that contribute towards the efficient air-blood barrier in the lung
OptionB: Present in the bronchus and secretes lipoproteins which prevent luminal adhesion should the airway collapse.
OptionC: Composed of phospholipid and glycosaminoglycans which form the basis of pulmonary surfactant.
OptionD: Allow the stretch and recoil properties of the lung, allowing the accomodation of air movement, preventing alveolar and bronchiolar collapse.
Explanation:
A: incorrect, this describes the function of Type 1 Pneumocytes 

B: correct :)

C: incorrect, describes the function of Type 2 Pneumocytes 

D: incorrect, this describes property of elastin, despite similar prevention of collapse clara cells do not facilitate stretch and recoil properties

Question: Ischaemic heart disease is caused by an inequality between oxygen supply and demand. Which of the following could lead to IHD through as a result of increased oxygen demand?
Explanation: A-D can cause IHD but they do so through decreased oxygen supply rather than increased oxygen demand. Thyrotoxicosis is a high output state as a result of increased thyroid hormone (hyperthyroidism) that increases the work of the heart.

Question: Typical risk factors for ischeamic heart disease include smoking, type 2 diabetes, age and hypertension. However, there are also non-traditional risk factors for IHD. Which of the following is a non-traditional risk factor for IHD?
Explanation:
A- not a risk factor for IHD

B- this is a risk factor for IHD but it is a traditional risk factor

C-this is a risk factor for IHD but it is a traditional risk factor

D- correct. There is evidence that people with chronic inflammatory conditions have an increased risk of IHD. COPD is also a non traditional risk factor.

E- not a risk factor for IHD

Question: Atherosclerosis is a disease of the arteries characterised by the deposition of fatty acids. Which of the following lipoproteins is reposnsible for transporting triglycerides from the gut to the liver?
Explanation: Chylomicrons transport triglycerides from the gut to the liver. They are involved in the first stage of the exogenous pathway of lipid transport.
Tags: Lipids and cardiovascular disease, atherosclerosis, Heart, Case 2

Question: Katie presents to A & E with the following symptoms; dyspnoea, cyanosis, tachycardia and a sharp, stabbing chest pain that radiates to the shoulder. She is diagnosed with pneumothorax (collapsed lung) and James, the F1 doctor tries to explain why this has happened. He says that it is due to an imbalance of pressures in the lungs. Can you help provide more detail to this explanation?
OptionA: Pneumothroax is caused by an excess of air entering the alveolar space, increasing intrapulmonary pressure meaning the lungs cannot expand as much on inspiration.
OptionB: Pneumothorax is caused by air entering the intrapleural space, therefore causing the intrapleural pressure to become less negative, rising towards atmospheric pressure. Therefore the lung collapses.
OptionC: Pneumothroax is caused by decreased air in the intrapleural space, intrapleural pressure therefore decreases so the lung collapses in on itself.
Explanation: B: correct, increased pressure means the lung can no longer expand as much. Air would be removed using a chest drain or needle aspiration.

Question: Statins can sometimes be prescribed to help lower the levels of cholesterol in people with high risks of heart attacks and heart disease. Which of the following stages, in the synthesis of cholesterol, do statins inhibit?
OptionA: Conversion of acetyl coA to HMG CoA
Explanation: The enzyme that converts HMG CoA to Mevalonate is HMG CoA reductase and this is the enzyme which statins competitively inhibit to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease.

Question: Atherosclerosis arises from lipid deposition within the coronary arteries. Which of the following is the correct order of decreasing density of these lipoproteins?
Tags: Lipid classification, Lipids and cardiovascular disease, atherosclerosis, Heart, Case 2

Question:
Does the following description indicate obstructive or restrictive lung disease?

"Lungs are forced from fully expanding due to stiffness in the lungs so there is difficulty INHALING"
Explanation: This is restrictive, for example in pulmonary fibrosis, obesity or sarcoidosis. FEV1 and FVC are both equally reduced due to fibrosis, so less air can be expelled in one second as there is restricted expansion of the alveoli as they are more rigid and stiff so it is harder to get air in as well. There is also a reduction in lung volume and capacity.

Question:
Does the following description show restrictive or obstructive lung disease? 

"Shortness of breath due to difficulty EXHALING due to damage or narrowing of the airways, air moves out slower than usual and a high volume of air remains in the lungs"
Explanation:
Obstructive is the answer, i.e. COPD or Asthma causes obstruction in the airways, there is a  reduction in both FEV1 and FVC but FEV1 is severely reduced because the patient find it extremely difficult to blow air past the obstruction so it is harder to blow a high volume of air out in 1 second. 

 

This reduction in airflow means air remains in the lung after expiration leading to hyperinflation of the lungs, increasing residual volume and consequently an increased total lung capacity.

Question: Elizabeth visits the GP for advice surrounding contraception. Together, you decide that the pill is most appropriate. You ask Elizabeth if she has a family history of breast cancer, to which she reveals she does. Based on the available information, which pill would be most appropriate?
Explanation:
The combined pill is contraindicated for patients who have a history of breast cancer (as Elizabeth revealed). This is because in breast cancer, some forms of the malignancy are fuelled by estrogen.  Therefore, the POP pill would be most appropriate. 

There are no estrogen only pills. This is because chronic/high dose oestrogen on its own risks a patient safety. To get effective contraception from high oestrogen dosing alone would significantly increase the risk of thrombo-embolic events in the patient because of the effect oestrogen has on the generation of blood clotting factors (information taken from Dr Coffey answered questions on learning central). Even if there was such a thing, estrogen is contraindicated to patients with a history of breast cancer and so this would not be appropriate 

Both ethinylestradiol and levonorgestrel are examples of the combined pill

Question: In the lungs, it is important to match the ventilation perfusion ratio (V:Q), if it is at 1 then there is balance between the two factors. When the V:Q is 0, what has happened within the lungs?
OptionC: This is the ratio in the dead space of the lungs
Explanation:
A: Pulmonary emboli impairs gas exchange, blood is diverted away despite airflow still remaining the same so the O2 pp is reduced and there is increased CO2, therefore the ratio would not be 0 it would be slightly lower than 1

 

B: this is correct, right to left shunting occurs (pulmonary shunt) meaning that ventilation fails to supply the perfused region so the ratio of air reaching the alveoli to blood perfusing them is zero. 

 

C: this is where V:Q is infinity:Q because there is no blood flow therefore there is no interface for gas exchange but plenty of ventilation, this is not efficient.

Question: A rise in pCO2 can be detected by central chemoreceptors, which are designed to detect changes in pH of the CSF and this rise is the main drive to breathe. A buffering system occurs, but what is the best way to describe this mechanism?
OptionA: Very sensitive to changes in the blood chemistry, decreased pO2 causes increase fiurig and can respond rapidly due to detecting oscillations during breathing so can work to increase minute ventilation.
OptionB: Increased CO2 reacts with H2O to form H2CO3 in the capillary, CO2 diffuses across blood brain barrier to CSF where the same reaction can occur, extra H+ in capillary are buffered but these ions cannot be buffered in the CSF therefore pH changes more in CSF so there is increased rate of ventilation and depth of breathing detected by the central receptors here.
Explanation: A: incorrect, this occurs as a result of peripheral receptors i.e. in carotid and aortic artereis which are exposed directly to blood and have areas of high flow rate so are very sensitive to changes in blood chemistry

Question: A 40-year-old lady underwent an attempted placement of a central line into the internal jugular vein. Unfortunately, the doctor damaged the carotid artery and this necessitated surgical exploration. As the surgeons incise the carotid sheath a nerve is identified lying between the internal jugular vein and the carotid artery. Which one of the following is this nerve most likely to be?
Explanation: The vagus lies in the carotid sheath. The hypoglossal nerve crosses the sheath, but does not lie within it
Tags: Cranial nerve, Anatomy, Nervous System, Neuroanatomy

Question:
A 25-year-old male is admitted to a neurology ward following a loss of sensation in his lower limbs when lifting a heavy crate at work. The patient has an MRI that reveals damage to the anterior spinothalamic tract following disc herniation.

 

Which of the following modalities is affected by damage to this tract?
Explanation:
The anterior spinothalamic tract carries course (crude) touch

 

Pain and temperature is carried out by the lateral spinothalmic tract.

Fine touch and vibration are carried by the dorsal column tracts

Question: A 50-year-old man presents with unilateral hyperacousia. Where is the nerve lesion most likely to be?
Explanation: Damage to the facial nerve in the bony canal may result in imparied innervation to stapedius and therefore sounds are no longer dampened

Question: A student is investigating common causes of upper respiratory tract infections which are infections above the larynx. Which of the following is not a common cause?
Explanation:
A is an infection of the pleural lining and is a common cause of lower respiratory tract infections along with bronhiolitis, acute bronchitis, infective exacerbations of COPD and asthma and pneumonia. 

The rest are correct and sinusitis which is common in chronic respiratory conditions can also be a common cause of upper respiratory tract infections.

Question: Josie falls on her knee whilst running and rubs it to help the pain. Why does this help?
OptionA: stimulates a delta fibres so inhibits pain
OptionB: stimulates a beta fibres so 'gate' closes in substantia genitosa before any other pain signals can get there
OptionC: rubbing builds up the amount of substance P inhibiting the pain response
OptionD: stimulates c  fibres so 'gate' closes in substantia genitosa before any other pain signals can get there
OptionE: stimulates a deltaso 'gate' closes in substantia genitosa before any other pain signals can get there
Explanation: when rubbing the knee there is excitation along A beta fibres. excitations run fastest along these fibres So Gate closes before pain signals fro c fibres and a delta fibres reach the brain

Question: Zac burns his finger stimulating sensory receptors in his finger to synapse with neurones in the brain. What neurotransmitter is released?
Explanation: glutamate is the main neurotransmitter released by nociceptors

Question: Cor Pulmonale can be caused by a number of different reasons, one primary cause is in chronic lung disease when there is regional hypoxic vasoconstriction, diverting blood away from specific areas of the alveoli. Describe what might happen to the heart following regional hypoxic vasoconstriction.
OptionA: Vasoconstriction within the lung raises lung blood pressure causing pulmonary hypertension, this means that the right ventricle has to pump against a higher pressure to allow blood to reach the lungs. Therefore the right side of the heart can undergo hypertrophy, possible leading to right sided heart failure.
OptionB: Vasoconstriction within the lung raises lung blood pressure causing pulmonary hypertension, this means that the left ventricle has to pump against a higher pressure. Therefore the left side of the heart can undergo hypertrophy, possible leading to left sided heart failure.
OptionC: Vasoconstriction within the lung decreases lung blood pressure causing pulmonary hypotension. Therefore the right side of the heart can undergo dilation, leading to right ventricular remodelling.
OptionD: Vasoconstriction within the lung decreases lung blood pressure causing pulmonary hypotension. Therefore the right side of the heart can undergo dilation, leading to left ventricular remodelling.
Explanation: A is the correct answer, right sided heart failure causes blood to become backlogged in the systemic circulation as there is an increased AFTERLOAD therefore leading to peripheral oedema, increased CVP leading to an elevated JVP. The initial hypoxia could be caused by FIBROSIS which can reduce the compliance/ventilation in the lungs.
Tags: Respiration, Respiratory Physiology, Heart, Case 2, Case 3

Question:
Mr Jones is a 70 year old patient who presents to A&E with severe dyspnea, central and peripheral cyanosis, confusion and drowsiness. He explains wearily that some of the symptoms have been present for a while but he thought they were just exasperated signs of his COPD, however now he is more worried as he is increasingly fatigued. 

Alex, the F1 doctor, performs a respiratory exam and notices signs of "hand flap" when the patient holds his hands up and he also performs an arterial blood gas and obtains the following readings: 

pO2- 7kPa

pCO2- 8kPa 

What type of respiratory failure can Alex deduce is present from these readings?
Explanation:
Type 2 Respiratory Failure is present because there is HYPOXAEMIA (O2 levels should be 11-13kPa) and HYPERCAPNIA (CO2 levels should be 3-5kPa). So alveolar ventilation is insufficient to excrete the volume of CO2 being produced by tissue metabolism. There is reduced ventilatory effort or inability to overcome increased resistance to ventilation causing hypoventilation. Treatment could include immediate ventilation, likely overnight. 

 

Type 1 Resp failure is when there is an issue with oxygenation, so there is only hypoxaemia therefore low levels of pO2 and normal/low pCO2 levels. This could occur if there is a V/Q mismatch, diffusion deficit,  decreased O2 consumption or hypoventilation. 

 

Not looking at pH in this instance although it would be affected and the conditions would be linked to acidosis however this is not what the question is asking.

Question: Respiratory acidosis can occur due to Acute Type 2 Respiratory Failure. It can cause symptoms such as hypoventilation (leading to hypoxia), drowsiness, disorientation, muscle weaknesses and rapid, shallow respirations. What would the pH and arterial gas readings be in this condition?
OptionA: High pH, low pCO2, slightly low HCO3
OptionB: Low pH, high pCO2, elevated HCO3 over time
OptionD: High pH, slightly high pCO2, high HCO3
Explanation:
A: respiratory alkalosis 

B is correct as there is metabolic compensation that occurs over days to excrete H+ ions and retain HCO3 due to the failure in ventilation. 

C: metabolic acidosis 

D: metabolic alkalosis

Question: Which of the following is not a feature of respiratory alkalosis?
Explanation:
Respiratory depression or hypoventilation is a feature of respiratory acidosis. Vomiting and dehydration are symptoms which are associated with patents with metabolic alkalosis. 

The increased availability of calcium ions in respiratory alkalosis can replace the lost hydrogen ions which can result in tetany and paraesthesia due to over excitability of the neurones. It can result from a panic attack which may be caused by hyperventilation and hence the low partial pressure of carbon dioxide.
Tags: Lung function, Case 3, acids and bases

Question: An aortic dissection can result from a tear in the intimal layer of the aorta. The pain is typically characterised as a severe tearing pain in the chest. Aortic dissections can propagate proximally and distally. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of a proximally propagated aortic dissection into the coronary Ostia?
Explanation:
A- this is from a proximally propagated aortic dissection into the aortic valve

B correct :)
C- this is from an external rupture of a distally propagated aortic dissection

D- this is from branch occlusion of a distally propagated aortic dissection

E- this is from pericardial rupture of a distally propagated aortic dissection

Question: Damascus, 17, has recently had a viral infection, Mumps. He presents to you with the persistent flu-like illness symptoms, fever, night sweats and significantly, a sharp stabbing chest pain when he lies down, bends over and on deep inspiration with a pulsation of the heart. He is also short of breath. Which of the following, based solely of this information, is the most probable diagnosis?
Explanation:
A- unlikely due to age

B - pain would be of a ripping/tearing sensation

C- correct. acute idiopathic pericarditis occurs sporadically in young adults and approx 50% are viral, i.e. from the Mumps he had

D- different presentation

E- wouldn't explain heart chest pain

Question: Emphysema and Chronic Bronchitis are conditions which fall under the label of COPD, but what are the major differences between them?
OptionA:
Emphysema is where the alveoli have a loss of elastic recoil, leading to hyperinflation so lungs fail to ventilate properly. This leads to symptoms such as dyspnoea, productive cough, wheeze and oedema.

Bronchitis occurs when there is reversible airway hyperresponsiveness, likely caused by an inappropriate immune response. Further inflammation can be caused by the mucus causing further infection.
OptionB:
Emphysema is where the alveoli have a loss of elastic recoil, leading to hyperinflation so lungs fail to ventilate properly. This leads to symptoms such as dyspnoea, productive cough, wheeze and oedema. 

 

Bronchitis occurs when there is hypersecretion of mucus, therefore is inflammation of larger airways so there is a chronic, productive cough. Further inflammation can be caused by the mucus causing further infection.
OptionC:
Emphysema is where the alveoli have a loss of elastic recoil, leading to hyperinflation so lungs fail to ventilate properly. This leads to symptoms such as dyspnoea, productive cough, wheeze and oedema.

Bronchitis occurs when there is impaired Cl- transport so dehydration of epthelial cell surfaces, there is thick mucus production in lungs and GI tract.
OptionD:
Emphysema is where the alveoli have a loss of elastic recoil, leading to hyperinflation so lungs fail to ventilate properly. This leads to symptoms such as dyspnoea, productive cough, wheeze and oedema.
