OptionC: Dorsal column tract and spinothalamic tract are damaged. The lateral corticospinal tract bypasses the hemisection
OptionD: The spinothalamic tract is damaged. The lateral corticospinal and dorsal column tract bypass the hemisection
OptionE: The lateral corticospinal tract is damaged. The spinothalamic and dorsal column tract bypass the hemisection
Explanation:
The lateral corticospinal tract and dorsal column tract are damaged. The spinothalamic tract bypasses the hemisection. The reason for this is that the dorsal column pathway ascends ipsilateral to the sensation, so it would be damaged the same way as the lateral corticospinal tract. The spinothalamic pathway decussates immediately upon entering the spinal cord and ascends contralateral to the source; it would therefore bypass the hemisection.

https://open.oregonstate.education/aandp/chapter/14-5-sensory-and-motor-pathways/

Question: Which vessel does the right ovarian vein drain into?
Explanation: The venous drainage of the ovaries is not symmetrical. The right ovarian vein drains into the inferior vena cava and the left ovarian vein drains into the left renal vein.
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of reproductive system, Blood Vessels, PCS 3, Case 4

Question: Eliza presents to the sexual health clinic as she is experiencing dysuria. After having a few tests she is told she has chlamydia and is given a course of antibiotics. The bacterium that causes chlamydia is chlamydia trachomatis and requires specific antibiotics as it is an obligate intracellular pathogen. Which of the following antibiotcs would be suitable?
Explanation:
Azithromycin is the correct answer.

Azithromycin is a macrolide and is often used in patients who are allergic to penicillins, as well as chlamydia infections. They can have both bacteriostatic and bactericidal effects as they bind to the 50S ribosomal subunit causing protein synthesis to be inhibited.

This is from the Case 4 pharmaclogy lightbulb.
Tags: Sexually transmitted disease, antibiotics, Case 4, microbiology, sexual health

Question: A patient has come into A and E and is found that they have suffered Lower Motor Neurone damage to the accessory nerve. What would you expect to observe as a result of this?
OptionA: Weakness shrugging shoulders on the contralateral side and weakness turning head on the contralteral side
OptionB: Weakness shrugging shoulders on the ipsilateral side and weakness turning heald on the contralateral sid
OptionC: Weakness shrugging shoulders on the contralateral side and weakness turning head on the ipsilateral side
OptionD: Weakness shrugging shoulders on the ipsilateral side and weakness turning head on the ipsilateral side
Explanation:
The accessory nerve provides motor innervation to the trapezius muscle and the sternocleidomastoid. 

upper motor neurone imput to the LMN of the accessory nerve is through the corticobulbar tract. 

input through the corticobulbar tract to the LMN for the sterncleidomastoid is ipsilateral; input through the corticobulbar tract to the LMNs of the trapezius is contralateral 

If there was an UMN leision of the accessory nerve then there would be weakness of the trapezius muscle (shoulder shrugging) on the contralateral side and weakness of the sternocleidomastoid (head turning) on the ipsilateral side 

If there was a LMN leision of the accessory nerve then there would be both weakness of the trapezius muscle and sternocleidomastoid on the ipsilateral side

Question: Waardenburgs syndrome may present with cochlear deafness. Which ion secretion is compromised that influences the endocochlear potential?
Explanation:
The cells that control the K+ secretion in the stria vascularis fail to migrate to the tissue during development. This leads to deafness as there is no endocochlear potential 

The perilymph of the scala vestibuli and scala tympani has a high concentration of the Na+. The endolymph of the scala media has a high concentration of potassium.

Question:
Mrs Jones, 45, is having trouble hearing people during conversation and her husband persuades her to see her GP. Her GP performs the Weber and Rinne tests and concludes that Mrs Jones has some degree of sensi-neuronal hearing loss in her right ear. 

Which of the following could be a possible cause of sensi-neuronal hearing loss?
OptionA: blockage of the ear canal due to excessive wax
Explanation:
A, B, C and E all occur in the outer or middle ear and are possible causes of CONDUCTIVE hearing loss.

A = prevents sound from effectively reaching the tympanic membrane

B = inflammation of the middle ear usually with fluid build up behind the tympanic membrane

C = occurs on tympanic membrane between outer and middle ear

E = affects the ossicles in the middle ear

 

D is correct. A vestibulocochlear Schwannoma is a tumour of the Scwann cells surrounding the vestibulocohclear nerve (it is often benign). This a potential cause of SENSI-NEURONAL hearing loss as it directly affects sending signals from the ear to the brain.

Question:
Mr Smith, 84, was diagnosed with Alzheimer's Disease a year ago. He continues to live independently but his daughter persuades him to see his GP as she notices significant changes in his personality and behaviour. She is very concerned and tells the GP "he is not himself anymore".

Which part of the brain is most likely to be responsible for Mr Smith's changes in personality?
Explanation:
A: temporal lobe plays a function in facial recognition, language and memory

B: frontal lobe plays a role in problem solving, behaviour, emotions and personality 

C: hippocampus plays a role in consolidation of short term memory to long term memory

D: parietal lobe plays a role in perception, recognising objects, visuospacial processing and recognising numbers

E: amygdala plays a role in emotional responses and processing and consolidating memory

Question: Mrs Jones, 82, has just undertaken the Addenbrooke’s cognitive exam. You are reviewing her results and find that she has scored very low in verbal fluency and naming to description. Based of the available information, what may be an appropriate assumption for her diagnosis?
Explanation:
Verbal fluency tests semantic memory. 

though there are declines in declarative episodic and working memory in normal aging, a decline in semantic memory is pathological 

Semantic memory impairment suggests that the disease has progressed

With patients who are 82 < , the tests provides 100% specifity (true negative) for dementia

Question: Which weber classification of fracture is least likely to require surgical intervention?
OptionB: Type B (fracture of the fibula at the level of the syndesmosis)
OptionC: Typce C (fracture of the fibula above the level of the syndesmosis)
Explanation:
syndesmosis = fibrous ligament which joins bones 

The more proximal the fibular injury the less stable the tibiofibular joint and the more likely surgical intervention is required (elearning on learning central) 

Type A fracture is a fracture to the lateral malleolus which is distal the tibiofibula syndesmosis, leaving the syndesmosis in tact. It its therefore ususally more stable and can be managed with simple measure such as a plaster of paris cast 

Type B fracture is at the level of the syndesmosis, meaning that it is probably torn. It is more likely to require operative intervention 

Type C is a fracture of the fibula proximal to the syndesmosis. Syndesmosis is interupted as there is a widening of the distal tibiofibular articulation.

Question: Frontotemporal dementia involves apathy developing and changes in personality. Which description below correctly refers to the role of the frontal lobe?
OptionD: executive functions, thinking, planning, organising, emotions and behavioural control
OptionE: perception, making sense of the world, spelling and arithmetic
Explanation:
A - motor cortex 

B - sensory cortex 

C - temporal  lobe 

E - parietal lobe

Question: Why is an occulomtor palsy with a dilated pupil a worrying clinical sign?
OptionE: may have a posterior communication artery aneurysm
Explanation:
A - thalamic tumours characterised by headache, nausea, vomiting, weakness on one side of the body, hormone imbalances 

B - intrinsic nerve damage such as through diabetes is less likely to affect the parasympathetic fibres

C - intracranial pressure is caused by the fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cord or due to raises in pressure of the brain itself. Can be caused by bleeding in the brain/ fluid , or swelling of the brain itself 

D- vision lost when optic nerve is damaged 

 

A posterior communicating artery aneurysm is a typical source of compression fo the CN III
Tags: Case 5, Clinical, Clinical relevance of anatomy

Question: Which type of fracture would require immediate disinfection?
Explanation:
Explanation
a) Comminuted fracture is when the bone splinters into two or more fragments, doesn’t necessarily break the skin, cannot be assumed it needs disinfection
b) Another name for a compound fracture is an OPEN fracture – this breaks the skin, allowing pathogens an entry route.
c) Pathological fracture is an abnormal weakness in the bone – Like osteoporosis – Not necessarily caused by a pathogen, therefore not the BEST answer.
d) Simple fracture is a fracture of the bone ONLY – no damage to surrounding tissue or skin.

Question: Which stage in fracture healing will result in the most VEGF release and stem cell proliferation?
Explanation:
a) Haematoma: Blood vessels tear, no VEGF release, that would be silly
b) Inflammation: Vasodilation YES, but no stem cell proliferation
c) Granulation: Formation of new capillaries AND stem cells proliferate into fibroblasts, chondrocytes and osteoclasts
d) Soft callus: Vascularised granulated tissue has been formed BUT all the necessary cells are already at the site, therefore no more stem cell production

Question:
Which hormone is responsible for osteoclast apoptosis regulation, therefore what are the results of a deficiency in this hormone?

Leading to decreased bone density and increase risk of primary osteoporosis
Explanation: Oestrogen: Reduced levels of oestrogen (typically as a result of menopause) can increase the ratio of osteoclasts: osteoblasts.
Tags: Sex hormones, Bone health, Case 1, osteoporosisrosis

Question: Which hormone acts on the kidneys to stimulate the release of calcitriol when blood serum levels of calcium are low?
Explanation: Calcitriol: derived from vitamin D, stimulates the intestines to increase calcium and phosphorus absorption?

Question: Which of the following options correctly identifies the function of CXCL8?
OptionC: Induces the differentiation of CD4 T cells into T-helper-1 cells
OptionD: Recruitment of neutrophils, basophils and T cells to site of infection
Explanation: From case 1 lecture on basic acute immunology, relevance to wound healing

Question: What is the role of the complement protein C3b when fighting pathogens?
OptionA: Binds to pathogen cell membranes, causing lysis
OptionD: Neutralises the toxins produced by the pathogen
Explanation: C3b: Important opsonisation effect through tagging the pathogen, making phagocytosis easier

Question: After the formation of granulation tissue through collagen deposition, fibroblasts differentiate into myofibroblasts. What is the role of myofibroblasts?
OptionA: To clear any remaining debris caused by damaged tissue
OptionC: To contract against the collagen, pulling the wound together
OptionD: To release ant-inflammatory cytokines, stopping the release of collagen.
Explanation:
a) Removal of debris is mainly down to neutrophils
b) The cell type that secretes keratin is called keratinocyte – These cells are involved in the formation of granulation tissue.
c) Myofibroblasts stick to the ECM and the actin inside contract against the collagen – Pulling the side of the wound together.
d) The release of anti-inflammatory cytokines is done by macrophages once they have engulfed a ‘full’ neutrophil.

Question: A deficiency in clotting factor VIII, is a sex-linked genetic disorder and increases bleed time. Which type of clotting disorder is being described?
Explanation:
a) Correct: Effects CF VIII and is sex linked
b) Effects CF IX and is sex-linked
c) Effects CF XI and is autosomal recessive, not sex-linked
d) VWF BINDS to CF VIII, therefore the problem is not with the deficiency of clotting factor but with the deficiency of VWF.
e) Effects factors 2,7, 9 and 10

Question: Where, in the brain, does the second neurone terminate (the second relay station) and which part of the brain perceives pain?

Peter fell of his bike a week ago. He has been taking Ibuprofen regularly since then to help with the pain and inflammation. As Peter takes his Ibuprofen he wonders, how does it work?

Which of the following is the correct mechanism of action for Ibuprofen?
OptionA: Binds to opioid receptors on neurons and acts as a serotonin-norepinephrine re-uptake inhibitor (SNRI).
OptionB: Irreversible inhibitor of PGHS by causing acetylation of the serine residue in the COX domain.
OptionC: Glucocorticoid steroid receptor agonist which down regulates the pro-inflammatory response.
OptionD: Competes with arachidonic acid for the COX domain active site of PGHS.
OptionE: Opioid receptor agonist which suppresses pain-neuron synaptic communication.
Explanation:
A = incorrect. This is the MOA of Tramadol

B = Incorrect. This is the MOA of Aspirin

C = Incorrect. This is the MOA of Prednisolone

D = Correct! This is the right MOA of Ibuprofen

E = Incorrect. This is the MOA of Codeine

 

All of the information on here was from Dr Coffee's pharmacology light bulb for case 1 :)

Question: The sodium - potassium - ATPase is a component of the plasma membrane. 3 sodium ions & ATP bind intracellularly. After ATP is hydrolysed, what happens next?
OptionD: More sodium ions bind to the ATPase.
Explanation: The sodium - potassium - ATPase is a component of the cell's plasma membrane. Three sodium ions bind intracellularly, aswell as ATP. ATP is hydrolysed, causing sodium ions to move extracellularly, which then allows potassium to bind. Phosphate ions are lost, which moves potassium intracellularly.
Tags: Action Potential, Electrical Activity, Biochemistry, Ion transport, Chemistry of life

Question:
The following description best describes which cellular organelle? :

" This is a double-membrane bound structure within the cell. The membrane surrounding the structure has pores to allow the movement of RNA between the structure and the surrounding environment of the cell. Ribosome synthesis happens within this structure."
Explanation:
Nucleus

- Double membrane with pores to allow the movement of RNA

- Nucleolus = site of ribosome synthesis within the nucleus

Question: Which description best describes the rough endoplasmic reticulum?
OptionA: Double membrane with pores to allow movement of RNA, site of ribosome synthesis.
OptionB: Interconnecting tubular vesicles, protein synthesis, close to nucleus, post-transcription modification.
OptionC: Interconnecting tubular vesicles, lipid & carbohydrate synthesis, protein modification and transport to Golgi, calcium store.
OptionD: Interconnecting and budding vesicles containing proteins and lipids for exocytosis. Modifies/ transports/ packages proteins and lipids.
OptionE: Single membrane, lytic enzymes for for beta-oxidation of very long chain fatty acids, produces hydrogen peroxide.
Explanation:
A - nucleus 

C - smooth ER

D - Golgi apparatus

E - Peroxisomes

Question: Oscar visits a cardiologist as his GP suspects a possible arrhythmia. The cardiologist listens to Oscar's heart. Which of the following best describes where the cardiologist should be able to hear the tricuspid valve?
OptionA: To the right of the sternum, in the 4th intercostal space.
OptionB: To the left of the sternum, in the 4th intercostal space.
OptionC: To the right of the sternum, in the 2nd intercostal space.
OptionD: To the left of the sternum, in the 2nd intercostal space.
OptionE: In the left mid-clavicular line, in the 5th intercostal space.
Explanation:
A = incorrect. You cannot auscultate any valve here.

B = correct! 

C = incorrect. This is where the aortic valve should be heard.

D = incorrect. This is where the pulmonary valve should be heard.

E = incorrect. This is where the mitral valve (apex beat) should be heard.

Question:
Mr Clover, 57, present to A+E with unexplained chest pain. The pain started 3 hours ago and has been gradually getting worse. An ECG is performed.

Which of the following ECG leads shows the function of the anterior aspect of the heart?
Explanation:
A = incorrect. These leads look at the lateral aspect of the heart.

B = incorrect. These leads look at the inferior aspect of the heart.

C = Correct! These are the leads which correspond to the anterior aspect of the heart.

D = incorrect. These leads also look at the lateral aspect of the heart.

E = incorrect. These leads do not look at the lateral, anterior or inferior aspects of the heart.

Question: Which list best describes the histological layers of the trachea in order?
You are trying to interpret some arterial blood gas results. What diagnosis can you make if both the pH is decreased and the plasma CO2 is increased?
Explanation:
If the change in pH is opposite to the change in CO2 then it is to do with the respiratory system. As the pH is less than normal it is acidosis. 

 

In respiratory acidosis there is an increase in CO2 so the pH drops. To compensate there is a rise in HCO3- .

Question: Dr Jones has asked you to prescribe a long term muscarinic ACh receptor antagonist for Mr Williams COPD. What do you prescribe?
Explanation:
Salbutamol and salmeterol are B2 adrenoceptor agonists

Fluticasone is a steroid

Ipratropium is short acting

Question: You are on placement and meet a patient who has a Trendelenberg gait. This is when their pelvis drops to one side when walking and is usually due to damage to the superior gluteal nerve. Which two muscles is this affecting to cause this gait?
Explanation:
The correct answer is E as gluteus medius and gluteus minimus should act to prevent pelvic drop and are both supplied by the superior gluteal nerve.

 

Gluteus maximus does not act to prevent pelvic drop and is innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve, so A and D are incorrect.

Piriformis is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve but it does not act to prevent pelvic drop, so B and C are incorrect.

Tensor fascia lata is also innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.
Tags: Lower Limb, Anatomy, Anatomy of the lower limb, Case 1, lower limb anatomy

Question: Mr Burn is a patient of yours presenting with a tingling sensation. He also reports distal arm pain and tingling. It is believed the axillary artery is responsible. Which of the following does he most likely have?
Explanation:
Thoracic outlet syndrome is when blood vessels or nerves in the space between your collarbone and your first rib (thoracic outlet) are compressed. Presents with pain in limb that nerves supplying, tingling, muscle weakness & discolouration. 

 

D is too vague.
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of upper limb, Clinical relevance of anatomy

Question:
Jo presents to A&E with a suspected fracture to his right ankle. X-ray confirms it is a comminuted fracture.

You suspect there may have been an obstruction to the blood flow to his foot from one of the bone fragments as his foot appears blue in colour. 

Which artery would you check for a pulse in the foot to confirm this?
Explanation: Dorsalis pedalis is correct as the pulse can be felt in it- the dorsalis pedis artery pulse can be palpated readily lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon.
Tags: Lower Limb, Anatomy, Anatomy of the lower limb, Case 1

Question: Mary ha recently had a blood test due to a suspected infection. You are assessing her white blood cell count. Which of the following white blood cells is in lowest prevalence in the blood in normality?
Explanation:
Normal WBC proportions (roughly)
• Neutrophils 60%
• Lymphocytes 30%
• Monocytes 6%
• Eosinophils 3%
• Basophils 1%

Question: Which of the following organs has an important role in up regulating complement production in an immune response?
Explanation: Production of complement molecules, such as C3a and C3b, is carried out by liver hepatocytes & the liver is signalled to in inflammation to up regulate this production

Question: Roy has recently sustained a deep cut to his hand following an attempt to cook. He tries to pretend that it is not as painful as it appears and insists he is fine so as not to worry his parents and seem tough. Which of the following is involved in this response?
Explanation:
A - too vague 

B - lateral pain system is involved in sensory discrimination of pain but this is demonstrating an emotional response so it involves the medial pain system so C is correct

D & E are parts of the lateral pain system

Question: Rosanna has recently injured herself playing hockey and her ankle is very swollen. She explains that she cannot feel any pain associated with it but is experiencing an unpleasant emotional response. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this impaired experience of the pain?
Explanation:
The lateral pain system is involved in sensory discriminative aspects of pain and this is what is not fully functioning in the context. since the secondary somatosensory cortex is part of the lateral pain system, this is the correct answer. 

 

A-C are all part of the medial pain system involved in emotional response to pain

Question: Inflammation processes occur in the body when PRRs (pattern recognition receptors) detect either PAMPs (pathogen associated molecular patterns) or DAMPs (damage associated molecular patterns). Inflammation processes can also be stopped by stop signals. Which of the following is an example of a stop signal?
Explanation: B D & E are all inflammatory response mediators. Histamine & Nitric oxide cause vessels to vasodilate to increase their permeability and initiate the inflammatory response. IF these molecules have a short half life then they can terminate the acute inflammatory response but the best answer as an actual stop signal is C- lipoxin, which is a derivative of arachidonic acid.

Question:
Mr Marlow, 62, visits his GP after noticing he needs to urinate more frequently and that when he does urinate the flow is weaker than normal. On one occasion Mr Marlow also noticed a small amount of blood in his urine. The GP is concerned as these are all signs of possible prostate cancer.

In which lobe of the prostate is a malignant growth most likely to occur?
Explanation:
The lobes of the prostate are the anterior lobe, posterior lobe, middle lobe, and lateral lobes.

Therefore C and D are incorrect as they do not exist.

 

A = incorrect

B = Correct! The posterior lobe of the prostate is most susceptible to malignant changes.

E = incorrect. This lobe is most susceptible to hyperplasia causing benign growth.
Tags: Case 4, Reproductive systems, Reproductive Anatomy, Prostate

Question:
Mr Dowling presents to A+E with an inability to urinate. One of the F1 doctors inserts a catheter to help relieve his pain and discomfort. Whilst inserting the catheter the doctor thinks back to her anatomy sessions in year 1 and tries to remember the sections of the male urethra.

 

Which of the follow is NOT a part of the male urethra?
Explanation:
This picture shows the 4 parts of the male urethra.

C is incorrect as there isn't a section called the post-prostatic part.
Tags: Male Anatomy, Case 4, Reproductive Anatomy, Reproductive systems

Question: Which vessels dilate during an erection?
Explanation:
The internal pudendal arteries dilate in an erection to fill the corpus cavernosa with blood; the veins are compressed.

The testicular vessels do not supply the penis.
Tags: Anatomy of reproductive system, Reproductive Anatomy

Question: What type of epithelium is the germinal epithelium of the ovaries?
Tags: Anatomy of reproductive system, Female reproductive hormones, reproduction, Reproductive Anatomy

Question: Which best describes the epithelial changes seen at the transformation zone of the cervix as you move from endocervix to ectocervix?
Tags: Anatomy of reproductive system, reproduction, Reproductive Anatomy, Reproductive systems

Question: What is the order of the sperm drainage out of the testes?
OptionA: rete testis to seminiferous tubules to ductus deferens
OptionB: rete testis to ductus deferens to epididymis
OptionC: seminiferous tubules to ductus deferens to rete testis to ductus deferens
OptionD: seminiferous tubules to rete testis to epididymis to ductus deferens

Question: What is the target organ for ACTH?
Explanation:
FSH/LH - gonads

ACTH - adrenal cortex

TSH - thyroid 

Prolactin - Mammary gland 

GH - Liver (and all body)

 

Side note - a way to remember all anterior pituitary hormones is Toilet Paper FLAG. For posterior pituitary hormones, All Other (ADH and oxytocin)

ADH - kidneys 

Oxytocin - mammary gland

Question: What is the target organ for TSH?
Explanation:
FSH/LH - gonads
ACTH - adrenal cortex
TSH - thyroid
Prolactin - Mammary gland
GH - Liver (and all body)

 

Side note - a way to remember all anterior pituitary hormones is Toilet Paper FLAG. For posterior pituitary hormones, All Other (ADH and oxytocin)
ADH - kidneys
Oxytocin - mammary gland

Question: Which of the following has a role in converting androgens to oestrogens?
Explanation:
Aromatse converts androgens to oestrogens.

 

5-alpha-reductase converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone.

 

Chrysin inhibits aromatase.
Tags: Female reproductive hormones, Case 4, Reproductive systems

Question:
Jenna is an F1 doctor about to carry out a catheterisation on an elderly woman. 

The female uereter passes under the anastomosis of which 2 arteries?
Explanation: Ureter passes under ovarian and uterine arteries- remembered by 'water under the bridge'
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of reproductive system, Case 4, Reproductive systems

Question: Ryan, a junior doctor, is trying to palpate the femoral artery to check the femoral pulse in an investigation of one of his patients. Where is the femoral artery palpated?
Explanation:
The site for optimally palpating the femoral pulse is in the inner thigh, at the mid-inguinal point, halfway between the pubic symphysis and anterior superior iliac spine.

 

This is NOT the same as  the middle of the inguinal ligament which is where the deep inguinal ring lies.

Question:
Chloe, 27, has an ultrasound of her pelvis as both her GP and herself want to find the cause of her irregular periods.  The doctor performing the ultrasound notices that her uterus is tilted in the wrong direction.

Which of the following best describes the 'normal' position of the uterus?
Explanation:
A = Correct! The normal position of the uterus should be anteverted and anteflexed.

 

The angle between the fundus of the uterus and the cervix determines if it is bent forwards (anteflexed).

The angle between the body of the uterus and vagina determines if it is tilted forwards (anteverted).

 

Some people with a retroverted uterus may experience irregular periods and lower back pain during menstruation.

Question: One of your patients, a male in his 60s, has recently been diagnosed with prostatic cancer. Which of the following regions of the prostate are most commonly affected by prostate cancer?
Explanation: The peripheral zone of the prostate has the largest prostatic volume & is most commonly affected by prostate cancer
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of reproductive system, Case 4, Clinical relevance of anatomy

Question: Benign prostate enlargement is a condition common in men over the age of 50. It is caused by benign hyperplasia of the prostate. In which of the regions of the prostate is this most likely to occur?
Explanation: benign hyperplasia of the prostate is most common in the transition zone

Question: Jules, 89, was recently in a fight with his brother, Paul, 85. Unfortunately, when Jules fell, he suffered a penetrating wound to his thoracic duct below the level of T5.The thoracic duct is the largest lymph vessel in the body. Which of the following is the most likely outcome considering the position of his injury?
OptionA: Accumulation of lymph in the right pleural cavity
OptionB: Accumulation of lymph in the left pleural cavity
Explanation: Thoracic duct, moving upwards, shifts from RHS to LHS at T5 so answer is A if injured below T5.

Question: During DNA replication the lagging strand is replicated into Okazaki fragments. Which of the following enzymes joins Okazaki fragments together?
Explanation:
A = Incorrect. DNA polymerase is used to add complimentary bases to the strand being replicated.

B = Incorrect. DNA helicase breaks hydrogen bonds between bases on the template strand to form 2 single strands of DNA.

C = Correct! DNA ligase forms phosphodiester bonds between Okazaki fragments to make 1 continuous strand.

D = Incorrect. Topoisomerase helps to uncoil supercoiled double stranded DNA so that replication can occur.

E = Incorrect. RNA polymerase carries out transcription not replication.

Question: Hannah, 30, has come into your practice with Oligomenorrhea. A blood test is taken and she is found to have excess prolactin which,  on further investigation, is found to be due to a tumour on the pituitary gland. Which drug agonist can be used to treat Hannahs Hyperprolactinemia?
Explanation: Dopamine is an inhibitory hormone produced by the hypothalamus which inhibits the production of prolactin by lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary. Dopamine agonist drugs are therefore used to treat Hyperprolactinemia. They reduce prolactin levels and the size of the prolactin secreting tumours in most cases.

Question: IP3 and DAG are important in stimulating release of Ca 2+ from the smooth endoplasmic reticulum for smooth muscle contraction. Which of the following converts PIP2 to IP3 and DAG?
Explanation:
A = Incorrect. PI3K converts PIP2 to PIP3

B = Correct!

C = Incorrect. PTEN converts PIP3 to PIP2

D = Incorrect. Adenylyl cyclase converts ATP to cAMP

E = Incorrect. PDK activates AKT (protein kinase B)

Question: Conn's syndrome is a rare condition that occurs when adrenal glands make too much aldosterone. This problem is known as hyperaldosteronism. Aldosterone is a hormone that controls salt and posassium levels in the blood. Most often, patients have a higher blood pressure than normal. Conns syndrome could be due to a benign cortical adinoma. Which layer of the adrenal gland would the adenoma develop?
Explanation:
The Zona glomerulosa produces aldosterone. Conn's syndrome occurs when patients develop an adenoma (benign tumour) of the zona glomerulosa which secretes excess aldosterone, leading to primary hyperaldosteronism (teach me physiology) 

The Zona reticularis produces Androgens 

The Zona Fasiculata produces Glucocorticoids ( cortisol) 

Adrenal medulla produce norepinephrine and epinephrine 

More information: https://www.urologyhealth.org/urologic-conditions/conns-syndrome

Question: What is the difference between therapeutic index and spectrum?
OptionA:
Therapeutic Index looks at the effectiveness of the antibiotic in terms of concentration i.e if there it is high then there is a wide range of concentrations where it is effective, therefore only at high concentrations can toxicity occur. 

 

Therapeutic Spectrum refers to the number of bacteria the antibiotic is effective is against so if it is narrow then there is only a few bacteria it is effective against.
OptionB:
Therapeutic Index refers to the number of bacteria the antibiotic is effective is against so if it is narrow then there is only a few bacteria it is effective against.

 

Therapeutic Spectrum looks at the effectiveness of the antibiotic in terms of concentration i.e if there it is high then there is a wide range of concentrations where it is effective, therefore only at high concentrations can toxicity occur.

Question: Lily is running through the woodlands on her daily jog when she trips and falls over a fallen tree branch. She falls forward onto her hands, however, the pain of the fall is slightly masked by her elevated serotonin levels (raised in exercise), this is through pain inhibition in the Peri Aqueductal Grey pathway, how exactly does this process work?
OptionA: Encephalin releasing hormones are activated releasing neurones in the raphe nucleus > causes release of opioid neurotransmitters > interneurons in the substantia gelatinosa release serotonin > serotonin binds to A-delta and C fibres, inhibiting the release of Substance P so less pain is felt.
OptionB: Encephalin releasing hormones are activated releasing neurones in the raphe nucleus > causes release of serotonin > interneurons in the substantia gelatinosa release opioid neurotransmitters > opioid neurotransmitters bind to A-delta and C fibres, inhibiting the release of Substance P so less pain is felt.
OptionC: PAG stimulates activity in the prefrontal cortex, distracting and placing attention elsewhere so less pain felt.
OptionD: PAG stimulates lateral thalamic nuclei, therefore involved in perception of pain and tells you where it is.
Explanation:
A: incorrect, not serotonin but opioids involved in final step

C: incorrect PAG does not influence PFC, but PFC does have influence on distraction but in a different mechanism 

D: confusion here, PAG not involved with LTN, this is just location of the brain which has sensory features, able to discriminate the sensation, determining if pain is felt.

Question:
A patient presents with a history of large bruises appearing in the absence of trauma. You send them for tests which may help you diagnose a blood disorder. There results are as follows:

 

Bleeding time: normal

Prothrombin time: normal

Activated partial thromboplastin time (APPT): increased

Factor VIII activity: normal

Factor IX activity: decreased

vWF activity: normal

 

What does this suggest is wrong with the patient?
Explanation:
Bleeding time looks purely at the soft clot formation - doesn't involve clotting factors, does involve vWF

Prothrombin time looks at the extrinsic pathway - only involves factor VII

APPT looks at the intrinsic pathway so would be increased in all haemophilias

 

Haemophilia A affects factor VIII

Haemophilia B affects factors IX

Haemophilia C affects factor XI

Vitamin K is needed for the synthesis of factors II, VII, IX and X

Question: There are five muscles that make up the thoracic cage. These muscles act to change the volume of the thoracic cavity during respiration. A group of these muscles are known as the intercostals (including the internal, innermost and external intercostals). How many pairs of external intercostal muscles are there?
Tags: Aerobic respiration, Anaerobic respiration, Anatomy, Thorax

Question: The external intercostal muscles are one of the three types of intercostal muscles in the thoracic cage (including internal and innermost). In which direction do the fibres of the external intercostal muscles run?
OptionA: The fibres run inferoposteriorly from the rib above to the rib below.
OptionB: The fibres run inferoanteriorly from the rib above to the rib below.
OptionC: The fibres run superiorly and anteriorly from the rib below to the rib above.
OptionD: They run laterally in between each rib, originating from the sternum/ costal cartilages and attaching at the spine.
Explanation:
The fibres of the external intercostal muscles run inferoanteriorly from the rib above to the rib below i.e. they start at one rib, travel downwards and forwards until they attach at the rib underneath. 

A describes the direction that the internal intercostals run (inferoposteriorly from the rib above to the rib below).

 

C & D wrong.

Question: The muscles of the thoracic cage act to change the volume of the thoracic cavity during respiration. The external intercostals are one kind of thoracic muscle, they are continuous with which of the following abdominal muscles?
Explanation:
External oblique muscle is continuous with the external intercostal muscles of the thoracic cage. 

https://teachmeanatomy.info/thorax/muscles/thoracic-cage/

Question: Mr Jackson, 48, presents with jaundice and nausea to A&E. He is an IV drug user and tests reveal that he has Hepatitis C. The doctor explains to him what a chronic HCV infection is. Which of the following is NOT a complication of end stage liver disease?
Explanation: Ascites is fluid build up in the abdomen due to higher pressure in the liver, forcing fluid into the abdomen. Oesophageal varices often bleed. 80% of hepatitis C infections are chronic and lead to liver cirrhosis. HCV can lead to hepatocellular carcinoma.

Question: A - E are all anatomical borders of the perineum, which is the roof?
Explanation:
The anatomical borders of the perineum are:

Anterior – pubic symphysis.
Posterior – tip of the coccyx.
Laterally – inferior pubic rami and inferior ischial rami, and the sacrotuberous ligament.
Roof – pelvic floor.
Base – skin and fascia.

https://teachmeanatomy.info/pelvis/areas/perineum/

Question: What symptoms would a patient have if they had damage to  their basal ganglia?
OptionC: effects to their movement as well as psychiatric and cognitive symptoms
Explanation: The basal ganglia are important form movement but if damaged there will also be some psychiatric and cognitive symptoms

Question: Which answer correctly describes the flow of CSF in the Brian
OptionA: Produced in lateral ventricle-- travels to 3rd ventricle via interventricular foramen--travels to 4th ventricle via cerebral aqueduct--travels to 5th ventricle---travels into subarachnoid space where most is absorbed by arachnoid villus in superior saggital sinus
OptionB: Produced in lateral ventricle---travels to 3rd ventricle via interventricular foramen--travels into subarachnoid space where most is absorbed by arachnoid villus in superior saggital sinus--- travels to 4th ventricle via cerebral aqueduct
OptionC: Produced in lateral ventricle-- travels to 4th ventricle via cerebral aqueduct--travels to 3rd ventricle via interventricular foramen--travels into subarachnoid space where most is absorbed by arachnoid villus in superior saggital sinus
OptionD: Produced in lateral ventricle-- travels to 3rd ventricle via interventricular foramen--travels to 4th ventricle via cerebral aqueduct--travels into subarachnoid space where most is absorbed by arachnoid villus in superior saggital sinus
OptionE: Produced in lateral ventricle--- travels to 2nd ventricle-- travels to 3rd ventricle---travels to 4th ventricle---travels to arachnoid space

Question: The perineal body is an irregular fibromuscular mass. It is located at the junction of the urogenital and anal triangles & acts as an attachment point for muscles from the pelvic floor and the perineum itself. Which of the following muscles does not attach at the perineal body?
Explanation:
Anatomically, the perineal body lies just deep to the skin. It acts as a point of attachment for the following muscle fibres:

Levator ani (part of the pelvic floor).
Bulbospongiosus muscle.
Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles.
External anal sphincter muscle.
External urethral sphincter muscle fibres.

 

The ischiocavernosus attaches to the ischial tuberosity.
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of reproductive system, Urinary system, Pelvis and Perineum

Question: A 65 year old male comes to your GP surgery complaining of shortness of breath, coughing up blood and chest pain. On examination, you can hear coarse inspiratory crackles and wheezing on expiration. You also notice he has finger clubbing. You send him for a CT and it shows a Signet ring sign in his lungs. What is your diagnosis?
Explanation: Bronchiectasis presents with all of these symptoms and the signet ring sign on the CT scan. This is due to dilated alveoli.

Question: Which cells in the CNS break down harmful substances (such as excess neurotransmitter)?
Explanation: Astrocytes break down harmful substances such as excess neurotransmitter in the brain.

Question: Which cells of the CNS create the blood-brain-barrier?
Explanation: Astrocytes break down harmful substances such as excess neurotransmitter and create the blood-brain-barrier.

Question: What is the role of oligodendrocytes in the CNS?
OptionA: Relay information from PNS to CNS so that the CNS can respond accordingly.
OptionB: Break down of harmful substances and creating the blood-brain-barrier.
OptionC: Production of protein sheath, Myelin, which surrounds neurones to speed up the impulses they carry.
Explanation:
A = neuron

B = astrocyte

C = correct 

D = microglia

Question: Jane, an F1 doctor is working a night shift on Christmas Eve in A&E. Barry, a 63 year old retired teacher presents to A&E with a suspected myocardial infarction. The patient had endured this heart attack at the top of a flight of stairs at home. Jane sends for a TnI blood test as opposed to a total CK test. Why is this?
OptionA: A total CK test isn't as well detectable in males as it is in females
OptionB: A TnI test is cheaper than a total CK.
OptionC: Total CK test is faster than a TnI test. Both are cardiospecific.
OptionD: TnI is cardiospecific, whereas total CK is not.
OptionE: Non of the above. He should've used a myoglobin test.
Explanation: D is correct as troponin is cardiospecific. The patient may also have elevated total CK due to the MI or it may also have been released due to skeletal muscle damage from falling down the stairs.

Question:
A patient of yours, Emily, visits your practice complaining of fatigue, muscle ache and a loss of apatite. You decide that it is appropriate to perform a blood test to determine whether she is suffering with Hepatitis B. The results appear as follows: 

- HBsAg (negative) 

- Anti- HBc(negative) 

- Anti-HBs (positive) 

- IgM anti-HBc (negative) 

 

What can you conclude from this?
OptionA: She currently has HBV that can be passed on to others
OptionB: She has had HBV in the past but is now immune and the infection cannot be passed on to others
OptionC: She does not have HBV and is immune due to vaccination
Explanation:
• HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen): When this is positive, it means that you are currently infected with HBV and are able to pass the infection on to others
• Anti-HBc (antibody to hepatitis B core antigen): When this is positive or reactive, it means that you have HBV infection or had it at some time in the past.
• Anti-HBs (antibody to hepatitis B surface antigen): When this is positive, it means that you are immune to HBV infection, either from vaccination or from past infection and cannot pass the disease on to others.
• IgM anti-HBc: When this is positive or reactive, it indicates recent infection with HBV.

 

Emilys results show that her HBsAg is negative, therefore she is not currently infected. Her Anti HBc is negative and therefore she has not be infected in the past (So is also not chronically infected). Her Anti HBs is positive, which suggests that she is immune due to vaccination (as her other results show that she has not had the infection before)

Question: The oesophagus is a fibromuscular tube, approximately 25 cm in length, which carries food from the pharynx to the stomach. At which vertebral level does the oesophagus originate, and at which vertebral level does it end?
Explanation: The oesophagus originates at the inferior border of the cricoid cartilage, which is at level C6. It ends at the cardiac orifice of the stomach, which is at the level of T11.

Question:
A 19 year old female attends a GP consultation and is requesting contraception. She mentions a family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). 

For which type of contraception is a family history of DVT contraindicating?
Explanation:
the correct answer is A. 

The COCP contains a combination of oestrogen and progesterone. Oestrogen is contraindicating to a patient with a family history of DVT as oestrogen effects clotting factors.

Question: The uterine tube consists of 4 parts - the infundibulum fimbriae, the ampulla, the isthmus and the intramural part. These parts are all lined by epithelium. What type of epithelium is this?
Explanation: the epithelium in the uterine tubes is simple columnar epithelium. Some of the epithelial cells are ciliated and some aren't. the non-ciliated epithelial cells release nutritional secretions when stimulated by oestrogen in order to facilitate the developing ovum. the ciliated cells beat the ovum towards the sperm, allowing for fertilisation.

Question:
Epiphyseal plates located at the metaphysis of long bones. 

What are these plates made of?
Explanation:
Correct answer is C - hyaline cartilage

The epiphyseal plates are a layer of hyaline cartilage where ossification occurs in immature bones.

cartilage forms on the epiphyseal side & cartilage ossified on diaphyseal side resulting in diaphysis growing in length

https://opentextbc.ca/anatomyandphysiology/chapter/6-4-bone-formation-and-development/
Tags: Bone health, Bone structure, Cartilage, Case 1

Question:
Shown below are a set of up to date blood results that belong to a 40-year old man:

 

HBsAg: +

HBeAg: -

IgM anti-HBcAg: - 

IgG anti-HBsAg: -

IgG anti-HBcAg: +

IgG anti-HBeAg: +

 

Which of the following best describes his current status?
OptionB: He has had a HBV infection in the past that has spontaneously cleared
OptionD: he has a chronic HBV infection, but is low risk
OptionE: he has a chronic HBV infection and is high risk
Explanation:
Since he is HBsAg positive, he is currently infected with HBV (either acute or chronic) - this rules out A or B.

He is IgM anti-HBcAg negative, so the infection is chronic - this rules out C 

He is HBeAg negative (a positive result is a marker of high HPV replication), therefore he is low risk. This rules out E, meaning the answer is D.

Question: What is the MOA of aspirin?
OptionB: Acetylation of serine residue in COX domain of PGHS.
OptionE: Opioid receptor agonist, suppressing pain transmission centrally.
Explanation:
B is correct.

 

A - MOA of paracetamol.

C - MOA of ibuprofen. 

D - MOA of prednisolone. 

E - MOA of codeine.

Question: What is the MOA of fluticasone? What is it used to treat?
OptionA:
Beta-2 adrenoceptor agonist, which causes cAMP-regulated smooth muscle relaxation --> bronchodilation. 

 

Acute asthma/COPD.
OptionB:
Muscarinic acetylcholine receptor antagonist, which causes reduced cGMP and therefore smooth muscle relaxation occurs --> bronchodilation.

 

Acute asthma/COPD.
OptionC:
Anti-inflammatory steroid that binds to glucocorticoid steroid receptors leading to an increase in anti-inflammatory proteins/mediators. 

 

Acute asthma/COPD.
OptionD:
Muscarinic acetylcholine receptor antagonist that acts as a long-term bronchodilator. 

 

Moderate/severe COPD.
OptionE:
Beta-2 adrenoceptor agonist that acts as a long-term bronchodilator. 

 

Severe asthma.
Explanation:
C is correct.

 

A - MOA of salbutamol. 

B - MOA of ipratropium.

D - MOA of tiotropium.

E - MOA of salmeterol.

Question: What is the MOA of quinolones (antibiotics)?
OptionA: Block protein synthesis by binding to 30S ribosomal subunit.
OptionB: Inhibit cell wall synthesis by binding to PBPs, preventing cross-linking in peptidoglycan cell wall.
OptionD: Prevent DNA replication by inhibiting DNA topoisomerase.
OptionE: Inhibit protein synthesis by competing for the 'A' site on tRNA on 50S ribosomal subunit.
Explanation:
D is correct.

 

A - MOA of aminoglycosides. 

B - MOA of beta-lactams.

C - MOA of sulfonamides. 

E - MOA of tetracyclines.

Question: Which of these drugs blocks nAChR's?
Explanation:
C is correct.

 

A, B & D all inhibit acetycholine-esterase. 

 

Acetylcholine-esterase  and nAChR inhibitors both work to increase the amount of acetylcholine (ACh), leading to better neuronal functioning. 

Although, as AD progresses, their efficacy decreases, as more neuro-degeneration, so less target tissue for the drugs is available. 

 

E is an anti-coagulant drug that inhibits factor Xa (Case 2).

Question: What is the MOA of ranitidine?
OptionA: Irreversible PPI that stops H+ ions moving into the lumen of the stomach, therefore reducing HCl secretion.
OptionB: Contains magnesium/calcium carbonate, so neutralises the low pH, producing CO2 that can causes side effects such as burping.
OptionC: Reversible PPI that increases the amount of H+ ions moving into the lumen of the stomach, therefore decreasing HCl secretion.
OptionD: Competitive and irreversible agonist of H2-receptors, which leads to reduced cAMP regulated activation of the H+-K+ ATPase proton pump.
OptionE: Competitive and reversible antagonist of H2-receptors, which leads to reduced cAMP regulated activation of the H+-K+ ATPase proton pump.
Explanation:
A - MOA of esomeprazole - PPI.

B - MOA of alkaline antacids. 

C - made up - PPIs are irreversible and decrease amount of H+ moving into lumen. 

D - H2 antagonists are reversible antagonists. 

E - correct :)

Question: David, 35, comes into your clinic with epigastric discomfort, nausea and dyspepsia. These symptoms are worse after he has eaten. He has also been vomiting some blood (haematemesis). He subsequently undergoes a Blood test, which reveals that he has iron deficiency anaemia. A carbon urea breath test also confirms the presence of H pylori. A biopsy taken excludes cancer. Based on the available information, what is a reasonable diagnosis for David?
Explanation:
Davids presentation is indicative of a peptic ulcer. The presence of h pylori helps to Identify this further. Blood test revealing iron deficiency anaemia may reveal constant low level bleeding from the ulcer. This is quite a common presentation of a gastric ulcer or a gastric cancer. However, the cancer can be excluded as the biopsy was negative. His symptoms were worse upon eating, which is suggestive of a gastric ulcer as pain from this is typically worsened by eating. Pain from Duodenal ulcers Is typically improved through eating. 

Achalasia and corkscrew oesophagus are motility disorders. They have some similarities in presentation (dyspepsia for example) however can be more classically defined by dysphagia.

Question: Whilst strutting around the SU, a person starts on Aled and initiates a fight. During this encounter Aled's sympathetic nerve system is activated. What is the result of sympathetic stimulation on the body?
OptionC: Bronchoconstriction, vasodilation, increased chronotropy, stimulation of grey body in the pre-frontal cortex
Explanation:
A- doesn't vasodilate

B- bronchodilates and causes ionotropy

C -bronchodilates,, vasoconstriction

D- correct.

E- vasoconstrictor
Tags: Cardiac Action Potential, Cardiac cycle, Case 2, sympathetic innervation

Question:
Louisa is on her placement at a GP surgery in Cardiff where she meets 80 year old Mr Smith. He has a chronic cough which has a larger diurnal variation (so there is a lower peak flow in the morning compared to the afternoon). He also presents with atopy, so has eczema and hayfever. Mr Smith explains that his cough is worse at night and as he talks, she notices he wheezes regularly. 

Dr Thomas says his FEV1:FVC shows bronchodilator reversibility of 15% and then asks Louisa what respiratory condition Mr Smith might have, can you help her?
Explanation:
Mr Smith likely has asthma, this is due to a range of reasons, firstly, due to the bronchodilator reversibility, this would have no effect on COPD patients as the airflow obstruction is not fully reversible. Also, a night cough is present in asthma patients due to a dip in corticosteroids at night (may be prescribed for asthmatics), thus increasing inflammation and irritation of the airways, whereas in COPD the airways are permanently obstructed i.e. due to mucus and reduced elasticity so the cough is chronic, always bad. 

 

Presence of ATOPY is significant as asthma is likely caused by inappropriate immune response, therefore leading to other heightened immune responses and allergic reactions like hayfever. 

 

Important to note that COPD is permanent damage to airways and is likely irreversible, like emphysema whereas asthma is reversible airway limitation and hyperresponsiveness caused by an inappropriate immune response.

Question: Which factor reduces gastric acid secretion through antagonising histamine?
Explanation:
Both Gastrin and Acetylcholine (from the vagus nerve) stimulate gastric acid secretion 

Somatostatin is released by D cells in response to low pH. Will inhibit gastric secretion through acting on Gi protein coupled receptors 

Secretin is released into the duodenum in response to fatty acid, low pH and hypertonicity. Secretin inhibits gastrin. 

Prostoglandin E2 inhibits gastric secretion by antagonising histamine (which stimulates gastric acid secretion). This is a reason why NSAIDS can increase susceptibility to gastric ulcers and gastritis. 

(Prostaglandins also stimulate the secretion of mucous and HC03-, which maintains the protective mucosal barrier)

Question: Which of the following does NOT cause the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the right?
Explanation:
D = correct!

 

Increased temperature, CO2 and 2,3 DPG as well as decreased pH cause the curve to shift to the right.

Question:
Daisy realises that she needs Brooke to do her 'mum voice' much louder when she tells her off and suspects that she has some form of hearing loss. She decides to see an ENT and have her ears checked where they perform the Rinne's and Weber's tests. Her results are as follows:

 

- Rinne's test positive 

- In the Weber's test she hears the sound better in her right ear
OptionA: sensorineural hearing loss in her left ear
OptionC: conductive hearing loss in her left ear
OptionD: conductive hearing loss in her right ear
Explanation:
Rinne's test 

- a positive test result (when the air is louder than the mastoid bone) means either normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss 

- a negative test result (when the mastoid bone is louder than the air) means that there is conductive hearing loss

 

Weber's test

- when the sound is heard equally in the midline, there is normal hearing 

- when there is a negative Rinne's test, sound is heard better in the bad ear --> conductive hearing loss 

- when there is a positive Rinne's test, sound is heard better in the good ear --> sensorineural hearing loss

 

Daisy has a positive rinne's test, meaning she has either normal or sensorineural hearing loss 

if she had normal hearing she would hear the sound equally in both ears in the Weber's test, however this is not the case

she hears sound better in the right ear, meaning she has sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear because sound is heard better in the good ear (right ear) 

http://www.oxfordmedicaleducation.com/clinical-examinations/tuning-fork-rinnes-webers-test/

Question: what is the function of the endocochlear potential
OptionA: allows for a large influx of Na+ from the endolymph into the hair cells when the movement of the stereocilia cause the opening of the ion channels
OptionB: allows for a large influx of Ca2+ from the endolymph into the hair cells when the movement of the stereocilia cause the opening of the ion channels
OptionC: allows for a large efflux of K+ from the endolymph into the hair cells when the movement of the stereocilia cause the opening of the ion channels
OptionD: allows for a large influx of K+ from the endolymph into the hair cells when the movement of the stereocilia cause the opening of the ion channels
OptionE: allows for a large influx of Na+ from perilymph into the hair cells when the movement of the stereocilia cause the opening of the ion channels
Explanation:
The scala media contains a fluid called ENDOLYMPH which is high in K+
- Endolymph is produced by a type of endothelium called stria vascularis which makes up the spiral ligament
- The stria vascularis also has a electrogenic Na+/K+ pump to allow for the flow of ions

 

The difference in composition of endolymph and perilymph creates an endocochlear potential → allows a massive influx of K+ from the endolymph to the hair cells when the mechanically sensitive ion channels open due to movement of stereocilia therefore the answer is D

Question: Emily, 18, has been struggling with low mood. Her mum suggests she nips into Holland and Barrett and picks up some St Johns Wort to help her. The only other medication Emily knows she is taking is Microgynon. Could this be a problem Emily?
OptionA: Yes. St Johns Wort reduces the effectiveness of her medication by increasing the rate at which it is metabolised, reducing it to sub therapeutic levels
OptionB: Yes. St Johns Wort has the potential to increase the circulating concentration of her medication, increasing the potential of ADR.
OptionC: No. St Johns Wort enhances the effectiveness of her medication.
OptionD: No. St Johns Wort has no effect on her medication. They are metabolised by different isoforms of enzyme
Explanation:
Microgynon is an example of the COCP. 

St John's Wort (containing hyperforin) can induce more CYP3A4 which then also metabolises the COCP containing ethinylestradiol , reducing it to sub-therapeutic levels

The antibiotic erythromycin occupies CYP3A4 preventing metabolism of the COCP containing ethinylestradiol . This increases potential for ethinylestradiol ADRs.

Question: Which of the following hormones is NOT released by the anterior pituitary gland?
Explanation:
D = correct!

Anterior pituitary hormones: FSH, LH, PRL, GH, TSH, ACTH

Posterior pituitary hormones: ADH, oxytocin

Question: Which of the following is not a portal-systemic anastomoses where obstructions can occur?
Explanation:
There are a number of areas in the body where there are connections between the portal and systemic circulations (anastomoses) which are sites of potential complications if obstructions occur. These sites include: 

- where the oeosphagus wins drain into azygous veins - oesophagus varies 

- between the rectal veins - inferior and middle into IVC and superior as inferior mesenteric vein - can cause haemorrhoids 

- para- umbilical veins of anterior wall with periumbilical superficial epigastric veins can cause caput medusae which is the appearance of distended and engorged and superior epigastric veins will radiate across the umbilicus.

Question: Which of the following correctly describes what a positive Hep B surface antigen represents?
OptionA: when this is positive or reactive it indicates a recent infection with HBV
OptionB: means, if positive, that you are immune to HBV either though vaccination or past infection and are no longer able to pass the disease onto others
OptionC: when this is positive it means that you currently have the HBV virus and are able to pass it onto other individuals
OptionD: when this is positive it means that you have the infection of HBV or have had it some time in the past
Explanation:
A- IgM anti HBc 

B - Anti HBs

D- Anti hep B core antigen

Question:
The Dorsal striatum is considered the “Habit Hub”. It provides input into the basal ganglia as these structures receive the majority of the afferents from other brain regions. The dorsal striatum is important for associative learning. 

Which structures comprise the dorsal striatum?
Explanation:
The dorsal striatum comprises the putamen and caudate nucleus 

 

Ventral striatum (Accubens nucleus) is considered the “reward hub”. It is associated with motivation and reward of behavior .

Question: You are a junior doctor doing a cardiovascular exam and you are listening for the patient's heart sounds. A murmur is heard in systole - what condition does this indicate?
Explanation:
Systole is heard as a swoosh and then a pulse while diastolic is in between the pulses. 

Aortic stenosis is where the valves narrow and an aortic stenosis is heard in systole while a mitral stenosis is heard in diastole. 

Aortic regurgitation is heard in diastole while mitral regurgitation is heard in systole.

Question: What are the 3 deep muscles of the shoulder?
Explanation: Trapezius and Latissimus Dorsi are both superficial extrinsic shoulder muscles. Extrinsic shoulder muscles originate from the torso and attach to the scapula/and or clavicle.
Tags: Anatomy of upper limb, Upper Limb, Upper Limb Anatomy

Question: A patient presents at A&E complaining of pain and tenderness in a specific anatomical area on the hand. After taking a history, you find that the patient has fallen on an outstretched hand (FOOSH). You suspect a fracture of one of the carpal bones and send the patient for an x-ray to confirm this diagnosis. Which of the carpal bones is the patient most-likely to have fractured?
Explanation: The scaphoid bone of the hand is the most commonly fractured carpal bone - typically caused by a FOOSH. The characteristic feature is pain and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox (specific anatomical area on the hand). Given the fact that the patient has fallen on an outstretched hand, and the question specifies pain in a specific anatomical area on the hand, the answer should be scaphoid.

Question: The supraglenoid tubercle is a bony landmark on the lateral surface of the scapula. Which of the following statements is true?
OptionA: The subscapularis muscle originates in the supraglenoid tubercle.
OptionB: The long head of the biceps brachii attaches at the supraglenoid tubercle.
OptionC: Pectoralis minor attaches at the supraglenoid tubercle.
OptionE: Biceps brachii originates at the supraglenoid tubercle.
Explanation: A is incorrect because subscapularis originates from the subscapular fossa of the scapula. B is correct. The long head of the biceps brachii does attach at the supraglenoid tubercle (a roughening immediately superior to the glenoid fossa of the scapula). C is incorrect because pectoralis minor attaches at the coracoid process, which is also where coracobrachialis and biceps brachii originate (making D and E incorrect). This information can be found here : https://teachmeanatomy.info/upper-limb/bones/scapula/

Question: Which feature is not observed in interstitial fibrosis?
OptionE: Small contracted lung and rib cage with raised diaphragm on chest radiograph
Explanation:
Honey comb lung: The alveolar architecture is destroyed and the scarring results in multiple air filled cystic spaces formed by terminal and respiratory bronchioles- so called honeycomb lung

Hypertension: pulmonary hypertension may be caused from the destruction of so many pulmonary capillaries 

Dyspnea: fibrosis makes the lungs stiff , reducing compliance.  This means patients suffer with dyspnea as stiff lungs are difficult to inflate

Drastically reduced FEV1 is more often observed in patients with obstructive diseases. In restrictive lung diseases, as pulmonary fibrosis, FEV1 is slightly reduced, but can sometimes even be normal (depending on the severity). 

Small contracted lung and rib cage on chest radiograph --> 

The increases elastic recoil pulled the ribcage inwards and the diaphragm upwards. The reticular shaddowing (in the image) is caused by the destruction due to fibrosis of the alveoli walls

Question: Which of the factors listed below may cause increased sensitivity to noise ( Hyperacusis) ?
Explanation:
The stapedius reflex is a protective mechanism which is evoked by loud sounds. Loud sound elicits reflex contraction of tensor tympani and stapedius. Muscle tension tightens the tympanic membrane and alters the position of the ossicles to reduce the impact of loud noise. The stapedius muscle, supplied by the facial nerve, limits the movement of the stapes to protect the cochlea. In Bell's palsy, there is facial nerve paralysis and the patient will consequently suffer from hyperacusis (sensitivity to loud noise) 

In Waardenbergs syndrome, the cells that control K+ secretion in the stria Vascularis fail to migrate during tissue development, resulting in deafness as there is no endocochlear potential 

Otosclerosis is a form of conductive hearing loss 

Presbycusis is hearing loss (particularly at higher frequencies) caused by natural ageing of the auditory system 

Adverse reaction to antibiotics (such as aminoglycosides) can cause hearing loss too.

Question: Bone is a specialised type of connective tissue, which has a specialised ultra structure in order to perform specific functions, i.e. storage of lipids and minerals. Which of the following is stored within the bone marrow?
Explanation: Adipose tissue is stored within the bone marrow, while calcium (B) is stored within hydroxyapatite crystals (C).

Question: There are three types of cells in bone. Which of the following statements is true for osteoblasts?
OptionA: These cells will monitor minerals and proteins to regulate bone mass.
OptionB: These cells synthesise unmineralised extracellular matrix called osteoid.
OptionD: These cells release H+ ions and lysosomal enzymes.
OptionE: These cells are large and multi nucleated.
Explanation:
A - osteocyte

C - osteoclasts

D - osteoclasts

E - osteoclasts
Tags: Bone health, Bone structure, PCS 1, Case 1, microbiology

Question: There are two types of bone - lamellar and woven. Which of the following statements best describes woven bone?
OptionA: Consists of highly organised sheets of mineralised osteoid, appears in embryonic development as it can be laid down rapidly, permanent structure.
OptionB: Consists of osteoid (unmineralised ECM), collagen fibres highly organised, temporary structure, can be divided into two types - compact and spongy.
OptionC: Consists of highly organised sheets of mineralised osteoid, appears in embryonic development as it can be laid down gradually, collagen fibres highly organised, permanent structure.
OptionD: Consists of osteoid (unmineralised ECM), appears in embryonic development and fracture repair as it can be laid down rapidly, collagen fibres arranged randomly, temporary structure.
OptionE: Consists of osteoid (unmineralised ECM), appears in embryonic development as it is laid down gradually, temporary structure, can be divided into two types - compact and spongy.
Explanation:
Under the microscope, bone can be divided into two types:

Woven bone (primary bone) – Appears in embryonic development and fracture repair, as it can be laid down rapidly. It consists of osteoid (unmineralised ECM), with the collagen fibres arranged randomly. It is a temporary structure, soon replaced by mature lamellar bone.
Lamellar bone (secondary bone) – The bone of the adult skeleton. It consists of highly organised sheets of mineralised osteoid. This organised structure makes it much stronger than woven bone. Lamella bone itself can be divided into two types – compact and spongy.

Question: Which of the following is a disadvantage of the use of longitudinal studies when looking at the cognitive effect of ageing?
OptionB: performances can't be related to individual earlier/future performance
OptionC: effect of age can be determined on an individual bases
Explanation:
A - this is an advantage of cross-sectional studies where there is a recruitment of different groups of people which are sampled across the age range and with each individual being tested once which means it is quicker and less expensive form of testing. 

B - this is a disadvantage of cross sectional testing 

C - this is an advantage of longitudinal studies which is where there is a recruitment of a representative sample tested repeatedly over time and this can then be useful in pinpointing precursors of disease. 

D - this is a disadvantage of longitudinal and can mean the sample becomes less representative 

E - this is a disadvantage of cross sectional studies

Question: Alzhiemiers disease is associated with the build up of what extracellularly?
Explanation:
Bet amyloid peptide is deposited extracellularly in plaques and also the build up of tau protein in a pathological form which accumulates but intracellularly as neurofibrillary tangles and this is accompanied by neuronal loss. 

The pathological diagnosis of AD rests on the presence of amyloid plaques and NFT.

Question: A patient presents with an inability to comprehend and produce meaningful language - where is the likely location of their lesion?
Explanation:
A - amusia is as a result of a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus which connects the Broca and Wernicke's area together and the patient is unable to recognise musical tones and reproduce them. 

B - Broca's aphasia is characterised by comprehension intact but there is trouble producing speech and it is brocken up. 

D - this is from a lesion in the fusiform gyrus of the temporal cortex and it is an inability to recognise people from their faces.

E - this is from damage to the posterior cerebral artery where contralateral field of both eyes is affected

Question: Mary, a 27 year old female has arrived at the hospital as her waters have broken and she is ready to give birth. Whilst at the hospital, amidst the pain of labour she wonders to herself, through which layers does the oocyte rupture through to be released into the peritoneal cavity?
Explanation: Case 4- anatomy and physiology lecture.

Question: Exocrine pancreatic secretion includes several enzymes that are vital for the digestion & absorption of various nutrients, including lipids. One such lipid absorbed in the small intestine is lecithin (phosphatidyl choline). Which pancreatic enzyme facilitates the breakdown of lecithin?
Explanation:
A: also present in small intestine, but breaks down the 2-ester linkage of triglycerides specifically

B: the correct answer.

C: incorrect and we haven't really learnt about it.

D: involved in cell signalling; breaks down PIP 2 to produce IP3 and DAG

E. lipoprotein lipase is synthesised by adipocytes and usually found in adipose tissue. it is involved in the breakdown/digestion of chylomicrons once they have left the small intestine and travel to adipose tissue.
Tags: Lipids and cardiovascular disease, Digestion, Enzymes, GI tract, Biochemistry

Question: The SA node is the heart's intrinsic pacemaker, located in the right atrium, near it's junction with the vena cava. How fast are the electrical impulses of the heart conducted through the atrial muscle?
Explanation:
The following information is from Geeky Medics:
The sinoatrial node (SAN) is of a group of cells found high up in the right atrium close to its junction with the superior vena cava.1,4,5
The SAN functions as the heart’s intrinsic pacemaker, regulating heart rate.
The SAN spontaneously generates electrical impulses which are transmitted to the right and left atrium.
These electrical impulses stimulate the atrial myocardium to contract.
Atrial muscle conducts relatively fast (0.5m/sec).
Tags: Anatomy, PCS 2, Cardiac Action Potential, Cardiac anatomy, Cardiac cycle

Question: The AVN has a slower conduction velocity than the atria, to allow for maximal ventricular filling prior to contraction. Which of the following values are correct for the conduction velocity of the muscular walls of the atria, and the AVN?
Explanation: The AVN has a slower conduction velocity (0.05m/sec) than the atria (0.5 m/sec), allowing maximal ventricular filling prior to contraction. (Geeky Medics)
Tags: PCS 2, Cardiac Action Potential, Cardiac anatomy, Cardiac cycle

Question: Which of the following does not apply to smooth muscle contraction?
OptionA: most of the calcium comes from extracellular fluid
OptionB: there is physical coupling of the ryanodine receptors on the cisternae and the dihydroryanodine receptors on sarcolemma
OptionC: entry of calcium ions forms a complex with calmodulin
OptionD: myosin light chain kinase is activated which phosphorylates MRLC which leads to contraction
OptionE: Neurotransmitters cause the phosphorylation of enzymes involved in pumping out calcium across the membrane
Explanation: B - this describes the relationship with skeletal muscle

Question: Which of the following muscles is not innervated by the median nerve?
Explanation: B-E are all inverted by the median nerve and it can be remembered using the acronym LOAF.

Question: Jim's just gotten a new iPhone and is playing around with portrait mode on the camera app. The way the camera is able to focus on a nearby object and blur out objects in the distance reminds him of how the human eye works in a similar way. The ciliary muscle in the eye controls accommodation for viewing objects at varying distances. Which cranial nerve innervates this muscle?
OptionA: Ophthalmic nerve (branch of CN V trigeminal nerve)
Explanation:
A. Ophthalmic nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin, mucous membranes and sinuses of the upper face and scalp.

B. Optic nerve functions to transfer visual information from the retina to the brain

C. correct answer. Whilst the oculomotor nerve innervates the superior, inferior and medial rectus muscles & the inferior oblique muscle, it also provides parasympathetic innervation to the ciliary muscle and pupil (facilitating pupillary constriction).

D. Abducens nerve provides motor innervation to the lateral rectus muscle

E. Trochlear nerve provides motor innervation to the superior oblique muscle
Tags: Cranial nerve, Anatomy, Eye, Nervous System, PCS 3

Question: Its the third round of the fight between Conor McGregor and Nate Diaz. Nate throws a jab but Conor moves to the side and lands a hook. After landing the hook onto Nate‘s head, he experiences pain and swelling in his hand. McGregor is diagnosed with boxer’s fracture, which metacarpal did Conor most likely break?
Explanation:
5th metacarpal, specifically the neck

It is usually caused by a clenched fist striking a hard object. The distal part of the fracture is displaced anteriorly, producing shortening of the affected finger.

Question: Its the rematch between McGregor and Khabib that we have all been finally waiting for. In the first round, Khabib was able to land a couple of takedowns but McGregor luckily escaped them all. Then in the second round, Khabib picked up and slammed McGregor onto the ground. Unfortunately McGregor’s shoulder is dislocated from this and he is unable to extend his arm, forearm, wrist and fingers. Which nerve has most likely been damaged?
Explanation:
Radial nerve has been damaged

 

https://teachmeanatomy.info/upper-limb/nerves/radial-nerve/

 

The radial nerve can be damaged in the axilla region by a dislocation at the shoulder joint, or a fracture of the proximal humerus. Occasionally, it is injured via excessive pressure on the nerve within the axilla (e.g. a badly fitting crutch).

Motor functions – the triceps brachii and muscles in posterior compartment are affected. The patient is unable to extend at the forearm, wrist and fingers. Unopposed flexion of wrist occurs, known as wrist-drop.
Sensory functions – all four cutaneous branches of the radial nerve are affected. There will be a loss of sensation over the lateral and posterior arm, posterior forearm, and dorsal surface of the lateral three and a half digits.

Question:
Jackson has suffered a major haemorrhage and is consequently Hypovolemic. Which functional zone of pulmonary blood flow is most likely observed in the apical of the lung? 

 

PA: Alveolar pressure 

Pa : Arterial pressure 

Pv: Venous pressure
Explanation:
Zone 1 is defined as those areas of the lung where alveolar pressure exceeds that of the pulmonary arterial pressure. Consequently, the pulmonary arteries become compressed and shut, eliminating blood flow in this zone and thus creating a zone of dead space. Zone 1 likely does not exist in a healthy individual's lungs as pulmonary arterial pressures just exceed that of alveolar pressure even at the top of the lung apex. However, in scenarios of hypovolemia such as major hemorrhage, reductions in pulmonary arterial pressure may result in the generation of a Zone 1 in the apical lung.

 

http://www.pathwaymedicine.org/pulmonary-blood-flow-distribution

Question: Which nerve has been damaged?
Explanation:
long thoracic nerve 

 

If this nerve becomes damaged, the scapula protrudes out of the back when pushing with the arm. The long thoracic nerve can become damaged by trauma to the shoulder, repetitive movements involving the shoulder or by structures becoming inflamed and pressing on the nerve.

Question: Masvidal achieved the quickest UFC knockout ever after landing a flying knee onto Askren in 5 seconds. Identify the bone type of the patella
Explanation: The answer is sesamoid bone

Explanation: The answer is Pseudo-stratified columnar epithelium
